When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal views, and experiences, as well as social and cultural influences. In this book, we will explore how these factors affect the style and meaning of a photograph, and how viewers understand and react to these images. For example, a person reading a newspaper may think they understand the photos printed there. However, instead of just accepting the photo as it is, we can ask if it truly shows what happened at that moment. Does it show the photographer's opinion? Is the exact moment captured important, or should we see the photo as a symbol of a bigger issue in the world?
**More than a Game**  
For me, sports are more than just a game. The most successful athletes believe in themselves completely. To succeed in sports, you need to focus only on that goal. It is a tough world, and no one will do the work for you. You either succeed or fail. Sports have taught me discipline and determination, but they also show the importance of teamwork. My sport allows me to shine individually, but it is still a team effort, and I must balance both. This is similar to life – you can achieve things on your own, but you should always remember the people around you. Sports have given me a lot, not just money. They have opened doors for me and shown me things in the world that many people will never see. However, you also have to give up a lot to enjoy these benefits.
**Tuning In**  
Some experiences stay in our memory very clearly. For me, one special moment happened many years ago in California. One night, I was awake listening to a beautiful mockingbird singing from a tree in my neighborhood. I don’t have trouble sleeping, but the bird's amazing song kept me awake. As I listened to its complex melodies, I felt like I was in a beautiful musical world. To understand the bird's patterns, I thought about my experiences with jazz and Indian classical music. The bird made me feel like I was enjoying a stunning live performance. I reacted with joy as I listened to its surprising musical changes until I finally fell asleep.

People have always had strong feelings about birds. They love them, fear them, and even worship them. But what does this say about us? 
In a greenhouse, a little brown bird called a wren is bumping against the glass. Some people think wrens are special birds that bring messages from another world. Others might just see it as a bird that is stuck. Both ideas could be true. 
Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In medieval times, people believed that the way wrens flew could tell them about their luck. Today, you can still see images of wrens in many British homes. Even if old beliefs about them are not as strong now, people still care about wrens. A place without wrens feels sad and empty. 
This connection with birds comes from a time when people relied more on nature for survival. They developed a way to understand the importance of different animals. However, these beliefs can change over time. 
For example, the red kite bird was once seen as a valuable part of city life in London. People were amazed to see them flying down to take bread from children. But soon, they were seen as pests and disappeared from many areas. Now, red kites are protected again and are symbols of conservation in Britain. 
Our connection with birds goes back to the beginning of human history. Early humans watched birds closely because they could warn them about danger or bad weather. Birds also connected them to their dreams. 
Birds are important to us because they represent freedom and beauty. Some people think our feelings for birds are old and not needed anymore. But these feelings are still part of who we are, and losing them would be hard. 
Recently, birds have become important indicators of environmental change. In Britain, 30 bird species are now endangered. This is sad not only because we might lose these birds but also because it means losing part of our culture. 
Certain birds, like the skylark and turtle dove, represent love and magic in stories and poems. Many people feel sad about losing these birds because they are part of our literature and folklore. However, we often ignore the loss of other birds that are not mentioned in stories. 
Folklore is very important. The stories and legends about birds connect us to our past in a way that scientific facts cannot. These stories help us feel emotions that are often hidden in our busy lives. 
Whether we watch birds on TV or in our backyards, the joy we feel from them is hard to explain with science. Birds engage us in ways we don’t fully understand. The wren in the greenhouse connects our present with a rich history, reminding us of the mysteries of life.

**Maps**
The purpose of a map is to show the relationships between different places and features on the earth. These relationships are based on distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance in time, like saying "it takes so many hours to walk" or "a day's journey by river." This way of measuring was more about how easy it was to travel through the land than about the actual distance.
Direction is also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were "Where do I go from here?" and "How far away is it?" Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like those for train systems, do not show true directions. In the beginning, important landmarks along a route were marked by signs that varied in size to show their importance.
Different maps have different styles based on their purpose and location. To understand early maps, it is important to know the style used. The history of map-making, or cartography, shows how the accuracy of distance and direction has improved over time. Other sciences have helped in this process. For example, instead of using shadows or stars to find direction, people started using the magnetic compass and other tools to measure angles accurately.
As explorers learned more about the world, they tried to create better maps. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, which helped improve large area maps. The needs of map users changed too. Travelers and merchants were not the only ones using maps anymore. Soldiers needed accurate maps for military purposes, especially after the invention of artillery. This led to the creation of contour maps, which show the shape of the land.
Later, archaeologists, historians, and modern geographers also needed maps for their work. Today, cartographers create maps for many different topics, like geology, climate, and land use. The growing recognition of the importance of maps in many sciences has led to a new interest in cartography.
It is important to note that the development of maps has not always been steady. There have been times of slow progress and times of quick change. Old ideas sometimes stayed alongside new ones. Cartographers have often had good ideas but had to wait for better tools to use them. Since it is easy to copy old maps, many map publishers have been slow to accept new ideas.
Therefore, we should not blindly trust maps as proof of current knowledge and techniques. The many maps we have today are the result of a lot of human effort and thought. They are valuable records for studying human history. This is what makes the study of historical cartography interesting and important.

I was taken into a young man's living room, which was a nice and calm place compared to the messy rooms where his family members spent time. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class. This room had the biggest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player I had encountered, and it was surprising to see a teenager who had bought expensive wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had a scholarship to study history at Magdalen College, Oxford, and he had nine months before starting school. During this time, he wanted to become a famous composer like Richard Rodgers.
I also had big dreams; I wanted to be a pop star for good reasons like women, money, and fame. But my dreams were not as important to me as Andrew's were to him. When Andrew suggested that I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I was open to it. This was partly because, after just ten minutes of meeting him, he played me three of his own songs, and I could tell he was very talented.
As he played more songs from the shows he had created at school, I remembered some of the best albums from my parents' collection. He needed a new lyricist, and I didn’t have much to show him except for my praise for his music and a single I had written that had not helped an unknown pop group’s career. We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theater, but I knew I had met someone special who would likely succeed in musical theater soon.
The next day, back at my office where I was training to be a lawyer, the excitement I felt about working with Andrew had faded a bit. I would still look for ads for groups needing a singer and write more simple songs, but it seemed likely I would finish my exams and become a lawyer by twenty-five. My father thought I would stop enjoying pop music by twenty-one, which worried me because that meant I only had a few months left to enjoy it. But I thought it would be fun to see Andrew again, go to a musical with him, and write lyrics for musicals instead of pop songs. Andrew was an interesting person who talked about good food and old buildings, and he supported a football team.
I wasn’t sure about the musical idea he had been working on for a year, but I knew he was very talented and had good connections. I soon found myself back in his living room. The idea was about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, a man from the 19th century who started orphanages. His story was important, but it didn’t excite me much. The main character seemed too perfect, and the idea felt similar to another famous show, Oliver.
However, Andrew was very confident about his music, and I started to feel excited too. I didn’t know much about musicals, but I remembered someone saying that if one hamburger place is popular, there is room for another. So, we could be the second hamburger place. I began to work hard, especially on the funny songs. Andrew explained the story, played me the music, and often gave me the song titles, which were probably thought up by his friend from school.
I even skipped a day at the law office, pretending to be sick, to write my first lyrics for the musical. I didn’t realize it at the time, but that day marked the start of my new career.

**Language**
You and I are part of a species that can communicate with each other very well. Language is so important in our lives that it is hard to imagine living without it. If you see two or more people together anywhere in the world, they will likely start talking to each other. When people are alone, they often talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I like to think of language as an 'instinct'. This means that people know how to talk, just like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders do not need to learn from someone else to spin webs; they just do it naturally.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather, which are created by the air around us, greatly affect the lives of animals and plants. Climate can change how landscapes look. For example, warm and wet weather all year allows tropical jungles to grow, which have many different types of plants and animals. On the other hand, cold and windy areas have fewer living things. The daily weather changes that create the climate happen because of large air movements. The air is always moving because the Earth is spinning. The air does not move as fast as the Earth, so it lags behind. The sun also causes a lot of air movement.
**Coffee**
As a bar-person, my job included serving drinks, but I was also responsible for making coffee. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on how good its coffee is. I spent several days learning how to make coffee, including how to clean and take care of the espresso machine. I also learned how to make a perfect cappuccino. By the end of the first week, I realized that making good coffee was harder than it seemed, and I thought I might have to go back to cleaning ashtrays. Fortunately, my boss was patient. He told me, "Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn how to do it well."

**Art on TV**
Why does television often have problems with programs about visual arts? Painting and sculpture are great subjects for the camera because it can show the whole artwork and then zoom in to see the details. However, there are not many TV series that show the joy and complexity of looking at art. 
A good example of this is Robert Hughes's series called *American Visions*, which has eight parts. Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality, and he has almost eight hours to introduce British viewers to American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on famous artworks, but instead, it looked at how American history and culture are shown in its art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as an international metals dealer and became known as a speculator. The metals market has fewer rules than other markets. With some luck, a willingness to take risks, and a good understanding of the market, it is possible to make a lot of money. Taking risks is part of this business. This adventurous culture fits well with a free-market global economy. 
However, free-trade economists who believed that the market would keep the prices of rare metals high have found that the opposite is true. More minerals are being mined, and the cost of raw materials is going down. When considering inflation, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to investigate claims against a large company that benefits from these cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its nearby cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas, which stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island has its own character and offers something special. To explore the islands and cays of Abaco, you need a boat. If a boat is not included with your room, don’t worry. There are many ferries and water taxis available. You can also rent a boat if you want to go at your own pace. 
Sailing is the most popular way to travel here. Abaco is known as 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reasons. The calm, protected waters are perfect for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The cays and their beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. You can find treasures not only in the sea but also at night when the lights of the restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

**Build Your Own Bamboo Bike at the UK’s First Workshop**
You can build your own bamboo bike at the Bamboo Bike Club in the UK. This workshop is run by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan. When you join a course, you get a custom bike frame designed by a computer and a fun weekend of bike-building.
It is Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can learn to build bamboo bikes. I went to see what was happening. There was a lot of energy and fun in the workshop. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes again. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire have been making bamboo bikes since 1894. However, many cyclists find these bikes too expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame can cost around $2,995 or £1,868.
James and Ian wanted to create a bamboo bike business that everyone could afford. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales, to develop their idea. They wanted to share the joy of making something special and sustainable. So, the Bamboo Bike Club became more about community than just a business. Both James and Ian have full-time jobs; James makes wind turbines, and Ian is a civil engineer. 
They offer monthly courses where you can build your own bike frame at a good price. On the first day, they teach you how to choose strong bamboo and how to make strong joints. You start by gluing the bamboo tubes together to form the bike frame. They also use metal tubes for parts that need extra strength, like the handlebars and wheel forks. 
James and Ian help everyone with their work, checking every cut and joint. If someone has trouble, they step in to help. Many people in the course are engineers, but Ian says everyone makes mistakes sometimes. If you mess up, just try again with a new piece of bamboo. Each piece of bamboo is checked for quality, so you can choose how your bike will look: plain bamboo, black, or mottled.
On Sunday, you spend time building the lugs, which are the parts that connect the frame. You wrap the joints with hemp and glue them to make them strong. After adding a waterproof coating, your bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and a seat. James and Ian say their bamboo bikes are just as strong as metal bikes. Ian has been riding his bike for over a year, and James has tested his bike off-road for three months without breaking it.
James says their bikes are made to be very strong, using thicker tubes and bindings. However, bamboo bikes may not look as polished as metal bikes. The hemp wrapping can look a bit like tape. But James and Ian believe that the unique look of bamboo bikes is part of their charm. 
I think bamboo bikes are great for relaxed rides rather than racing. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride. When I tried James's bike, it felt light and smooth, thanks to bamboo's ability to absorb bumps. James says the best part of the workshop is riding the bike after building it. They are light and fun to ride. 
And the best part? The price is less than £500.

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York when she first saw a book by a new pop psychologist, Dr. John Gray. She thought the title was great and believed it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray became very successful, and Dione started her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand each other better in relationships and is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry tries to meet people's desires to improve their lives, but it also creates new desires and supports the publishing world in New York. 
In Britain, people are discovering that many self-help books are not very good, but many more are rejected because they are too similar or too specific. This is a good thing. Editors are now looking for the next big hit, and they focus more on how marketable a book is rather than the writing style. Dione Reverend says that if someone has a catchy title, it makes it easier to attract readers.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, there is an unspoken agreement that they will tell the truth. However, this agreement is often not fully kept. Writers may leave out things they feel are too embarrassing or not important enough. Sometimes, they might even create stories that are not completely true but express their feelings better than the facts. They might call their book an autobiography just to make readers believe it is true, even if it is mostly fiction. This can happen without any bad intentions.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
People who study detective stories say that this genre grew because of the problems in society in the late 1800s and early 1900s. A detective story often shows a crime that represents human feelings like greed or desire. Solving the crime usually brings the person back into society, making everything work well again. 
In Hammett's stories, society is shown to be corrupt. The detective and the criminal are two sides of the same person. They understand each other and are somewhat comfortable together. The detective is seen as too honest by criminals and too shady by the law. He is both a criminal and a competitor. Sometimes, the detective feels guilty about his role, and this can make him more determined to catch the criminal.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is one of the best science writers today. I met him at the Grand Hotel while he was promoting his new book. Neither of us felt comfortable there. Gould said he couldn’t write well in such a fancy place. He believes that knowing the culture is very important for a writer. Science is its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. If you don’t understand the science community, you will struggle to write about it.
Gould has a rule: never write down to your readers. He says you can make the language easier to understand, but you should never make the ideas simpler. If readers feel like they are being treated like children, they will stop paying attention to your writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym, a popular place for City of London workers during lunch, it feels very cold inside. To handle the high summer temperatures, the gym has turned the air-conditioning up too much. Sometimes, it feels like being in the Arctic! This shows how people often misuse air-conditioning today. It is now a common part of our lives, showing how we try to control the climate. However, many buildings could use other ways to stay cool. They could use natural light and fresh air, and have thicker walls that keep heat out during the day and let it go at night. These ideas might seem simple, but they can really help and would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
It is interesting that as we start a new millennium, more people are interested in sundials. Sundials are tools that tell time by using the sun's position. A hundred years ago, they were very important for keeping time. People needed them to make sure their clocks were correct. But as clocks and watches got better, sundials became just decorations in gardens. Now, they are being taken seriously again. David Harber, who makes sundials, thinks people like them because they connect us to the planets. He says there is a special moment when a sundial starts to work. They are calm and beautiful objects that remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
My idea of china-painting came from a visit to an arts and crafts show long ago. There, I saw serious-looking older women painting delicate flowers on teacups with great skill. It was amazing to watch because each brushstroke created a perfect petal or leaf. Their hands were steady, and the paint never smudged. I thought these women must have practiced for many years or had a special talent. Because of this, I wondered what kind of people would join a china-painting class. Would beginners be good at it? When I attended a class, I found out it was not scary at all. Everyone was there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint like the women I had seen before.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a package holiday for Keith and Dawne at a good price. They had a flight from Gatwick Airport and twelve nights in Venice, a beautiful city, at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency to book the trip, the clerk told them that the other people in their package were a school group from the south coast, all learning Italian.
But something went wrong. At the travel agency, the check-in desk, or maybe in a computer, a mistake happened. Dawne and Keith ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland. At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. An hour later, they were surprised to hear older people on the plane speaking with accents from the North of England. Keith thought there might have been a cancellation or that the Italian class was on another plane.
They ordered drinks on the flight. When they landed, a heavy woman with glasses told them to stay together. The brochure did not mention an overnight stop, but when the coach arrived at its destination, Keith realized that was what was happening. It was close to midnight, and they were tired, so they did not question the beds they were given. 
The next morning, they found out they were supposed to stay in the hotel for their whole holiday, and they became worried. The receptionist smiled and said, "We have the lake and the water birds. You can take a boat to Interlaken." 
Keith calmly told the receptionist, "There has been a mistake. We were meant to be in Venice, at the Pensione Concordia." The receptionist replied, "I do not know that name. This is Switzerland." 
"A coach is supposed to take us on," Keith insisted. "An official said so on the plane." The receptionist said, "Your group is booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. If you want to change, it will be difficult." 
Dawne added, "The man who made the booking was bald, with glasses and a moustache." She gave the name of the travel agency in London. 
A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they had seen at Gatwick, approached them. She smiled and said, "I’m married to the man with the bad leg." Dawne asked, "Are you in charge? We are in the wrong hotel." 
Keith explained, "We got into the wrong group. We reported to the Your-Kind-of-Holiday girl." Dawne added, "We should have known when they weren’t from Dover." 
Mrs. Franks explained that there are many different holidays offered by Your-Kind-of-Holiday, and all tickets look similar. She laughed and said, "If you just followed others with the yellow-and-red label, you might think you could end up anywhere!" 
Keith insisted, "We are not supposed to be in Switzerland." Mrs. Franks then walked away, leaving them standing there. 
The receptionist was gone, and they could hear typing. Dawne whispered, "She seems kind." But Keith was not listening. He thought about everything that had happened: giving the tickets, waiting, and getting on the plane. 
An elderly man interrupted his thoughts, saying, "Nice to have some young people here." He and his wife, both in their eighties, said they had the best sleep in years because of the lakeside air. 
"That’s nice," Dawne replied. Keith walked out of the hotel, and Dawne followed him. They did not say anything about the irony of their situation. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they found themselves on a package tour with older people when they wanted to escape from the needs of the elderly. Uncle had said so himself when they tried to convince him to join them.

**HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON**
American business leaders are looking to the polar explorer Ernest Shackleton as a good example of management. Eluned Price reports.
Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. However, America has only recently discovered him. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton "an Antarctic explorer whose achievements went mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century," which is not entirely true. Now, Americans are showing great interest in him. Many books and stories about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being published, and the American Museum of Natural History is planning a big exhibition. Columbia Tristar is also making a film about his life.
Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with great respect and find lessons in his leadership and communication skills. They even refer to each other as "speaking Shackleton." Shackleton, known for his determination and resourcefulness, has become a model for modern management consultants.
Jim MacGregor, a managing partner at Abernathy MacGregor Frank in New York, has looked up to Shackleton for years. His firm focuses on communication during business mergers and crises. For example, they deal with situations like "the factory exploded" or "we have to lay off half the workers." While it may seem hard to connect Shackleton's survival skills in extreme cold to handling a business crisis, MacGregor believes Shackleton is a great model for management because of his leadership qualities. Shackleton knew what was important and was at his best when he and his team had a lot to lose, including their lives.
One of Shackleton's most interesting decisions was to turn back when he was only 97 miles from the South Pole. This decision showed his commitment to his men's safety. In a crisis, people want to know who is in charge. While many managers today avoid responsibility, Shackleton was willing to take charge. His 1914 expedition became legendary when his ship, the Endurance, got stuck in ice for nine months and was eventually crushed. When the ship sank, Shackleton told his men, "We should all reach safety if you do your best and trust me." 
From the diaries of the expedition, it is clear that Shackleton was always in control. He thought carefully, planned for every situation, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to change plans if something was not working. MacGregor says they have developed effective principles based on Shackleton's story that clients can relate to without feeling criticized.
Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical strength, and patience. MacGregor notes that one of the hardest things to do in tough situations is to wait, especially in America, where people often want quick solutions. For example, if you invest in bonds and make a wrong guess about interest rates, it is better to wait and get your money back than to sell and take a big loss. Also, if a new product is not selling well, don’t be afraid to change your plans.
Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he saw Hurley, the expedition photographer, without gloves. He insisted that Hurley wear his gloves, saying he would throw them overboard if he didn’t. Someone else remembered Shackleton doing something similar with a biscuit when they were starving on an earlier expedition, saying he would leave it in the snow because it was so valuable.
As Caroline Alexander, the author of "Endurance," says: "People are increasingly interested in heroic efforts. Shackleton shows that there is not much heroism today. He stands out as a true example of the ideals we long for."

**Tapping into a Food Supply**
In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. This primate has a way of finding food that is similar to how a woodpecker does. Both the aye-aye and the woodpecker look for insects by digging into wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye, however, uses its sharp front teeth to chew into the wood and its long third finger to reach inside and get the insects.
Scientists first learned about the aye-aye's unique way of eating over a hundred years ago, but they have only recently discovered how it finds the insects hidden in the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied three aye-ayes: two males named Nosferatu and Poe, and a female named Samantha with her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to see if they could find insects just by looking for signs, like holes in the wood where insects might have entered.
Dr. Erickson gave the aye-ayes logs with small holes. Some holes led to food, while others were empty. The aye-ayes went straight to the logs with food, showing that they did not need to see the holes to find it. They might have been using their sense of smell or hearing, but more tests showed that they did not rely on these senses either. Even when the smell of the insects was blocked, the aye-ayes still found the food.
So, how did the aye-ayes find the insects? Dr. Erickson found that they could sense the empty spaces in the wood. When looking for food, an aye-aye taps the wood with its long middle finger and listens carefully. Dr. Erickson thinks that the aye-aye is using a method called echo-location, where it listens for sounds that tell it there is a hollow space below. It can also hear insects moving when they are disturbed.
Some scientists believe that the aye-aye takes the place of woodpeckers in Madagascar, but there are also birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that look for insects in wood. So, the woodpecker role may not be empty. The aye-aye is not only like a woodpecker and an echo-locating bat, but it also acts like a squirrel. Its front teeth keep growing like a squirrel's, and it has been seen in the wild chewing through nuts and using its long finger to get the nut meat inside.

**Ordinary People, Ordinary Lives**
Many of us have pictures of our grandparents, but how many of us really know what their lives were like when they were young? Sometimes, diaries give us a little information, but family stories are often not complete. And what will our grandchildren know about us? We often plan to write things down, but we never seem to do it. We might leave videos instead of photos, but videos are still just images.
Hannah Renier has found a solution: she writes autobiographies for other people. She creates a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary lives. Hannah got this idea after talking to her family and realizing that much of the past was being forgotten.
"When I started, I didn’t take it as seriously as I do now," she says. "I met people who really wanted to share their interesting lives. They often say they are doing it for their children or future generations, but they enjoy it too."
People feel safe to share their stories with Hannah. A 62-year-old man said, "I was honest. I was surprised by what I shared. There were painful things, like my divorce." He wrote his story for his family, but he hasn’t let his children read it yet because he thinks some details might hurt them. He wants them to read it only after he is gone.
Hannah has noticed that many people are influenced by their parents. "It’s amazing how much childhood experiences affect people for their whole lives," she says. People often repeat the same patterns in their lives, like marrying someone their parents liked or choosing a partner to rebel against their parents.
Many people have regrets about their past. Even after many years, they still feel hurt by things that were never resolved with their parents. They often try to impress parents who were never impressed. Some people even want to say, "I can’t stand my mother."
Hannah listens more than she asks questions. "I’m not here to judge or be nosy," she explains. Sometimes, people share something and then worry if it should be included. She tells them they can remove things later, but most people want to be honest.
This is not just for people who want to show off their lives. Hannah believes that as life moves quickly, we are losing touch with our past. Writing these stories helps people connect with their roots and remember their ancestors. 
Each book takes about 30 hours of recorded interviews, which Hannah uses to write the life story. She organizes the material and writes it well. The final book looks good and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies available for £25 each. Hannah gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the high cost stops many people from buying.
"I thought more people would want this service," she says. "But the clients I have are often from wealthy backgrounds, the kind of people who would have had their portraits painted in the past."

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**  
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has one of the few collections of copies of Greek and Roman sculptures in the world, with over six hundred pieces. It is important to know that none of the sculptures are real. All the sculptures are exact copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a specially built gallery with great natural light. The benefits of plaster casts are many: sculptures that were originally displayed together but are now in different museums across Europe can be seen together as they were meant to be. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in just one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**  
Cambridge Darkroom is a photography center with community darkrooms and a gallery that shows different photography exhibitions. We often run courses and workshops for people of all ages and skill levels, including a popular Beginner's Course, a shorter Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. We have a membership program that allows all members to use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (ages 12 to 16) improve their skills through our Young Members program, led by our resident photographer. We sell photography books and magazines and have a full range of photography materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**  
The Sedgwick Museum has a wonderful collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all geological ages and parts of the world. It also has Britain's oldest complete geological collection, from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). This collection includes nearly 10,000 rare and interesting specimens stored in their original cabinets from the early 18th century. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and took care of the Woodwardian collection. Throughout his life, he greatly increased the collections, creating a truly amazing museum. The collection is organized by geological age, so you can see how life on Earth has changed over time. The new Whewell Gallery displays beautiful minerals and gems, with labels explaining their nature and modern uses.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**  
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the last 45 years. The University has its own aircraft based at Cambridge Airport and takes photographs all over Great Britain. The photographs are interesting because they show a detailed record of the landscape, showing both nature and human activity from prehistoric times to today. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the helpful library staff can answer your questions. The photographs cannot be borrowed, but you can usually buy copies. These are made to order and usually take about a month.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**  
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is the second oldest and longest-running center of its kind in the world. It is one of the most unusual tourist attractions in the area. You can have fun creating wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred different brass plates from the tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center has made resin copies, called facsimiles, to protect the originals while allowing everyone to enjoy brass rubbing. The brass plates were a way to remember the tomb statues and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Many beautiful brasses were destroyed during various revolutions, but most of the remaining ones are in Britain, and you can see the widest range at the Cambridge Centre.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**  
I have had a strange personal life, but I have been lucky to spend 35 years with small children, and I have loved every moment. This morning, I enjoyed feeding my baby, which is what being a father means to me. I feel very lucky with my children. We all enjoy the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This has created a strong bond between us, especially now that they are mostly grown up and I feel more like a friend than a father. I do not believe in using physical violence. I have sometimes slapped my children when I was angry, but I do not think it is right. I may not have been the most attentive father, but I have always tried to be there for them. I am available if they need me, but I believe they should reach out to me first. I do not want to make them feel guilty for not contacting me, as my parents did to me.
**B. The Advertising Executive**  
I was young when my children were born, around 25 years old, and I found the responsibilities difficult. It made me feel older quickly, but it also kept me young, which I appreciate. As they became teenagers, they introduced me to music, youth culture, and fashion, which helped me stay connected to my work. I missed some important moments when they were young, like their first concerts and sports days, and I feel sad about that. However, now I can take them on holidays to the south of France, and they enjoy spending time with my friends and attending parties and award ceremonies with us. I think it helps that my job is seen as interesting and glamorous.
**C. The Politician**  
My first child was born just as I was about to start my political career. My wife and I promised to make time for our children, but as I became more involved in politics, it became harder to find time. I only accept weekend meetings and public events if my children can come with me. This way, they can see what I do when I am not with them, and they do not feel like I am disappearing. I have noticed that more politicians are bringing their children to work, which shows that we are becoming more aware of the importance of including our kids in our lives.
**D. The Writer**  
My first marriage ended when my daughters, Kate and Bonnie, were young, so I had to think more about being a father. I worked hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even tried living next to each other for a while so they could visit easily, but I think it confused them. Kate has said in interviews that I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I was around a lot, but I treated my children like adults too soon. Kate recently said that I was too lenient. I wish I had set more rules and structure. I still worry about my older daughters just as much as I do about my youngest. In that way, being a parent never ends.
**E. The TV Presenter**  
I was ready for children. I was 30, had met my wife, and we had a nice home, so we thought, "Why not have a child instead of just buying new furniture?" Having my daughter, Betty, has helped me understand who I am. It feels special to have a child, but it also makes you just one of many parents. Sometimes I feel frustrated, but just one smile from her makes everything better. A baby's smile is the best way to feel happy again.

**THEATRE CHARLES SPENCER**
A. **Tamburlaine the Great**  
Marlowe's play about a powerful warrior can feel very long, but Terry Hands' production makes it exciting. He has cut parts of the text to make the show faster and more energetic. Antony Sher plays the main character and does amazing things, like jumping from the balcony and sliding down a rope while speaking. He captures the audience's attention with his intense desire for power. Great performance!  
*Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
B. **Women Laughing**  
This play by the late Michael Wall is now in London after being shown in Manchester. The first part creates a tense feeling as two married couples talk on a sunny lawn. In the second part, the story changes and becomes a strong and caring look at how illness affects people. Wall was a talented writer who sadly passed away at just 44 years old.  
*Royal Court Theatre, London SW1 (0207 730 1745)*
C. **Amphibians**  
Billy Roche is a new Irish playwright who adds to the English stage. His plays are set in Wexford, and this one looks at the problems in the fishing industry. It has rich characters, deep emotions, and funny moments. Sometimes the story feels a bit lost, but it builds up to an exciting ending.  
*Barbican 3 Pit Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
D. **Murder by Misadventure**  
This is a traditional thriller about "the perfect murder." Gerald Harper and William Gaunt play two crime writers who want to kill each other. Although the story is familiar, the surprises are clever.  
*Whitehall Theatre, London SW1 (0207 867 1119)*
E. **The Alchemist**  
Young director Sam Mendes brings out the best in Jonson's comedy about 17th-century tricksters. After a successful run at the Swan Theatre, the show is now on the Barbican's main stage, with Jonathan Hyde, David Bradley, and Joanne Pearce giving great performances as the three con-artists.  
*Barbican Theatre, London EC2 (0207 638 8891)*
F. **The Madras House**  
Peter James' production of Harley Granville Barker's comedy about fashion and women's roles in Edwardian society is now in London after being successful at the Edinburgh Festival. The staging is stylish, the acting is excellent, and the play is a classic that deserves more attention.  
*Lyric Theatre, Hammersmith, London W6 (0208 741 2311)*
G. **Dreams from a Summer House**  
This new musical by Alan Ayckbourn tells a version of Beauty and the Beast set in a London suburb. It has beautiful music by John Pattison and a sweet celebration of love, making it a charming show. Producers looking for a hit should check it out in Scarborough.  
*Stephen Joseph Theatre, Scarborough (01 723 370541)*
H. **The Merry Wives of Windsor**  
David Thacker's production of Shakespeare's comedy is not very exciting, but it has great performances from Ron Cook as Dr. Caius and Anton Lesser as the jealous husband, Ford. Most of the other actors seem a bit uncomfortable.  
*Shakespeare Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 295623)*
I. **The Voysey Inheritance**  
This is another important revival of Granville Barker's work, now touring. It tells the story of a respectable lawyer who leaves a corrupt financial legacy to his son, resulting in a wonderful play.  
*Apollo Theatre, Oxford (01865 244544)*

**Hide and Seek**  
*Yvonne Coppard*  
Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game where they watch a strange bookshop. Emma sees that one of the few customers is her Uncle Jim. He tricks her and tries to turn her against her friends. When Emma's life is in danger, the story becomes very serious. She is trapped in the cellar of an old house. This book shows family life, childhood friendships, and warns that adults are not always safe. It is an important and interesting read.
**Backtrack**  
*Peter Hunt*  
Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, discover that their family members were involved in a mysterious train accident in 1915, where eight people died. The story uses different viewpoints and documents like maps and personal accounts to help the reader understand what happened. It is a clever and complex novel that needs careful reading.
**Pigeon Summer**  
*Ann Turnbull*  
Mary Dyer feels out of place in her family and society. She loves her father's racing pigeons, and when he leaves for work, she takes care of them and wins prizes, even though her mother is upset. Set in 1930, this story teaches that "There are different kinds of cleverness." Thoughtful readers will enjoy it.
**Yaxley's Cat**  
*Robert Westall*  
In this chilling story, a mature woman named Rose moves to a cottage with her two children to escape her unhappy life. A fierce cat and strange items in the cottage help explain why the previous owner, Sepp Yaxley, disappeared. However, the locals do not welcome them, and their lives are in danger. By the end, the violence is controlled, but Rose is troubled by her son's behavior. It is a gripping story.
**Someone's Mother is Missing**  
*Harry Mazer*  
Sam is a chubby and talkative boy who admires his cool cousin, Lisa, from a wealthy family. When Lisa's life falls apart, Sam helps her find balance, and they both learn the importance of family. The story has a slow pace at times but includes gentle humor and shows the growing friendship between the two teenagers. It can appeal to both boys and girls.
**Stanley's Aquarium**  
*Barry Faville*  
Barry Faville writes with confidence and humor, bringing his New Zealand setting to life. Robbie takes a job gardening for an elderly man named Stanley. At first, she finds him interesting, but later she is disturbed by what he keeps in his aquarium and his plans for them. The story takes a thrilling turn while still exploring character and relationships. It is unusual and engaging.
**Dodger**  
*Libby Gleeson*  
This is a sad story about Mick, who struggles with his relationships and school life. The story is told through flashbacks, letters from a teacher, and Mick's own notes. He learns to deal with the negative views of others and his low self-esteem through a school play and a caring teacher. It is highly recommended, even though it is a painful read, especially at the end.

**Science Flying in the Face of Gravity**
Journalist Tom Mumford joins students who are testing their ideas in weightlessness. The aircraft looked like a normal plane from the outside. The pilot told the 13 students from Europe and America that it was built in 1964 and was a Boeing KC-135 refuelling tanker, based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was very different. The inside was a long white tunnel with few windows and bright lights along the padded walls. Most of the seats were removed, except for a few at the back where the nervous students sat.
For a year, these students had competed to take part in this flight, which was offered by the European Space Agency. They had to suggest creative experiments to do in weightless conditions. The best ideas won a spot on this special flight, which was like the most exciting roller-coaster ride ever.
For the next two hours, the Boeing would fly like a giant bird, going up high before falling back down. The pilot would turn off the engines at 3,000 meters, and the plane would go even higher because of its speed. Then, gravity would pull it back down. During the few seconds between going up and coming down, everything inside the plane would be weightless, and the students would feel like they were closer to the moon than to Earth.
The flight started smoothly, but that changed quickly when the pilot made the plane climb at a steep angle for about 20 seconds. The engines roared, and we felt the blood rush from our heads as we were pushed against the cabin floor. Then, the engines stopped, and we suddenly felt weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence, as if the floor had turned into a trampoline. One small step sent us flying towards the ceiling. We floated around, and directions like left or right didn’t make sense anymore.
After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane out of its dive. Gravity returned, but not as quickly as it had disappeared, and some students landed hard. After the first curve, some students felt sick thinking about the 29 more to come. Thirty curves meant ten minutes of "space time" for experiments. The Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats always land on their feet. They released a device to test this, and one student managed to turn it over using a remote control. 
Another student accidentally landed on it during a rough return to gravity. Meanwhile, a German team from the University of Aachen studied how metal joints are affected by weightlessness, which could help build future space stations. A team from Utah State University worked on creating solar sails from thin liquid films that harden in sunlight. They believe that if they perfect this process, satellites could use solar sails like yachts use wind.
After two hours of flying between heaven and Earth, breakfast felt strange, but the main feeling was excitement, not sickness. This feeling would stay with us for a long time. One student said, "It was an unforgettable experience. I wanted to be an astronaut before, but now I want it even more."

**With the Trees, I Planted My Stake in New Zealand**
**JONATHON PORRITT TALKS TO DANNY DANZIGER**
Jonathon Porritt is the author of *Seeing Green - The Politics of Ecology*.
I had a strange time in my life when I didn’t have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer, which is actually winter there. So, I experienced nine winters in a row, which I enjoyed because I like winter. My parents had the idea to buy a small piece of land for my brother, sister, and me to take care of. My mother said, “If you can plant trees on it, then you can have it.” The idea was that we would always have a connection to New Zealand, which is nice because my father grew up there. They found a piece of land about 20 miles north of Auckland in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was suitable for planting trees.
I have always been interested in land. I spent a year in Australia working on sheep farms and doing different farming jobs, so the idea of planting trees excited me. I think my family became enthusiastic as we went along. I started planting in 1968, and by the end of 1972, the three of us had planted the entire 70 acres.
In New Zealand in 1968, it was a very rainy winter. It rained almost every day while we were planting. I remember being very wet and cold for a long time. Every morning was a challenge: getting ready to plant again. I would come out of the Land Rover, still warm and dry, but then the rain would start, and I would have to deal with wet clothes and slippery shoelaces. My mind would start to think about many different things in life.
In that first year, I worked with an experienced tree-planter, which helped me a lot because I had never planted trees seriously before. I wore a planting bag around my neck to carry as many trees as I could. When the bag was full, it was heavy, but it got easier as I planted more trees. The hardest part was getting the lines straight. We had to decide how far apart to plant the trees and set up three poles to guide us. Once we were in line, we could plant all the way down and then come back.
I enjoy hard physical work, and it helped me get fit. After a while, planting trees became almost automatic. I learned a rhythm and used the least number of movements to dig the holes. This rhythm is important in many farming jobs. You train your body to do the same actions, and then it becomes easy: take a tree from the bag, dig a hole, put it in, stamp it down, and move on. 
Mentally, it was interesting. My mind started to think about many things, including nature and our place in it. These thoughts have influenced my life a lot. I have returned to New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow, which has been very satisfying. I feel a connection to what happens to them. I always worry when I read news about strong winds or droughts in New Zealand. However, everything turned out well, and those trees are now 20 years old and healthy.
I should also mention that I took a break from teaching and went back to New Zealand in 1984 for three months by myself. I wrote my first book, *Seeing Green*, there. There is a simple cabin on the tree farm with just a bed, a table, and a chair. In the mornings, I wrote; in the afternoons, I pruned the trees; and in the evenings, I did research. My connection to that area is still very strong. It is the place where I feel closest to the bond between people and the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" was my first thought when one of my helpers brought a cardboard box to me. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset, where we care for orphaned animals. But the noise from the box—a mix of a cackle and a bark—was strange to me. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their soft coats were like velvet, and their milky eyes looked up at me from their tiny black-and-white striped heads. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most badger cubs are born between mid-January and mid-March and live underground. If they are orphaned, they usually die from hunger. These three were found by builders who accidentally disturbed their home while working. Their mother was dead, but the cubs were still healthy, though cold and whimpering. 
After removing fleas from them, I took them into the farmhouse kitchen and placed them near the stove for warmth. There were two females, named Primrose and Bluebell, and a male named Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe, but I had to wipe them with a warm cloth first to make them feel like their mother was licking them. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Within a week, they learned to drink from a bottle and started to move around, even if it was a bit shaky. They were happy together and had a heated pad to keep them warm.
Three weeks later, I noticed that Willow seemed tired, but he was still eating normally. This was a warning sign. I should have acted quickly, but I didn’t realize how serious it was. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he died from a lung infection. When feeding animals with a bottle, it is important not to let them drink too fast, as it can cause problems. In Willow's case, this led to an infection that was hard to treat because he was so small. Feeling sad about my loss, I continued to care for the other two cubs. 
Then, a local farmer came to see me. He had found another male cub, abandoned by its mother. He knew the mother would not return, and the cub was cold and hungry. I named him Willow II. He was about two weeks younger than the females. I soon found out that he was very difficult to feed. I had to keep moving the bottle around and squeezing it to get him to drink. After ten minutes, he would finally latch on as if he hadn’t eaten all day. By the end of April, the females were eating creamed rice and anything else I offered. Willow II was happy to stop using the bottle but had trouble eating without making a mess. Eventually, I gave him a sausage, which he slowly learned to eat.
At nearly five months old, all the cubs were eating cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, hard-boiled eggs, and sunflower seeds for dinner. Normally, badgers eat mostly earthworms, along with beetles, baby rabbits, mice, and some plants. My badgers were better off than others that year because it was very hot, and finding earthworms was hard. By August, my badgers started to be active at night and would go for walks at dusk. We often walked through the cider orchard, where they would chase each other and play. I learned to avoid their playful nips, but Derek sometimes got caught and ended up with bruises.
During these late-night walks, I saw other badgers in our field. They were likely looking for food because their own areas were disturbed. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive, so we had to protect our cubs. The local press took pictures of me walking the badgers, and many people wanted to help us build a home for them on the farm. With advice from others, we designed a new home for the badgers. My son Daniel drew the plans, and we built a sett with tunnels and a badger gate. It had three chambers, one larger than the others, with a glass side so people could see inside.
As the sett was built, the badgers explored it before their walks. Soon, they were more interested in the tunnels than going out. The building cost more than we expected, but a local bus company helped fund it, and local businesses donated materials. Everyone wanted to see the badgers have a home. One evening, they finally moved in. After watching them for a while, we left them to settle. Half an hour later, I checked on them and saw three badgers curled up and sleeping.
Now, I don’t walk with them as often because they don’t wake up until midnight. We see Primrose only sometimes because she has joined another sett, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before running off into the night. This is their territory now, and they have made it their home.

**In Search of True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet**
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow in the footsteps of Sir Edmund Halley. Anjana Ahuja reports.
Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. However, one of his biggest achievements was mapping the "variations of the compass" during his sea voyages on the warship Paramore. These variations, now called "declination," show the angle between magnetic north and true north. Sailors needed this information to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley was one of only two people in England at that time who were paid to do scientific research. He set out for the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the North and South Atlantic, but had to turn back because of problems with his crew. He later made another voyage that took him to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From this journey, Halley published a map in 1701 showing the variations of the compass in the Western and Southern Oceans. This map helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in the Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate.
Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by retracing the route of the Paramore. He needs to raise £70,000 before he can start, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him.
Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while he was at Halley Station in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. "Halley had an amazing life," Dr. Clark says. "He was a respected scientist and led many expeditions. He was not just an astronomer; he also studied geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and worked on other projects."
During this time, Halley created a diving bell and helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica, which is important in physics. Dr. Clark believes that retracing Halley's voyage will give him the recognition he deserves. His expedition, called "In the Wake of the Paramore," will also have scientific value. They will take measurements like Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because the Earth's magnetic field is always changing.
Dr. Clark explains, "We usually measure the strength of the magnetic field, but not its direction. To measure direction, we need to know true north." On this expedition, they will use satellites to find true north. The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments for the trip. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements, and Dr. Clark hopes his data will help fill in any gaps in the satellite's coverage of the Atlantic Ocean.
Halley's journey was very important. It was the first scientific expedition at sea, and Halley was the first civilian to be appointed as a naval captain for this purpose. 
Does Dr. Clark have what it takes to make his journey successful? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed the 13,000 kilometers from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with different crews.
Does he share Halley's passion? "I am ready to give up eight months of my life for this, so some might say I'm obsessed. But I wouldn’t want to sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his incredible life have given me a real sense of purpose."

**POWER DRESSING**
Every summer, the peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tail feathers to the hens. This behavior has puzzled scientists for a long time, including Charles Darwin. He wondered how birds could develop such extravagant features in a world where survival is tough. 
Darwin believed that living things change over time through evolution, not by special creation. He thought that the strongest and best-adapted individuals survive and have babies. However, he found it hard to explain why peacocks have such large tails, which can be a disadvantage. So, he introduced the idea of "sexual selection," suggesting that females choose males based on their beauty.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different view. He believed that if peahens liked the most beautiful peacocks, it meant that these males had some hidden qualities that helped them survive. According to Wallace, the tail was not just for show; it was a sign of something important.
Now, 100 years later, scientists are still trying to understand this behavior. At Whipsnade, there are 200 peacocks that live like wild birds but are used to people, making them easier to study. Marion Petrie and her team have two main questions: Do peahens really prefer the males with the most impressive tails? And do these males have other advantages, or is it just about looks?
The researchers have observed the peacocks and found that hens do seem to prefer the males with the most eye spots on their tails. These eye spots are linked to the tail's length, and the peacocks with the most eye spots attract more mates. However, it is still unclear if these attractive males are better in other ways.
William Hamilton from Oxford University suggested that showy male birds might be healthier and have fewer parasites. This idea has been supported in other bird species, but Petrie and her team have not yet been able to check the health of the peacocks at Whipsnade.
This year, Petrie is studying the offspring of attractive and unattractive peacocks to see if the children of the attractive males grow faster and are healthier. If they are, it would support Wallace's idea that females choose mates for practical reasons.
There is also an interesting theory from the mathematician R A Fisher. He suggested that if a female chooses a male with a slightly better tail, her sons will inherit that tail, and her daughters will prefer long tails. This could lead to a situation where males with the longest tails have the most mates, creating a cycle that makes the tail even longer over generations. This idea could also support Darwin's view that females might eventually choose mates just for their beauty.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**
Tom Cunliffe believes that the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He showed this with his own boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of beautiful yachts with the latest technology. Most of these boats come from a big change in boat design that happened 25 years ago. In contrast, my boat is quietly resting in a tidal creek on the south coast. Although she was designed last year, she looks like she is 100 years old. You might think her owner is a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I’m not sure.
My boat uses the best parts of traditional boat design, but modern technology has made it easier to build. However, even though technology is important for designing and building boats, it often keeps sailors away from the real challenges of life at sea. These challenges are often what sailors want to experience when they go to sea. I don’t think sailors should go back to suffering through every difficulty. I believe it is important for my boats to have a coal stove for warmth and comfortable places to sleep. But why go sailing if everything is done for you? Dealing with sails that flap in the wind is part of being a sailor.
Why should we change the steering position from a safe place at the back of the boat to a less safe spot in the middle? This change makes the cabin feel like a big ship, with a bed bigger than the one at home. For me, a boat should be a boat, not a house on the water. When I bought my first boat, Hirta, to sail around Britain for a TV race, the previous owner said she had all the comforts but no luxuries. Over time, I learned how true this was. Hirta had heavy sails, no running water, little electricity, no fridge, no central heating, and no electronics for navigation, but she was the easiest boat I ever sailed.
However, classic boats like Hirta need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I realized I could not keep her anymore. I looked for a younger boat but found nothing good, so I decided to build a new boat from scratch. The Westerman has never let me down. Although the designer, Nigel Irens, and his assistant, Ed Burnett, use computer programs, Irens first sketched the boat on a paper napkin and then moved his ideas to the computer. After creating a model, we worked together to improve the design. The final version was perfect.
The completed boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won four out of her first six races. She looks timeless, moves beautifully in the sea, and has a peaceful atmosphere inside, made from reclaimed pitch pine. This might be because she was designed only as a sailing boat, without thinking about furniture. This is a traditional way of designing boats. In her calmness, she shows that you don’t need to follow trends to be happy, and sometimes it’s good to learn from the past. Made from wood treated with a special glue, she is completely waterproof. So, she has the advantages of a fiberglass boat but still looks, feels, and sails like a real boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**
Health farms and country house hotels with spa services are becoming very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.
**A. HENLOW GRANGE**  
I was happy to spend six days at Henlow Grange because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable, and I felt calm right away. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started taking classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors were very skilled. I was surprised at how flexible I felt as the week went on. They offer many treatments, including aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial treatment, which lasts an hour, made me feel like a new person. The staff in the treatment rooms were very friendly and professional. The atmosphere was full of energy and excitement. Henlow is planning to make big improvements this year, including a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or take a quiet walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt happier and had a better appetite. I left feeling great and full of energy, which lasted a long time. I will definitely visit again. This is a perfect getaway for busy women. Save Room 5 for me!  
*Marcella D'Argy Smith*
**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**  
The peaceful atmosphere of this stately home was clear as soon as I walked up the big staircase to the reception area. The Hall has a beautifully decorated library, a lovely conservatory, and plenty of space, so you can be alone if you want. When you arrive, everyone gets a medical check-up, which includes an examination and checking weight and blood pressure. They called us patients, which felt strange because I am healthy. However, I was impressed that they quickly helped with a shoulder problem I had. Each person gets a special diet to follow. I lost weight without starving, but I was still hungry and got a bad headache on the second day. My daily menu included grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and a mix of fruit, yogurt, and hot broth for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you can eat in the main dining hall, where the food is tasty. You get a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are reasonably priced.  
*Liz Gregory*
**C. CAREYS MANOR**  
Careys is not a health farm, but it is a lovely old manor with cozy log fires and a big lounge. If you are counting calories, you might want to skip the gourmet food. The French chef makes rich sauces and delicious desserts. Luckily, the hotel has a gym and a soft-water pool, so I could exercise after enjoying the food. There is also a spa bath, steam room, sauna, and treatment rooms. A big attraction is the sports injury clinic. I got advice on an old shoulder injury. The physiotherapist suggested good posture, exercises, and massage. Careys is comfortable and luxurious, but also relaxed. If you want to explore, there is beautiful countryside around.  
*Beverly D'Silva*
**D. CLIVEDEN**  
Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel that treats guests like royalty. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, tennis, horse riding, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens in the 376-acre estate. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with amazing dishes. It took me a long time to read the dinner menu because there were so many choices. The meal was fantastic, especially the sticky-toffee pudding with banana ice cream. I went to bed very happy! The next morning, I spent some time in the gym to burn off a few calories before my next meal. In the Pavilion, I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. I thought about all the other journalists who would write about fitness and beauty treatments. Cliveden has everything you need if you want to stay fit before enjoying a meal at Waldo's.  
*Kay Letch*
**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**  
The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is the best because it is the most delicious I have ever had. It is the worst because it has 360 calories, which is a lot if you want to lose weight. You have been warned! The second best thing is the amazing aromatherapy massage. I chose relaxing oils and fell asleep twice during the massage. I had the best sleep in years. The place is modern and well-organized, with great facilities and comfortable rooms. There are many therapists and beauty rooms, so it is easy to book appointments. They offer many treatments, from manicures to deep-cleansing facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to mothers and daughters. I would love to take a break here every month.  
*Eve Cameron*

**NATURAL TALENTS**
In the last seven million years, since humans separated from chimpanzees, we have not changed much. Genetically, we are still over 98% similar to chimps. This means that the differences between humans and animals are very recent. Our ability to create art and other things we think are unique to humans comes from just a small part of our genes. 
Recent studies of animal behavior show that many traits once thought to be only human are now seen as differences in degree. For example, both humans and wild chimpanzees use tools. Chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, while sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys also have a simple form of language, with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. This means that besides art, there are not many clear differences between humans and animals.
If human art comes from a special genetic ability, it is strange that our ancestors did not create art for almost seven million years after separating from chimps. The earliest forms of art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but these materials do not last over time. The first clear evidence of human art appears around 35,000 years ago with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments.
If we believe that our recent creativity makes us different, we need to think about how our art is different from animal art. Three main differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it is made for enjoyment, and it is learned rather than instinctive.
First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." This means that human art does not help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike many animal behaviors. While some human art communicates ideas, this is not the same as passing on genes. Birdsong, on the other hand, helps birds defend their territory or attract a mate, which does help them pass on their genes. So, by this idea, human art does seem different.
The second claim is that human art is motivated by enjoyment. We cannot ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they mostly sing during the breeding season, which suggests they are not singing just for fun. Again, this makes human art seem unique.
The third difference is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo are different from those in Paris. People can learn each other's songs. In contrast, some birds are born knowing how to sing their species' song, even if they have never heard it before.
Human art styles change quickly. For example, Roman writers described geese honking 2,000 years ago, and they still do today. But human art changes so fast that even a casual museum visitor can tell a twentieth-century painting from an older one, like the Mona Lisa.
Interestingly, two chimpanzees named Congo and Betsy created paintings that some people might mistake for human art. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and seemed to enjoy it. They even had an art show in London in 1957, and many of their paintings sold. 
These chimpanzee paintings challenge the idea that human art is very different from animal activities. Like human art, the chimpanzee paintings were not made for practical reasons; they were created for the enjoyment of the painter. Some might argue that human art is different because it is meant to communicate, while the chimps did not care about sharing their art. However, some famous human art was also made for personal satisfaction, not for communication.

**An Awfully Big Adventure**
The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on Earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and lived to tell his story. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and narrow eyes, looking into the unknown. Today, we don’t see such people in stories or in real life. Or so I thought until I met Charles Blackmore.
Blackmore's big adventure was leading a group across the Taklamakan Desert. Its name means "once entered, you never come out," but local people call it the Desert of Death. He remembered the dangers and excitement of that amazing journey while sitting calmly at home with his family. The team he led included four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. It turned out that the camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were long-distance truck drivers. This misunderstanding could have put everyone in danger and made the trip very difficult.
This mixed group set out to cross 1,200 kilometers of the world's toughest desert, and Charles Blackmore wrote a fascinating account of their journey. At that time, he was about to leave the Army after 14 happy years. He started the expedition for fun, to fill a gap in his life, and to discover who he really was outside the Army. "I had always thought I would spend my whole life in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but suddenly I wanted to see who I was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was very worried that I wouldn’t come back because nobody had ever done that route before; we went into it without knowing what to expect. In the end, it took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was very kind to us."
Anyone reading his amazing story will wonder why he used the word "kind." The team faced many hardships: sickness, extreme temperatures, severe thirst, and losing part of their water supply. "But," Blackmore explains, "when we were at our limits and the camels had gone without water for seven days, we found some. We didn’t experience the desert's famous sandstorms, and we never faced the freezing cold that could have stopped us. That doesn’t mean we didn’t have challenges. The fine sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and for the heavily loaded camels, which often fell over onto us."
