"What pushed me on more than anything was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. Our budget and time didn’t allow for one. No aircraft ever flew over us. Once we got into the sandhills, we were completely on our own. I knew I had the mental strength for the trip, but I was scared about my physical ability. I remember the first day — we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot that it was hard to breathe. I thought, 'We have to do it now!' At that moment, I was very scared."
If it was hard at the beginning, how did they feel at the end? "After walking for 1,000 kilometers, you are not going to give up. You have gone through so much; you have come so far. We were very thin but also very strong despite being tired. My body was fit, and my legs felt powerful. I could walk over anything."
In the middle of the book, Blackmore describes lying in the desert, looking up at a full moon and thinking of his family. How did he feel about what they must have gone through? "Inside me, there is someone trying to find peace. When I have doubts about myself now, I think back to the desert and remember that we managed to do that together. I feel prouder of that expedition than of anything else I have done. But when I think about my life, I think of my family and the happiness we share. Compared to that, the desert does not measure up."
Has Charles Blackmore found peace? "I long for the challenge and the open spaces. We felt a strong sense of purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of the sameness of modern life."

Life Without Gadgets**
Susan Harr decides to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us useful devices that make life easier. However, Susan feels that we have become too dependent on technology. She had a bad experience with a broken word processor, which cost her a lot of money to fix. This made her think that gadgets are often not worth the trouble.
Susan started to stop using some of her household gadgets as they broke down. She questions what "time" technology really gives us. Does it just allow us to do more things that need even more gadgets? She feels that marketing tricks us into thinking we need these devices.
When her broken gadget made strange noises, she decided to leave it outside. Now, she enjoys taking her time with her sewing. She feels free from noisy machines and can carry her sewing supplies anywhere. While she appreciates some gadgets, like her washing machine, she has found joy in living without others. 
For example, she returned her rented color television and went back to a small black-and-white one. This change helped her family spend more time walking their dog, reading, talking, and enjoying hobbies. Susan has taken up sewing by hand since her old sewing machine is now just a table for plants. 
She realizes that we often think we cannot live without our gadgets, but she enjoys the simple pleasure of sewing while listening to the radio or talking with family. She can even watch TV while doing simple sewing tasks, which makes her feel less guilty about watching. 
Sewing by hand is not boring for her; it is relaxing and satisfying. She finds that she can complete tasks quickly and at her own pace. This new way of living helps her avoid the rush of modern life. She also enjoys washing dishes while daydreaming.
Now, Susan looks around her home and wonders if she really needs all her gadgets, like the freezer or microwave. She thinks they might be wasting money and considers living without them.

The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst**
Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. When I arrive at his workshop in East London, he seems to be in a hurry. He greets me with a quick handshake and says, "Well, fire away then!" It is hard to tell if he is really busy or just acting tough. 
His workshop is under a railway arch and is filled with unfinished furniture and pieces of wood in many colors. Hurst has been making furniture for ten years and has a great reputation. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise himself. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, or bookcase, Hurst is the right person to ask.
Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes high-quality furniture is more difficult. Hurst says, "There are few real cabinet-makers now. Many people just call themselves furniture-makers." He is often disappointed by the quality of modern furniture. He does not like cheap, mass-produced items and believes that many people accept poor quality.
Hurst's desire for perfection is a big part of his success. He is confident in his skills and says, "I have a huge natural ability. I have always been good at making things." He learned his craft by asking questions and teaching himself. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some come back to him many times. He enjoys doing complete projects for their homes.
However, he admits that working with clients can be challenging. He finds it frustrating when clients do not know what they want. He prefers clients who are clear about their needs. Hurst is proud of his work but also respects other craftsmen. He says, "There are people far better than me. I can admire other people."
He criticizes those who take too long to make furniture or try to make it look like art. He believes furniture should be practical and useful, not just a fashion statement. Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he reminds me, "After all, I am only making furniture."

**Three Theories About Sleep**
People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This shows that sleep is very important. However, scientists do not fully agree on why we need to sleep. There are three main theories.
The first and most popular theory says that sleep is important for our bodies. It suggests that we sleep to keep our bodies healthy. While we sleep, our bodies repair any damage from the day and get ready to work well again.
The second theory focuses on learning. It says that sleep helps us process the information we learn during the day. Without sleep, we would not be able to learn properly.
The third theory is about energy. It claims that we need to sleep to recharge our energy, like recharging a battery. This helps us have enough energy for the next day.

**ECCENTRICS**
An eccentric is someone whose behavior is different from what is normal in society. This raises the question, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own strange habits or interests. For example, someone might love entering newspaper competitions, collect beer mats, or write letters to the press about many topics. Being eccentric shows our individuality.
Inside us, there is often a struggle between two forces. One is called individualism, which is the desire to be unique, and the other is conformity, which is the desire to fit in. Most people want to be accepted and liked, so they often choose to conform rather than stand out. 
People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often come together. They form clubs and hold meetings to share their interests, which others might see as strange. Being part of a group can be comforting. Many of us feel a conflict between wanting to fit in and wanting to be different. For example, a man at a bar might say, "I say what I think," to show he is unique. 
Anyone can choose to be more individualistic at any time. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel strongly about what you are doing, pursue it and don’t give up. You might confuse some people." However, this strong expression of individuality is not the same as being eccentric at first. 
If a pop singer wears strange clothes just to get attention, or a socialite makes shocking comments to be noticed, that is not eccentricity. But if they continue these behaviors until they become part of who they are, then they can be considered eccentric. 
The key to eccentricity is that it is natural. Eccentrics do not try to be different; they just are. They do not care much about what others think. They act according to who they are. This makes eccentrics different from enthusiasts, pranksters, criminals, show-offs, and recluses. These people are aware of society and often react to it. In contrast, eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.

**Natural Books**
We asked four well-known naturalists to share the wildlife book that has influenced them the most.
**A. Geoffrey Lean**  
It was easy to choose the author. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. One of the most important is Barbara Ward, a small and fragile woman. She has been at the center of environmental issues in Europe after the war. She combined her experiences from different environmental movements into her own strong ideas. When I was a young journalist, she helped me understand these issues better. Choosing her book was harder. It could have been "Only One Earth" or "Progress for a Small Planet." But I believe her most important book is "The Home of Man." It talks about the rapid growth of cities and the big ideas she cared about. It is a powerful call for what we now call "sustainable human development." I have read many books since, but none are as good as this one.
**B. Linda Bennett**  
When I read "Signals for Survival" by Niko Tinbergen, I can hear the calls of herring gulls and remember the smell of their droppings in the sun. This book wonderfully explains the interesting world of animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, if you watch a gull colony, you will see how their chaotic activity is actually a well-organized social structure. You can identify which birds are partners and recognize families later in the season. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviorist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. His work with talented wildlife artist Eric Ennion made this book special and interesting for anyone who loves wildlife. Ennion's paintings show how one gull can be aggressive while another is calm, showing the skill of a true naturalist.
**C. Lee Durrell**  
The book that has influenced me the most is "My Family and Other Animals" by Gerald Durrell. This book not only led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation, but it also deepened my love for the natural world. I was doing research on animal sounds in Madagascar when I first read it. After two years of challenges, this book made me feel hopeful again. It beautifully connects animals, people, joy, and nature, showing a world worth saving. Some people think humans are the worst because of the harm we have done to other species. But I remember Gerald as a boy in the book, seeing all living things as a family, showing that we are all connected. This is an important idea for everyone to understand.
**D. Bruce Pearson**  
I found "The Shell Bird Book" by James Fisher in my school library soon after it was published in 1966. I was immediately attracted to it, especially the 48 colorful bird paintings by Eric Ennion. These images caught my attention. I already had other bird books and had spent holidays learning to identify birds. They inspired me to start sketching what I saw. But "The Shell Bird Book" offered so much more. It had beautiful paintings, chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and even a chapter on birds in music, literature, and art. This book helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative responses to nature are just as important as scientific ones. Since art was my stronger subject, I began to see new opportunities for myself.

**DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS?**
We asked five important British publishers how book reviews affect a book's success. Here is what they said.
**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. They are the first thing we look at in newspapers. A study showed that many people said they bought a book because of reviews, more than any other reason like ads or recommendations from friends. Authors feel differently about reviews. Both authors and publishers are upset when there are no reviews, but publishers are usually okay with bad reviews. They think that any review can help sales because it makes readers want to see for themselves. Publishers like reviews that match their own feelings about a book since they are often the first to read it.
**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they have different needs. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed, especially in a good way. Book reviews today are better and more varied than they were 40 years ago. However, many paperback books still do not get enough attention. Publishers should not complain too much because they need reviews to help readers discover books and authors. A good review from a trusted source can really boost sales, especially if there are several good reviews.
**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for publishing. Without them, we would struggle to promote our books. Most of our books are not by famous authors, and we do not advertise much, so we rely on literary editors to review our books. Good reviews are much more valuable than ads because readers trust them. Publishers often say they care more about the size of the review than its content. Good reviews can help a book and an author become successful, but they need support from other sources like recommendations from readers and good marketing.
**Publisher D**  
I wish I understood the relationship between publishing and reviewing in Britain! In the United States, a single review can make or break a book. Here, bookshops often do not pay much attention to reviews. Sometimes it takes many years of good reviews for people to notice a talented writer. Interestingly, some poorly received books or books without reviews can still sell very well. It is all very unpredictable, but non-fiction reviews often focus more on the subject than the book itself.
**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers hope for great reviews. But do they really sell books? I once published a biography that received excellent reviews, but it did not sell well because people thought they could just read the reviews instead of buying the book. Does the name of the reviewer matter? Thirty years ago, if certain reviewers liked a book, people paid attention. Now, sometimes it is the unexpected reviewer or the creativity of the review that encourages people to buy the book.

**WEATHERVANE MAKER**
Making weathervanes is an old skill that started in ancient Egypt. Today, this craft is still alive in the workshop of Graham Smith. He is one of the few people in the country who makes hand-cut weathervanes. Graham creates unique designs based on what his customers want. He says, "This way, I can make a special item just for them." Many of his customers are women looking for gifts for their husbands. They want something special that shows the man's job or hobbies.
Graham's work is very different from the traditional cockerel design, which is the most common type of weathervane. The first weathervane he made was not a cockerel, but a witch on a broomstick. His friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. He realized that there were endless ideas for designs. So, he decided to focus on making weathervanes.
Before this, Graham trained as a precision engineer and worked in that field for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change their roles. Liz went to work as an architectural assistant, and Graham stayed home to take care of their children and grow his business. This was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. He says, "My old job was not creative, but this work is exciting and artistic. I really enjoy designing."
Graham has now created over 100 original designs. He pays close attention to detail and always gets the customer's approval on the design before he starts cutting it by hand. He also keeps many traditional designs in stock because they are still popular. Graham believes that people like handmade items because they are different.
He does not plan to expand his business because he wants to keep it as a rural craft. He says, "I have found my place in the market. People love unique items, and I feel satisfied when I see a simple shape turn into something beautiful." For many years, weathervanes have helped people understand the weather by showing changes in wind direction. Now, more people are moving to the countryside and want to add a special touch to their homes. This has helped crafts like his.
Graham is now busier than ever, sending weathervanes to customers all over the world, especially in America and Denmark. He explains that the price depends on how detailed the design is. His latest request was for a weathervane shaped like a curly-coated dog. No matter the occasion, Graham can create a special gift.

**Young Masters**
Bobby Fischer is trying to return to chess, but age is against him. Chess is now more of a young man's game. After being away from chess for 20 years, Fischer is back and playing against his old rival, Boris Spassky. Fischer won the first game, which was impressive, but he is not the same player he was in 1972. He is now 49 years old, out of practice, and not in great shape. Spassky is even older.
Chess has changed a lot in the last 20 years. Fischer helped make chess popular, and now there is a professional chess circuit. Today, the main goal for players is to win. In international chess, a player’s nerves and stamina are just as important as their intelligence. The pressure in chess has always been high. Players use a chess clock to make sure they finish their moves in time. If they don’t, they lose the game. Now, games can last longer, and many are played without breaks. This has made it harder for older players.
In the last 30 years, every new world champion has been younger than the last. Of the ten best players in the world, eight are under 30. The way chess is played has also changed. Many players prepare before matches, especially because computers can store many chess games and help players study their opponents. In recent matches, players have had teams of helpers working to find weaknesses in their opponent's game. The beginning of a chess game is now studied very carefully, and being well-prepared can decide the game.
Today, there are more top players than ever before. Many grandmasters compete for small prizes around the world. Success in chess requires both mental and physical effort. A single game can last up to eight hours, and players must stay focused. If they lose concentration, they can lose the game. The chess clock adds to the stress. At the end of a game, players often rush to make their moves in a "time scramble," where they have only seconds to act. This creates a tense situation where nerves and determination are crucial.
For top chess players, losing is very painful. Winning brings great satisfaction and a chance to recover from the stress. However, one win is not enough to win a tournament. Players must be ready to compete again the next day. Most chess tournaments last 9 to 11 days, with games every day. World championship matches can be even tougher. For example, a match in 1984 between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov had to stop after several months because both players were exhausted.
Can Bobby Fischer overcome these challenges? He once said, "All I want to do, ever, is play chess." This makes his long absence from the game surprising. If he has returned for money, he will do well, as both he and Spassky will earn millions from their match. But if Fischer believes he can prove he is still the best player, the outcome could be very disappointing for him.

**Fame and Fortune**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A** Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, *Peaches*, into a movie script. He says, "It's low budget, but we don't know how low. It won't be over £30 million, but it could be £30." Nick is very talented, but the surprising thing is that before he wrote *Peaches*, he had never been to a play or read one. He says, "When I wrote the play, I never thought it would be performed. It's set in a car. I probably wouldn't do that now because I know it would be hard to manage. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He realized he wanted to write for actors because he wanted his writing to be heard, not just read. He says, "Suddenly, I was with people who thought like me. It was the first time I enjoyed being in school. It was very inspiring."
**B** Comedian Simon Pegg, who is 28, has made great progress in his career since studying drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tough tour with comedian Steve Coogan. Simon has always worked hard. Even in Bristol, he was practicing his comedy in clubs. He remembers, "University was very theoretical. It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor; I was always more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it really isn't. If you have courage and good material, it's wonderful to make people laugh." He has performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but his best partnership has been with Steve Coogan. Simon admits, "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan of his, he probably noticed I was copying him."
**C** Ciaran McMenamin, who is 24, became well-known when he danced on TV in the show *The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star*. The response was very positive, and his career has taken off quickly. He says, "It's been a great opportunity for me. Now I can choose what I want to do, which is what I've always wanted." This is a lucky position for someone who just graduated. Ciaran's early career shows that he was always meant to be recognized. Encouraged by his mother, he went from leading roles in school plays to the Ulster Youth Theatre, where he acted for four years. He laughs, "I was using acting to avoid doing homework. But then I decided I wanted to take it seriously because I had a talent and passion for it." Now, he is waiting for more praise, but when asked about fame, he becomes thoughtful. He says, "When you're 18, you think you'll love the photos and interviews, but you soon realize that's not why you act. It's about getting respect for doing good work."
**D** Neil Taylor, who is 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which has just signed a deal for three albums with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate, Rick Brown, are expected to be very successful when their single, *Chimera*, is released soon. Neil says, "The record company has a different idea of success than I do. They want a big hit, but for me, if two people buy it, I'll be happy." Unlike many new pop stars, Neil has worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and has been trying to enter the music business ever since. He says, "It's funny how things happen. I had been performing at student gigs for eight years and was starting to feel tired. I was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had connections at Domino, and we formed Matrix. It couldn't have come at a better time. There were times I felt very down, and I was in some terrible bands. But hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E** Stephen Richards is a 27-year-old poet and author who has won many awards and honors. He is already well-known in the poetry world, where he has been performing and giving readings several times a week for the past six years. His first novel, *Hidden*, will be published in March. He says, "It's a story about obsessive love. It was a strong idea that I couldn't write as a poem." Stephen loved creative writing in school but lost interest in education later. He decided not to go to university, but after getting bored with a job at a theater, he changed his mind. After university, he published his first book, a children's book, in 1992. He says, "I don't think my parents expected me to be a writer; they thought I would just be a reader because that's all I did as a child." With his poetry getting great reviews, moving to novels is a big step for him. He explains, "My poetry has a structure, but a novel can be any length, so there are more chances to make mistakes. My main goal is to avoid just writing a lot without caring about the quality."

A. Isabel is a 31-year-old art student who thinks she looks good in jeans, but she rarely wears them because she doesn’t want to be seen with the wrong people. She is looking for Mr. Right but worries that her knobbly knees might stop her from finding him. Despite this, she remains hopeful, which helps her and others in the story. The author writes in a lively style, using chapter titles like "Our Hero Feels Inspired," making the story feel like an old silent film.
B. This story is about the rise and near-fall of a local radio station in America. It is told from the perspective of a smart but shy child named Francis With. Francis works for WLT (With Lettuce and Tomato) Radio, which was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays a mix of singers, preachers, and soap-opera stars. The small-town setting allows the author to use dry humor and simple writing, taking readers back to the 1940s and 1950s, a time of old stores and classic cars.
C. In this story, it is normal for a second husband to talk to his wife’s first husband. When professor Richard Vaisey falls in love with a beautiful Russian poetess, he shares his feelings with his wife’s ex-husband. The poetess writes bad poetry, which bothers Richard, and she is also trying to get help for her brother who is in prison. The author skillfully untangles these problems with humor and insight into relationships, making the story enjoyable and clever.
D. In 1960s London, two sets of best friends—two women and two men—become connected for 25 years through life and death. At the beginning of the novel, James Hudson, a wealthy American, is starting a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake as the editor. The newspaper launch is important, but so is the fact that a woman they both loved, and one of them married, was killed years ago. The story includes themes of murder, ambition, love, and jealousy, and the writing is engaging. This book allows readers to really get to know the characters.
E. This story, written by a talented American author, is funny and touching. It follows Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about a past mistake and decides to take care of his brother's three orphaned children. At 40, he is slowly becoming an unusual bachelor. The story explores many emotions and shows the special bond Ian forms with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm book that balances sadness and laughter perfectly.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four academic writers talk about international volunteer work.
A. It is difficult to say that volunteer work really helps development a lot. Volunteer tourists can help build homes or schools, but they usually pay a lot of money to do this work. If this money was given directly to a local community, it could pay for more help than one volunteer can provide. This is especially true for gap year volunteers, who often do not have much skill or experience. Many studies question whether these volunteers really want to help the community or if they are more interested in improving their own careers. However, these projects can help develop people who will act ethically and help those in need in the future.
B. Volunteering can lead to better understanding between countries, help solve conflicts, and encourage people to participate in global issues. It can also create international social networks among regular people. In this way, both the volunteers and the communities they help can benefit. But if only wealthy people can volunteer, it may help them in their careers without really helping the communities that need it most. Those who volunteer may continue to gain benefits while using the communities as a way to advance their own lives.
C. At its worst, international volunteering can be seen as a form of charity that is more about helping the volunteers than the communities. It can also provide important technical help for development. When done well, international volunteering can bring benefits to both the volunteers and the organizations they work with, while also allowing for the sharing of skills and experiences in developing communities. Most importantly, volunteering can raise awareness about the unfair power relations and deep-rooted causes of poverty and injustice.
D. Volunteer tourism fits well with the idea of helping others. These small efforts to "make a difference" can seem positive, especially when people are frustrated with big governments and businesses. However, this approach can ignore the need for democratic government and reduce development to individual acts of charity. While volunteering is a good act, when it is promoted as sustainable development, it can weaken the real conversation about development. The politics of volunteer tourism can distract from understanding global inequalities and the poverty many people face in developing countries.

**Sound the Alarm**
Stuart Harris reports
Many of us listen to the radio in the morning, and we often need something to help us get out of bed. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? A group of us, including inventor Tom Granger and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five different models.
One model has a 'dual alarm function.' This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for work days and one for weekends. However, it does not let you snooze and wake up later as I thought. Since this model costs about the same as another one we tested, it is a good deal because it has a cassette player. You can listen to your favorite tapes to fall asleep and wake up to a quiet morning. We all agreed that the radio quality was excellent, but the size was a problem. It is as big as a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said, "Any clock radio I buy must leave enough space on my bedside table for my keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. I always book a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn’t work."
This model was voted the best-looking and overall winner. Paul Bridges said he was "in love with it," even though the clock he tested kept getting stuck at 16:00. I liked the digital display with its nice grey numbers on a soft green background. The snooze button is wide, so you can easily tap it with your eyes closed. However, the buttons felt nice to touch, which made me want to play with them. This was a mistake when I finally looked at the instruction booklet. The clock has a backup battery, so you don’t have to reset it if the power goes out. We all liked this feature. However, we found it hard to set up, but once we did, we felt cool and smart.
Tom Granger thought this model, which has a built-in lamp, was "very cheap" in quality. He had to read the instructions twice to get it to work because the clock kept changing from 12:00 to 02:00. The lamp was hard to position, and you couldn’t read by it because it only shines on the clock, which is already lit. Paul Bridges found the lamp idea funny but agreed that the radio was difficult to tune. The buzzer sounded like an alarm on a submarine, which made me want to throw it across the room. Interestingly, this model is the third most popular on the market. It is aimed at young people with its bright colors, which appealed to Tom Granger and me. Tom said, "I would choose this one because it stands out more than the others." The traditional controls made it the only one we could set up without reading the instructions. Unfortunately, the alarm can be off by 20 minutes, meaning it might ring 10 minutes earlier or later than you set it. Paul Bridges laughed at this idea and said the model was "very annoying" and "completely useless."
The simplest and cheapest model we tested was liked by Tom Granger because it was "very standard and took up little space." It also has old-fashioned dial tuning, which is easier to use. He said, "With modern push-button tuning, you’re never sure if you pressed the buttons in the right order." He agreed that radio quality has improved because of button-tuning. I thought the tuning was not very good, and so did Paul Bridges, but we agreed that the radio quality was fine. The buzzer on this model worked well; it got me out of bed in just two beeps!

**Hedgehogs**
A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many parts of the world, but they are not found in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they feel threatened, so their spines point outwards. This helps protect them, but how well it works depends on how many spines they have. Some hedgehogs that live in deserts have fewer spines because they have adapted to their environment. These hedgehogs are more likely to run away from danger instead of rolling up.
Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day, often hiding under bushes or in holes in the ground. Although all hedgehogs can hibernate, not all of them do. In good conditions, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sportswomen on a Winning Streak**
Excelling in any sport is hard, even for men, but women often have to work even harder. Training and competing take up a lot of time, so they have to make sacrifices. Despite this, they are overcoming challenges and breaking records. Here, we talk to some amazing British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.
**A. Jill, 27, Skier**  
"It's a great feeling to fly through the air and land safely, but it can be scary. Sometimes I don’t feel well or it’s windy, and I can’t see well, but I keep going. It’s hard to have a life outside of skiing because we train for ten months each year. I give up a lot of my social life and friends, but it was my choice. There are six men and three women on the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it’s a young sport."
**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**  
"Two years ago, I borrowed a bike to join a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing since I had never cycled before! I earn good money as a professional cyclist, and there are many opportunities for sponsorship. However, I worry that people might think I succeeded because of my looks, not because I am a good cyclist. So, I focus on cycling instead of making money. I train for at least four hours every day on the bike, plus I do stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time it takes."
**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**  
"Rowing is hard for girls because very few schools offer it. Most girls start when they are 19 or 20, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Also, coaches often change, so the women’s team lacks stability. But I love it, and being fit is great, plus there is a good social life."
**D. Ffyona, 24, Long-Distance Walker**  
"When I was 13, I dreamed of walking around the world, not knowing how big it was! I felt trapped in Britain and wanted freedom. Each walk has been different. Walking across Australia was the hardest experience for me. I walked 50 miles a day with very little sleep and had many blisters on my feet. But I set a record! I had to because my sponsorship money would run out after 95 days. Some men think women are more likely to fail, so they see sponsoring us as a risk."
**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**  
"Some men have big egos when they drive. When I do well, they often ignore me. Being a woman has its challenges. When I reach a corner, some men think they must beat me, so I have had many tough moments! You need to be competitive and strong. It’s hard to earn money, and what I do make goes back into racing. Women have been racing since the 1920s and have often been seen as unusual. It’s great that more women are joining racing every year. I love saloon car racing because I always aim for a perfect lap."
**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**  
"I wake up at 5:30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evenings, I cycle or run. Sometimes I fall asleep at my desk! There is a lot of pressure before a race, and I push myself hard. I often ask myself why I do this. The answers are: a) I feel happier when I stay fit, b) I would be lazy if I didn’t push myself, and c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together, but when events are covered in the news, 90% of the articles focus on the men’s events, and only 10% mention the women’s. The prize money is not as good either. But now we have formed an International Triathlon Women’s Commission to help improve this."

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met Picasso when he was 78 years old. Even from a distance, he could see Picasso eating lunch at a restaurant in Cannes. At that time, I was an 18-year-old student traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van. I had run out of money and found a job painting boats by the water. I spent a lot of time drawing and was lucky to have my sketchbook with me when I saw Picasso.
Picasso was known to be a private person who usually stayed away from others to work. So, I was surprised to see him sitting at a table with his wife, Jacqueline, and some friends. I would not have had the courage to go over and ask for his signature if my friend hadn’t encouraged me. I nervously introduced myself and offered my sketchbook, and to my surprise, he agreed. He wrote his name at the top of the page and then added some lively lines below. These lines might have represented a cloud, the sea, or the shape of Cannes harbour.
I thanked him and started a conversation. Since Picasso's English was not very good and my French was not great either, an American woman at the table helped us communicate. She kept calling him "the Maestro," which made it hard for me to speak. But I told Picasso how much I loved art and admired his work.
After a while, I went back to my boat and showed my friend what I had. He noticed that Picasso was still having lunch and asked, "Is that all?" He encouraged me to go back and talk to Picasso again, saying I might not get another chance like this. So, with my sketchbook, I returned to Picasso's table. I decided not to ask if I could draw his portrait, as I was afraid he might say no. Instead, I just stood there, set up my pad, and started to draw.
When Picasso saw me, he smiled and made it hard for me to draw. He acted out funny faces and made silly gestures, like rolling his eyes and sticking out his tongue. It was like he was playing a game. I felt like giving up, but his playful spirit made me want to keep going. After a while, he finally relaxed and let me study him without moving. He looked strong and alert, wearing a blue-and-white striped shirt. He seemed much younger than his age, with bright, dark eyes that were very captivating.
Even though he was with friends, he seemed a bit distant and alone. He let his friends talk while he quietly focused on his own thoughts. When the American woman told me that Picasso wanted to see my drawing, I felt shy and said it wasn’t good enough. But Picasso insisted, and when I showed him my sketch, he nodded in approval. Then, to my surprise, he said it was his turn to draw.
I quickly gave him my crayon, and he made a few quick strokes on the paper. In just a few seconds, he drew a face that looked very different from my careful drawing. He had moved one of my eyes to my nose and captured my smile with just one lively line. I looked like a character from one of his playful artworks. 
I thanked Picasso and asked if he could sign my drawing. The American woman explained that he said I already had his signature. So, he was not going to give me another one! Still, I feel very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It meant a lot to me.

**Talking Shop**
Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? This article explains how stores encourage you to spend more money.
**A. The Fresh Look**  
Supermarkets know that people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to make the store look fresh. They might also have a bakery that fills the air with the smell of fresh bread. The colors in the store, like green, are chosen because they remind people of fresh food. However, most of what supermarkets sell, like frozen foods and cleaning products, is not fresh.
**B. Smart Product Placement**  
Where products are placed in a store is very important for sales. Supermarkets use computers to find out which areas are most popular with shoppers. They put high-profit items in these areas. Products at eye level are more likely to be bought. Stores also use "dump bins" for special offers to attract bargain hunters. They often place related items together, like desserts near ice cream.
**C. Spreading Essentials**  
Supermarkets often place low-cost items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, shoppers pass by more expensive items on their way. Stores also put popular products far from the entrance, hoping loyal customers will look for them and see other tempting items.
**D. Less is More**  
Chain stores have changed how they display their products. For example, the Next chain shows fewer items on the shelves, making them seem special. Even though their clothes are mass-produced, their store design makes them look exclusive.
**E. Total Costs Matter**  
Shoppers care more about the total cost of their shopping than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix low-cost staples with more expensive items. They sometimes sell staples at a loss to attract customers, a strategy called "loss leaders." They also get discounts from manufacturers by buying in large amounts or giving products good display space.
**F. The Price Tag**  
Shoppers in chain stores tend to buy fewer items and pay more attention to prices. For example, pricing a blouse at £14.99 instead of £15 can make a difference. This pricing strategy can also help reduce theft by making cashiers ring up sales for small change.
**G. Lighting Matters**  
Both supermarkets and chain stores think carefully about lighting. Chain stores try to use natural light so customers can see the true colors of clothes. Supermarkets use special lighting to make fresh foods look more appealing.
**H. Store Layout**  
Many chain stores use different carpet patterns to guide shoppers. One pattern shows the paths through the store, while another marks sales areas. Some stores, like Marks and Spencer, use nicer carpets in sales areas to encourage shoppers to explore.
**I. In-Store Promotions**  
When you enter a supermarket, you often see big pictures of delicious food, which can make you hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets are testing "video trolleys" that show ads for products while you shop. These trolleys aim to encourage impulse buying and can increase sales significantly.

**Sea, Ice & Rock**
Chris Bonnington, who is 58 years old, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and has written many books, such as *Quest for Adventure* and *Everest the Hard Way*. Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his career at sea in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-1969, he became the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht named Sunhaili. He also set a record for crossing the Atlantic Ocean, taking just 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard in England.
Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about their journey in their new book, *Sea, Ice and Rock*. In 1979, while Chris was working on *Quest for Adventure*, he called Robin to ask for an interview. Robin invited Chris to join him for a sail. Chris could teach Robin some climbing skills, and Robin could teach Chris how to sail. This was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed for a while and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin paddled to shore to practice climbing.
The climbing route was quite hard, but Chris was impressed by how steady Robin was in difficult conditions. They reached a big drop, and Chris asked Robin if he had ever climbed before. Robin had not, so Chris showed him how to do it. When they finished, Robin politely asked if he could climb down using the ropes from his boat. He was used to using his arms, but Chris wanted him to use his legs. Chris was not very happy about it, but Robin managed to lower himself down safely.
During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they combine their skills for a trip to Greenland, which was a big step from their Skye adventure. Chris admired Robin as a leader. Normally, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions first. Most of the time, people were too afraid to give advice, but it felt good to be part of the decision-making.
Chris found sailing difficult and boring. He preferred the excitement of a crisis, but he struggled with being on the sea for many days. He liked being on land and was not very handy. Robin, on the other hand, was a natural sailor and enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt useless because he knew Robin could manage without him. The crew was also very close together, with six people on a yacht meant for four. On a mountain trip, you can get away from each other more easily.
When they reached Greenland and it was Chris's turn to lead, he found it hard to be responsible for Robin's safety. There were times when if Robin fell, he could pull Chris down with him. Chris had to be careful. He also underestimated how hard climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, would be. Robin was not a natural climber, which made his efforts even more impressive. The first time they tried to reach the top, they climbed for 24 hours. On the way down, they were so tired that they almost fell asleep on steep slopes, 1,500 feet above the ground. Robin trusted Chris completely and just followed him. When it became too difficult, Chris knew they had to turn back, and Robin accepted this. 
Chris also knew that Robin was worried about their boat and whether it would be okay in the ice. Still, Robin wanted to try climbing the mountain again. The only time they had a problem was on the way home. They were taking turns to keep watch on the yacht. Chris was supposed to wake up at 4 am for his shift, but Robin decided not to wake him because he thought he could handle it alone. Chris had almost fallen asleep the night before, and he felt that Robin did not trust him. He told Robin how he felt, and Robin quickly reassured him that he was wrong to think that.
Although they enjoyed their trip to Skye, they did not really get to know each other until the end of the Greenland expedition. Chris discovered that Robin, despite his tough appearance, was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**
Apples have been around for a very long time, in many different colors, shapes, and sizes. However, in the late 20th century, we risk losing this important part of our history.
**Prehistoric Times (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples since ancient times. In Britain, they would spit out apple seeds. About 10,000 years ago, they found apple remains near lakes in Switzerland and Italy. In these areas, ancient people even stored apple halves to eat in winter. But these apples were wild crab apples, which are small and not like the apples we eat today.
**Norman Knowledge (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans, and this knowledge was brought to Britain. The Romans introduced some apple varieties, but many did not grow well in Britain. After the Normans came, they started to grow apples that were better suited to the British climate. Monks in Britain also experimented with apples, and many of today’s apples come from these early varieties.
**Medieval Favorites (1200)**  
In the 13th century, several apple types became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a main dessert apple until the 18th century. The Costard was a cooking apple sold in markets. However, bad weather, the Black Death, and wars led to fewer apples being grown, and more were imported. In the 16th century, King Henry VIII sent a fruit expert to France to learn more about growing apples. He returned with many new apple types, including the famous Pippins.
**Settler Treasure (1750)**  
By the 17th century, apples were so popular in Britain that the first settlers who went to Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand took apples with them. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers brought them to America. In North America, a man named John Chapman, known as 'Johnny Appleseed', planted many apple trees and became famous for it.
**Modern Delicious (1850)**  
In Iowa, a Quaker farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree growing from a dead tree. He named the apple 'Hawkey'. When he showed it at a fruit show, a judge called it 'Delicious'. This apple became very popular around the world.
**Granny Smith (1850)**  
Another famous apple, the Granny Smith, was found in Australia by Maria Anne Smith. She was known as 'Granny Smith' because she took care of her family’s farm. In 1868, she discovered a small tree growing from old fruit. She moved it, and soon she was harvesting green apples that became famous worldwide. She believed that something good could come from what others thought was useless.
**Uniformity Issues (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world, but most come from just a few types that are chosen for their looks or how well they travel, not for their taste. This lack of variety is a problem, as many old apple types have disappeared, especially in the US. However, people are starting to want more different kinds of apples. It is important for everyone to help protect the variety of apples and other foods we have.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups Leave Few Footprints**
Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We create trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our focus is on visiting new and unique places with interesting travel plans. Our brochure has over 100 original adventures, including tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last from 1 to 4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
We travel in small groups, usually with about 16 people. These informal groups are led by experienced guides. This gives you a chance to learn more about the places we visit and connect with local people. It is a rewarding experience for all travelers.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport during our trips. You might travel by coach, local bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, raft, camel, light plane, or even on foot. Each trip reflects the local environment.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who are ready for new experiences. Most come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are suitable for anyone in good health, reasonably fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, while the rest are solo travelers.
**Activities and Interests**
It is hard to describe Explore Worldwide because each trip is unique. We have divided our adventures into 8 categories, each highlighting special activities. These highlights are important parts of the tours, but many other factors also make our trips enjoyable, such as unique places, interesting encounters, and local customs.
**Cultural/Adventure**
Most of our trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours emphasize local cultures and historical sites. For example, you can explore Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Turkey, Greece, India, and more. Many trips include short walks of 2-4 hours to visit less-known sites.
**Wildlife and Nature**
Our wildlife safaris take you to some of the best game parks in the world, where you can see animals in their natural habitats. In Africa, you might even leave your vehicle to explore the wild. **Cultural Encounters**
A special part of our adventures is meeting ethnic or tribal groups. You might meet the Tuareg of the Sahara, the Maya of Mexico, or the Huli of Papua New Guinea. Many of these cultures are at risk, and we aim to promote understanding and respect while minimizing cultural and environmental impact.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Many trips include easy walks through beautiful countryside, often staying in rented homes or hotels. You can hike from village to village, sometimes staying overnight in local homes. These trips are available in places like Spain, Greece, Morocco, and Thailand. On longer hikes, your main luggage is transported separately, so you only carry a small bag.
**Major Treks**
We offer some challenging treks for experienced hikers. These may involve walking at high altitudes and staying with local people or camping in mountain ranges like the Himalayas and Andes. Support vehicles and porters are usually provided, so you don’t have to carry heavy gear.
**Wilderness Experience**
Exploring remote wilderness areas is an exciting adventure. You can discover the beauty of the Amazon Rainforest or the deserts of the Sahara and Gobi. These trips offer a chance to experience something truly special.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
These are relaxing holidays where we travel by local boats. You can sail through Upper Egypt, explore the islands of Greece and Thailand, or cruise the Galapagos Islands on a small yacht.
**Raft and River Journeys**
Our river trips can last from a few hours to several days. You can paddle your own inflatable boat or enjoy thrilling whitewater rafting with skilled guides. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught quickly. Our river journeys in India, Africa, and the Amazon provide a unique view of beautiful landscapes and wildlife.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain, known for running 10,000 meters. He visits a training camp in Kenya, which is located ten miles south of the equator. The camp is near Mount Kenya, the highest peak in the country. For the last three years, Richard has trained in this beautiful but quiet place during the winter. However, he had never trained with Kenyan runners before. 
On his fourth trip to Kenya, Richard decided to change this. He ran in his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp, where the best Kenyan runners prepare for competitions. He was invited by the national team coach after he finished fifth in the World Championship 10,000 meters race. This was a great opportunity for him. Training at high altitudes helps runners produce more red blood cells, which improves their ability to carry oxygen. This is one reason why many Kenyan runners are successful.
Richard's first race in Africa was also special because it was the first international cross-country race held in Africa, in Nairobi. He finished behind 41 runners, most of whom were Kenyan. He felt he did well, but he knows that Kenyan runners' success is not just because of the high altitude. They have a simple and relaxed approach to running, and they enjoy competing.
During his time at the training camp, Richard learned how the Kenyan runners train. The camp is located at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya, surrounded by beautiful fields and plants. The living conditions are basic, with six athletes sharing a room. Their daily routine includes three training sessions: a morning run, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the late afternoon. They start their day at six in the morning. The coach reminds them to take it easy during the morning run because they have a tough day ahead. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they only run 20 kilometers.
Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast, which includes tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar, with dishes like ugali (a maize dish), stew, and vegetables. After training, they often go to bathe in streams that come from the melting glaciers of Mount Kenya.
By the end of his stay, Richard understood more about why Kenyan runners are so successful. It is not just about genetics or the altitude. He believes that the simple lifestyle, hard training, and passion for running are important reasons for Kenya's success in long-distance running.

**The Challenges of Mass Marketing**
Almost everyone knows that advertising is struggling. This problem started in early 1989, before the recession really began. The decline in advertising is happening all over the world. The main issue is that advertising has not kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers often think about large groups of people and big media, but as more brands and media appear, the target audiences have become smaller and more specific. Even big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they usually do not.
Think about your own shopping habits. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30, 40, or even 50 items. Most of these items are not from advertised brands, and you might buy several of the same brand. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred different brands. For things like cars, you might only buy one every three years. You also do not buy many clothes, and most of them are not from advertised brands. Overall, you likely do not buy more than 400 different brands in a year. 
Now, compare that to the 32,500 brands and services that are advertised. If we ignore the 23,000 brands that spend less than £50,000 a year, we focus on 9,500 brands that are analyzed. The average person buys about 400 of those 9,500 brands, and not all because of advertising. This means that about 96% of advertising is wasted, but no one knows which part is wasted.
When you watch TV, count how many commercials are for brands you buy or might buy. Most people find that only about 1 in 16 commercials (6%) are relevant to them, meaning 94% of the commercials are likely wasted. Many people think they are different and not influenced by advertising, but that is not true. Most people do not buy most of the brands they see advertised. 
Advertising is often wasteful because not everyone who sees an ad will buy the product. However, advertising can still be effective. Many ads have shown that they work. Advertisers need to reach a lot of people to find the few who will respond, as they cannot know in advance who will be interested. 
Even the best-targeted ads do not get a 100% response rate. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every person they talk to. If advertisers knew exactly who would respond, they would not need to use mass media at all. 
Any advertiser who can gain one million new customers (about 2% of adults) is doing well. For popular products like soap powder, the top brands would be very happy with a million extra customers. Therefore, any advertising campaign that can reach 2% of the population is very successful, and that is a small part of the population. 
To improve advertising, the messages need to be more focused on specific groups than ever before.

**Solar Survivor: Charles Clover Visits a Green Home**
Charles Clover explores one of the most environmentally-friendly homes in Britain, located in Southwell, Nottinghamshire. This area has some interesting surprises. First, there is Southwell Minster, a little-known ancient cathedral. It is famous for its carvings of 'green' men made by medieval craftsmen in the thirteenth century. The second surprise is the 'autonomous house,' built by Robert and Brenda Vale. 
The Vales have created a home that uses rainwater for washing and drinking, recycles sewage into compost for the garden, and heats the house using waste heat from their electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with that of their three teenage children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay tile roof, and is located 300 yards from the Minster. It was designed to match the orange brick of the town's older buildings and was approved by planners, even though it is in a conservation area.
When you ring the solar-powered doorbell, you will notice it is very quiet inside. The house is well-insulated, with special windows that keep out noise. Once inside, you must take off your shoes, as Robert insists on this. The house feels calm and peaceful. On a sunny summer day, the windows are closed, and the conservatory warms the air before it circulates through the house. Robert opens clever ventilation shafts and windows to create airflow because the house is designed to keep out drafts. Even the cats have their own small air-locked door.
The Vales, who teach architecture at Nottingham University, have cared about the environment for many years. They wrote a book about green architecture in the 1970s called *The Autonomous House*. They wanted to create a building that did not produce carbon dioxide. They also decided to avoid using mains water. They designed special toilets that compost waste, installed rainwater tanks in the cellar, and used copper gutters to keep drinking water clean. They filter the water before using it. Water from washing goes into the garden, and they do not use a dishwasher because they believe it is wrong to use strong detergents.
Robert says, "We wanted to show that it is possible to design a house that is better for the environment without living in darkness." The only old-fashioned part of the house is the hall, which has a fireplace and a staircase that goes up to the top of the building. The Vales do not pay for water, and last winter, their house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. This is much less than what other four-bedroom houses use for heating.
Soon, they will install solar panels in the garden, which will help the house use even less electricity. The house will still use mains electricity for cooking and appliances but will produce extra electricity. One day, they hope to have enough to charge an electric car. The only heating in the house is a small wood-burning stove, which they only use on very cold days. 
When I visited in February, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The temperature on the first floor was 18°C, which is lower than what is usually expected, but he said it felt comfortable because there were no drafts and everything was at the same temperature. He mentioned that a woman from the early 1900s felt comfortable at 12.5°C because of her warm clothing. He suggested that people living in old houses should go back to how people lived back then, but this idea might be hard to accept.
The secret of the house is that it is simple and low-tech, so there are not many things that can go wrong. Most materials were bought from a local builder's merchant and installed by local workers, making the house affordable to build. It cost the same per square meter as low-cost rental housing. Not surprisingly, big building companies do not want this idea to become popular.

**The Camera Never Lies**
Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought of himself as a rational man and a scientist. In 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden and believed they were real proof that these tiny creatures existed. He published the photos with an article where he accepted fairies as wonderful supernatural beings. 
However, in 1939, the two women who took the photos confessed that they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and placed them among flowers. The photos looked beautiful, but the simple trick showed that photography can be misleading. 
Many people believe that photography is always true, but that is not the case. Today, we can use computer software to change our digital images. Photography has never been completely innocent; from the beginning, when cameras started capturing images, those images were being changed.

**Blacksmiths**
Throughout history, iron has captured the human imagination, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have often been seen as more than just skilled workers. Before the Industrial Revolution, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors and astrologers because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also considered artists. In the 18th century, blacksmiths created beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The elegant metalwork in French and Belgian Art Nouveau buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths.
However, by the late 1960s, the number of blacksmiths in Britain had greatly decreased because heavy industry no longer needed their skills, and modern architects rarely used beautiful wrought-iron designs. In the last 10 years, there has been a revival of interest in decorative architecture and more creative interior design. Still, much of the work looks similar, with manufacturers of gates and balconies often calling their products "classical" or "Victorian-style." You can find trendy design stores filled with rusty candlesticks that look the same.
Fortunately, there are new events to promote the blacksmith's craft. The first event, an exhibition of forged ironwork by members of the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA), opened last week at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says, "We could be starting a new Iron Age because both the public and blacksmiths are seeing things differently." Power tools have made it easier for blacksmiths to work with metal, allowing them to bend, twist, and weld it more easily. Dawson explains, "These artists now have a material that lets them express themselves."
About 250 pieces of work are displayed in the show, including bookends and a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and can go much higher. Most of the money will go to the individual artists, but a part of every sale will be used by the Association to promote good ironwork. Dawson has created an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says, "My style comes from letting steel bend and take shape when it's hot. It's like drawing with metal in space."
Many artists are fascinated by iron. Unlike other metals that are soft when cold, iron and steel are tougher and more challenging to work with. Susan May, a jeweler, says, "It's magical because it's very soft when hot, but when it cools, it becomes hard and unmovable." Ann Catrin Evans makes door knockers and handles that look like they belong in a scary castle. One design looks like a ball and chain, and another looks like a Celtic cross. She says, "I love that steel is cold and hard, and it feels like it will last forever."
No other metal gives people as much visual pleasure or a sense of security. It is likely that iron will continue to be used for decoration for many years to come, as long as we don’t have to see any more rusty candlesticks!

**The Day I Gave Up Smoking**
I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my coworkers was very angry. She shouted, "What do you mean? If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I found it hard to explain how I went from being a heavy smoker to not smoking at all in just a few hours. It was a bit annoying for me too. 
The stop-smoking session I attended was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy. It happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn’t plan to stop smoking, and I didn’t really want to. I felt pressure from people who are against smoking, and I still feel that way. I also had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn’t cough or feel sick, and I got over colds faster than my friends who tried to live healthier.
On that ordinary Thursday afternoon, I went to a session in Birmingham called The Easy Way to Stop Smoking. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit. I said, "I won’t try to stop myself; that wouldn’t be fair. I’m here to write, not to quit." I thought I was being reasonable because I really enjoyed smoking. It made me happy.
The counselor seemed to understand me. We were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn’t want to, and neither did the others. I think the messages about stopping smoking started to make sense to me. Just like smoking had become a challenge, the idea of quitting began to feel good. The thought of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a personal feeling that was just for me. 
Quitting was easier than I thought. The strong desire for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn’t a problem at all. I was worried I wouldn’t be able to meet deadlines without smoking, but I managed just fine. 
Surprisingly, the hardest part was doing things at home on weekend mornings. I realized that smoking helped me deal with boredom; having a cigarette was something to do. Yes, I do miss smoking, but not too much. Every new experience as a non-smoker is something I have to get used to, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a break at the theater. These are all moments when I would have smoked before.

**Dorothy Who?**
Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. For the past four years, I have been asking friends if they know about her. If they respond with excitement and say things like, "Surely there's already a biography?" they pass my test. 
Why should people in Britain know about Dorothy Hodgkin? She won a Nobel Prize, which should make her famous. If someone in literature won a Nobel Prize, everyone would know them. Hodgkin, who died in 1994, was an amazing person. Her life shows important changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and the global sharing of science.
When I started my research, I wanted to read biographies of scientists. A friend of Hodgkin suggested I read about Linus Pauling, who was a close friend of hers and also worked in science. I went to a bookshop but found that there were no biographies of Pauling available. I was surprised because he was a very important chemist and won Nobel Prizes for both chemistry and peace.
Even scientists sometimes think that biographies about scientists are not interesting. Peter Medawar, a Nobel Prize winner, said that the lives of scientists are often boring to read. If scientists think this way, it is not surprising that publishers and booksellers feel the same. 
People often see scientists as different from artists, writers, or politicians. This idea makes it hard for scientists to be recognized as interesting people. Some scientists do not want to be seen in the media because they do not want to seem like they are promoting themselves. This can make science seem less inviting to young people.
However, things are changing. Scientists are now appearing in public in different ways. For example, Professor Richard Dawkins gives out prizes on a TV quiz show, and geneticist Steve Jones appears in car commercials. These activities help people see scientists as real people, not just researchers.
The world of publishing is also changing. Scientific biographies used to be very serious and not very interesting. They often did not talk much about the scientist's personal life, like their family. But this has changed with books like Richard Feynman's "Surely You're Joking, Mr Feynman?", which is funny and touching. Now, even famous scientists like Isaac Newton and Marie Curie are shown with their flaws.
Dorothy Hodgkin was dedicated to her work. She discovered the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1964, and she also worked on insulin. She was a mother of three and had a husband who was often away for work. Her personal life is not directly related to her science, but it shows how she balanced everything in her life.
There is much to learn from her life, but her scientific work is also very important. Understanding her passion for science is a challenge for biographers because many readers may not know enough science to understand complex ideas. Learning science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language; it just takes practice.
It is sad that educated people often do not know about important scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin, even though they would feel embarrassed if they did not know famous writers or artists.

**Margaret and Her Water Finding Skills**
Margaret Wilkins is known for having a special ability, often called a "sixth sense." She can use a forked hazel stick to find water underground. Many farmers need her help because their wells have dried up. Margaret and her husband run a well-drilling business that uses machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. However, to find water, she only needs her hazel stick. They have a success rate of over 90%.
This ability to find water, minerals, and lost objects underground is called dowsing. There are many ideas about how it works, from physical reasons like magnetism to spiritual beliefs. One popular idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more than other things. Some dowsers believe they can feel these vibrations, while others say they can smell water, as smell is a strong sense.
Recently, during dry years, Margaret has been very busy. She often has a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. She says, "We usually see customers only once because wells last a long time." Other customers include people with holiday homes far from water pipes and developers building golf courses.
Margaret looks for water between 50 and 70 meters deep. She explains, "You can't drill where there is a risk of waste getting into the water. The water we find is in safe rock layers, and if we bring it up correctly, it should be clean. But in Cornwall, we have to be careful about minerals like iron."
Electricity is also needed to run the pump, and it is expensive to bring power over long distances. So, it is best if the well is close to existing power sources. After thinking about all this, Margaret starts her search for water.
For large areas like golf courses, she first uses a map and a pendulum. She holds the pendulum still and moves it over the map. It swings when she is above a water source. After finding possible areas on the map, she walks over the fields with her hazel stick. 
When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. She then uses the stick to find the exact spot to drill. Holding the two forks of the stick, she pulls them slightly apart to create tension. "When water is below, the straight part of the stick rises," she says. It is very important to drill exactly where the stick points. If they drill even a little in the wrong place, they might miss the water. 
Margaret's husband also checks the same area. Usually, they agree on where to drill, but if they disagree, they keep looking until they find a spot they both agree on.
Margaret is not alone in her work; many researchers and writers are interested in this unusual skill. She calls it an "intuitive perception of the environment," which is the best way to explain how she finds water so accurately. If she did not have this special ability, how could her family continue to run their well-drilling business year after year?

**We Changed Lives for a Day!**
Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? It might be fun to try something different! We helped four people do just that. Here’s what happened.
**Amanda's Story**
Amanda is 23 years old and a mother of two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy restaurant in London. 
Amanda had never been in a place like that before. It was dark, loud, and full of people. It was very different from her hometown, and she felt nervous. Being a mother is busy, but waitressing was even harder! She had only fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks. The other waitresses made it look easy, but when Amanda tried, the drinks fell and spilled everywhere. She felt embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed and told her it happens to everyone.
By 11:30 am, there was a long line of customers outside, and Amanda felt even more nervous. She worried about remembering the orders, but luckily, everything was done with computers. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to handle. Every time a customer spoke to her, she had to ask them to repeat themselves, which was embarrassing. By the end of her shift at 5 pm, she was very tired and just wanted to soak her feet in hot water. One waitress told her it had been a "quiet" day, and Amanda was shocked. She never knew waitressing could be so tiring. She thought it was an easy job, but it actually requires a lot of energy and a friendly attitude. Amanda realized she could not handle the busy Saturday nights. She was also disappointed with the tips she received. In the end, she was happy to return to her children, as being a mother felt much easier after her day as a waitress!
**Cindy's Story**
Cindy is 30 years old and was nervous about being a mother for a day, but she was also excited. She knew Amanda's daughters were a bit cheeky, but she thought she could manage. 
When Amanda left for the restaurant, Cindy had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, she thought she would have three hours of peace. But she was wrong! A note from Amanda reminded her that she still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the laundry.
At 1 pm, Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then took her home for lunch. But when she brought Sophie home from school, things got chaotic. The girls turned the sofa into a trampoline and screamed loudly while playing. Cindy thought they would tire out soon, but she was wrong again. She tried to get them to bed by 8 pm, but then they kept asking for water so they could come downstairs to watch TV. It was exhausting to negotiate with them all evening. 
Cindy realized that taking care of two small children was very tiring. She had no time for herself, and the responsibility was overwhelming. However, she enjoyed the day overall.
**Rosemary's Story**
Rosemary is 42 years old and runs a dairy farm. She swapped lives with Hilary, who is 30 and a primary school teacher. 
On the farm, Rosemary usually wakes up at 5:30 am, but on this day, she got to sleep in until 7 am, which felt great! She was nervous about how to dress for school. When she arrived, there were about 400 students at the assembly, and she hoped she wouldn’t stand out too much.
In class, the children worked in small groups, which was different from how Rosemary learned in school. She helped with a nature project about snails. By lunchtime, she was tired and looked forward to a break, but teachers only have about five minutes to eat. After lunch, she attended a staff meeting and helped with athletics trials.
