Later, she had a silent reading lesson and then a fun French lesson where the children practiced speaking with her. Finally, they had Physical Education, and by then, Rosemary was very tired, but the children had so much energy! The hardest part for her was speaking in front of the class, even for just two minutes. Although teachers have more holidays, Rosemary decided she prefers farming.
**Hilary's Story**
Hilary is 30 years old and arrived at Rosemary's farm at 8:30 am, only to find that Rosemary had been working for three hours already! Rosemary's farm is very big, with many cows and sheep. 
Hilary spent most of the morning in the ice-cream shop, filling milk containers and making ice cream. It was hard not to eat the treats! At lunchtime, she checked on the sheep and helped a ewe that had fallen over. If sheep are not helped quickly, they can die, so it is important to check them every day.
After feeding the calves, Hilary started milking, which took two and a half hours. Rosemary does this twice a day, every day of the year! Hilary found the day lonely and missed being around children because animals don’t talk back. The hardest part of the job was that there is no time off. The cows need to be milked twice a day, making it hard to plan vacations. Farming may seem romantic, but the reality is very different. The income can be unstable, and Hilary wouldn’t want to depend on the weather.

**A Trumpet Isn't Just for Christmas**
It is surprising how many musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger, the only son of parents who did not play music, grew up in a small town in southern Sweden. At the age of 30, he has become a unique trumpet player in the world. His recordings introduce new music, including concertos by old composers and new pieces.
When you meet him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of his trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in one of London’s top concert halls. A television show was made about his work, filmed in London and Sweden.
Hardenberger was born near Malmo. His music career started when he was eight years old. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong's music, decided to give him a real trumpet for Christmas instead of a toy. The gift was a success, and the boy played the trumpet all the time. His mother found a trumpet player from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra to give him lessons. Bo Nilsson, the teacher, saw Hardenberger's natural talent right away. Hardenberger feels lucky to have had such a passionate teacher.
Hardenberger explains that the trumpet is a simple instrument, and it is impossible to make a perfect one. Each trumpet has its own small problems, and no two mouthpieces are exactly the same. He believes it is important to understand these imperfections and work with them.
From the beginning, Hardenberger had a special sound that people could recognize. Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player who played in orchestras, Hardenberger always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired the French trumpeter Maurice Andre and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream of becoming a trumpet player.
At 15, he needed to decide where to study. His teacher wanted him to go to America, but his parents thought it was too far and dangerous. Instead, he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra was not as exciting as being a soloist.
Hardenberger knew he played better than many of his peers. When he entered a competition at 17, Thibaud suggested he join for experience. He learned the first round of pieces and made it to the second round. He was surprised to reach the final, where he faced a difficult concerto. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed performing and realized that people were listening to him.
Hardenberger is realistic about his talent. He does not want to analyze what makes his music special because he believes it might ruin it. He thinks the power of music is that it can always touch people's hearts.

**New In Paperback**
A. The story of Tristan Smith, a citizen in the made-up country of Efica, is a unique tale about human power, history, and humor. The author skillfully creates a world with its own history, traditions, and customs. The book is also known for its humor and the author's special view of life, combined with deep understanding of people. It is a challenging but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a confident middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. Normally, she would not meet Sheila, a traditional working-class woman who cares for her elderly father and has raised her grandson, Leo, since he was three. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe, in the street. After the court case, both boys refuse to talk about what happened. Leo, who was a good student and had never fought before, cannot explain his actions, while Joe physically recovers but becomes quiet and withdrawn. Harriet is deeply affected by what happened to her son, and taking care of him becomes her main focus. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet, which leads to an unusual friendship. The author is skilled at showing how people react to difficult changes in their lives. He also captures the feeling of a mother who believes she can never do enough for her child.
C. This book, which was nominated for the Booker Prize, tells the story of one of the most isolated Scottish Orkney islands and its people over a long and quiet history. The story is set against important moments in Scottish history, imagined through the daydreams of a young boy named Throfinn Ragnarson. He suddenly disappears in the story but returns after World War II, having learned to appreciate the simple lives of his ancestors.
D. After his recent big success, the author has written a sequel that continues the gentle humor and sharp observations of family life that made the first book popular. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is nearing her seventies and has a lively friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora's way of living is still a mix of vanity, charm, and reluctant kindness, and Rosie helps her in her enjoyable manipulation of friends and suitors. By the end of the book, Aurora must face the passing of time and the arrival of a new generation. The author skillfully reveals the sadness that lies beneath the ordinary moments of life, focusing more on the shadows than the bright parts of human experiences.
E. Six very different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful descriptive language to show the personal journeys of self-discovery that each sailor experiences as they prepare to return home, feeling inspired by their time at sea. The author uses striking images to express themes of memory and awareness, which can feel both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**
Rebecca Cripps meets five women who talk about their different jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and what a typical workday is like for them.
**A. THE BRAIN SURGEON**  
**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34  
**ANNE'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 6:30 am, go to the gym at 7 am, and get to work by 8 am. I start surgeries at 8:30 am. I do surgeries all day on Mondays and Wednesdays, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most brain surgeries take about three hours, but some can take all day. Sometimes, I work for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when to do surgery can be stressful. I don’t feel stressed while I’m operating, but I do worry about what I will do the next day. Brain surgery is usually a last option for patients, but when it goes well, it feels amazing. From 10 am to 1 pm, I meet with patients to explain their surgeries. I enjoy this and find it easy to talk to them. If they get upset, I try to comfort them, but I sometimes feel rushed. I leave work between 6 pm and 8 pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call, and I always carry my pager. When I’m on holiday, I worry about my patients for the first few days, and I often dream about operating."
**B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER**  
**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31  
**MARITA'S DAY**  
"I wake up at 7:45 am, leave home by 8:20 am, and take the train to work, arriving at 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, we have a meeting to discuss our work and any problems. I work in a team with three senior designers, a partner, and a junior designer. My job is mostly about production, with only a little design work. I get a brief from the client about what they want. I spend three to four weeks designing and developing the project. After that, I present my ideas to the client. If they like my ideas, we work on budgets and I hire photographers and illustrators. I also work with printers to make sure everything is done on time. I spend a lot of time managing people and need to communicate well. When I get home, it’s usually between 7:30 pm and 8:30 pm, and sometimes later. It’s hard for me to relax after a busy day."
**C. THE CHAUFFEUR**  
**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42  
**LINDA'S DAY**  
"I usually wake up around 7 am, but on some days, I wake up between 4:30 am and 5 am for long flights. At 10:30 or 11 am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Since chauffeuring is a sitting job, I have to be careful about my diet and exercise. I usually have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People often ask me for restaurant or shop recommendations, so I need to know the area well. Most of my jobs are booked in advance, which helps me plan my routes. Not all passengers are polite; some can be rude. But most are nice, and I have good relationships with my regular clients. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, so I have to be careful not to get too tired. I try to go to bed by 11 pm."
**D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER**  
**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27  
**TRACY'S DAY**  
"I wake up around 7 am, leave home at 7:30 am, and go to my first job. My assistant and I mostly take care of gardens we designed. We do some commercial work, but most is in private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each place. Around 11 am, we get hungry and go to a cafe for breakfast. In summer, I might work until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. I run the business from home, so when I get back, I check messages and return calls. If someone wants a new garden, I usually meet them in the evening. We like to use old materials to make gardens look historic. Sometimes clients have strange ideas, but it’s very satisfying to see a garden we created bloom. I find it hard to relax in the evenings because I can hear the business phone. I sleep well because my job is very physical, and I’m always tired at the end of the day."
**E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER**  
**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27  
**ZENA'S DAY**  
"I arrive at the work site by 8:30 am. I am an assistant engineer, and I help build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. I check that the workers are following the schedule and safety rules. I also help solve any problems. The workers start at 6 am, so my first job is to find out what happened since I left the night before. I usually have paperwork to review or questions to answer. I take a half-hour lunch break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm, but I often eat while I work. I need to keep a good relationship with the workers, even if we sometimes disagree. I usually leave the site around 6 pm, and I am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**  
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I manage programs for our credit card users. My job includes starting and managing the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I keep in touch with current card users, find new ones, and build relationships with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes organizing my day and then check my emails. I work with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan our advertising strategy. I have many meetings during the day, but I keep my door open for anyone who has questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I’m in London, I usually leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**  
I arrive at work by 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes about ten to twenty demo tapes, letters from producers, and invoices. The phone starts ringing around 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings throughout the day to discuss projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I know that these are very important to the artists, so I try to give helpful feedback. Once I sign a band, we start working on their first album, choosing songs and producers. I also manage budgets and spending. I usually leave work by 7:00 pm and often go to concerts in the evening, sometimes seeing up to five new bands. I often don’t get home until 1:00 am, when I listen to music to relax.
**C. Sales Director**  
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and my schedule for client meetings. I enjoy showing customers around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques that cost between £1,000 and £6,000. I spend time working with restorers and other specialists to fix the furniture we buy. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette while drinking coffee to stay updated on the business. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm, and it usually takes me about an hour to relax after work.
**D. Air Traffic Controller**  
I work on a set schedule. When I have an early shift, I leave home at 6:00 am. I start my shift at 7:00 am, taking over one of the control positions in the tower. I work for about an hour and a half at one station, then take a break and switch to another station. My team controls aircraft movements, handling about 1,000 flights a day in winter and even more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new air traffic rules during my breaks. This job is stressful, and I find it hard to relax after my shift. I hope to become a watch manager and then a general manager of the airport.
**E. Shop Manager**  
If I have an early shift, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start by getting the electronic sales system ready. I make sure someone is watching the cash register and organize lunch breaks for the staff. I spend the morning helping customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, but it can be frustrating when they expect me to quickly gather many books for them. From 2:00 pm to 4:00 pm, publishers’ representatives visit, and I discuss new book titles with them. I need to ensure that new titles arrive on time. My early shift ends at 5:45 pm. On two days a week, I work a late shift, closing the store and going home afterward.
**F. Financial Analyst**  
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then get up and take a taxi to work, arriving by 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to find out what is happening in my area. I assess financial risks for companies working abroad and warn clients about possible problems. I provide three services: an online news preview, a security forecast, and a travel information guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss the stories I will cover. I need to finish my first news preview by 10:00 am and my second by 11:00 am, so I work quickly. I travel to Africa about three times a year to report on events. I usually leave work around 6:00 pm, but it’s hard to relax, and I often stay awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: Take Control at Work**
A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**  
A good leader inspires others and helps bring about change. Leadership is not about being tall or smart. According to Pat Dixon, who wrote the book *Making the Difference: Women and Men in the Workplace*, leadership is about "making things happen through people who are as enthusiastic and interested as you are." Enthusiasm is very important. A good leader should be able to express their ideas clearly and confidently. Dixon says it’s about having the confidence to say "I believe" instead of "I think."
B. John van Maurik, who runs a Leadership in Management course, believes that most people have more potential to be leaders than they think. To become a leader, you need to recognize your hidden talents, develop them, and use them. In a way, we are all born leaders; we just need the right environment to grow. While it is easy to see leadership in famous people like Emmeline Pankhurst or Mahatma Gandhi, it can be harder to see it in our own jobs. However, leadership is now seen as very important for good management.
C. Think about the best and worst boss you have had. They might have been good at setting goals and meeting deadlines. But how did they achieve these goals? The best leader motivated you and supported you. The worst leader made you feel unimportant and kept information from you. When things went wrong, they blamed you. The first boss led well; the second one managed poorly.
D. Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new opportunities. Micheal Shea, who wrote *Leadership Rules*, says, "A good manager can keep a company running smoothly, but a good leader can change a struggling organization, whether it’s a company, a sports team, or a country."
E. Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can improve your leadership skills. Here are some lessons to learn:  
- Leadership works best when you choose to lead. Find out what you are passionate about. When you feel inspired to lead, use that energy to take action.  
- Start seeing yourself as a leader. Your ability to lead is an important part of who you are.  
- Working together is good, but sometimes strong leadership is needed. Try different styles. If you usually follow others, try taking the lead. Notice how this changes the results.  
- Set goals and try to achieve them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better and advance in your career.
F.  
- Leadership does not just happen. It develops when you take the lead, take risks, and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate tasks, motivate others, organize, and give feedback.  
- Don’t think that your way of leading will always please your colleagues. It might even push them away. Keep improving your communication skills. You don’t have to be liked, but your ideas and achievements should be respected.  
- Be visible and approachable to important people. Remember, you don’t have to lead all the time. Know when your contribution is essential and how you can help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Film Critic Nick James**
**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created a tense Cold War thriller called Abyss. The story is about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine that is stuck deep underwater. The characters, especially foreman Bud and his team, remind us of tough heroes from older movies. The special effects and set design are very impressive, but the dialogue and characters are not as strong. Overall, the story feels like a typical B-movie.
**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This version of the book by James Jones, about the battle for Guadalcanal, is directed by Andrew Marton. It is different from Terrence Malick's new film, which is more poetic. Marton’s film is a more traditional war movie and focuses on one soldier and his difficult relationship with his sergeant. While Malick's film is richer and more complex, Marton's version has some strong moments, especially a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife.
**C. On Guard**  
This fun swashbuckler is based on a novel from 1875. It is better than many other musketeer films. The villain, played by Fabrice Luchini, is a sneaky politician causing trouble. Vincent Perez plays a lively hero, and Daniel Auteuil, who is more serious, also has good moments as a swordsman. The film uses familiar costume drama ideas but does it with a lot of humor and charm.
**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film tells a serious story. The detailed costumes and sets make it look like a museum piece. Jan Decleir plays a harsh bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is cruel to his tenants. His difficult relationship with his son is the main focus, but the filmmakers spend too much time on the details and not enough on the dark story.
**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released film shows off director Leone's skills. The sound is especially good, making every noise clear. The story is very harsh, and whenever it slows down, Morricone's great music brings excitement back. The characters, played by Clint Eastwood, Lee van Cleef, and Eli Wallach, are all morally questionable as they travel through the post-Civil War West.
**F. The Longest Day**  
This three-hour war film features many international stars and has four directors and 23,000 extras. However, it feels too long and slow, especially in the early scenes where soldiers wait for news about an invasion. While it is impressive in terms of logistics, it is better suited for the big screen. Watching it on video does not give the same experience.

**BOOK A** Steve Martin's *Compelling Evidence* is very interesting. The main character is a lawyer who is trying to start a new career after leaving a powerful law firm. He ends up defending his boss's wife when she is accused of murdering her husband. The trial scenes are exciting, and the ending has a surprising twist. This is a great first book in a popular genre.
**BOOK B** *Curtains for the Cardinal* starts with a lot of action. It follows Sigismondo, a problem-solver for the rich people of the Italian Renaissance, as he gets involved in politics, church secrets, and serious crimes. Even though the story is complicated and a bit too long, it is still very enjoyable.
**BOOK C** *File Under: Deceased* introduces a new detective, Leah Hunter, who is a tax inspector. She gets involved in a mystery when a strange man dies in front of her. Despite facing challenges and the disapproval of a handsome local detective, Leah is brave and smart, making her a great character.
**BOOK D** *Double Deuce* by Robert B. Parker features Spenser, a clever private investigator. He helps his friend Hawk get rid of drug dealers in a poor area of Boston. The dialogue is quick and sharp, and while there are not many deaths, there is more thinking and philosophy than usual. Parker always provides high-quality entertainment.
**BOOK E** *False Prophet* by Faye Kellermann has her usual detectives, Pete Decker and Marge Dunn, looking into a robbery at the home of a famous film star's daughter. The author's easy writing style and focus on unusual human behavior make this an enjoyable mystery.
**BOOK F** *Blood Red, Snow White* is written by husband and wife team Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It features another lawyer and a female client, but most of the action happens outside the courtroom. The lawyer becomes a victim as the story unfolds. It has all the classic elements of romance, money, and violence, making it a gripping suspense novel.
**BOOK G** *Dead for a Ducat* by Simon Shaw features actor Philip Fletcher as a character who is supposed to be a victim. A funny group of characters comes together to film a story about Robin Hood, but Philip feels that this is not the right direction for his career. Simon Shaw usually entertains well, but this time the story is not as strong as his usual work.
**BOOK H** *Fall Down Easy* is Lawrence Gough's best book in a while. It follows Canadian police as they search for a clever bank robber who targets female bank tellers. The story builds tension slowly and shows the smart but troubled robber, making it much better than an average detective novel.

I might be too old for this adventure, but here I go! At 34, Tim Pozzi has left a good job to go backpacking. He thinks about why he and others his age are making this choice. This summer, I quit my job and decided to rent out my flat to travel in South East Asia for a year. You might think I'm lucky, but I'm 34 years old and feeling nervous. I have traveled before. After university, I spent two years backpacking in North and South America, and I promised myself I would do it again someday. But then I fell in love, started a career, bought a flat, and got used to earning a salary. I slowly realized I was giving up my own happiness for my job. When I handed in my resignation, it felt like I was taking control of my life again. 
I have no ties now. Many of my friends are married with children. They wouldn’t want to change places with me, but they envy my freedom. I’m not in a relationship, and I don’t have big career goals. I feel like I should make the most of my freedom, especially for my friends! But why am I so nervous? First, I need to make all the arrangements. How can I let someone else live in my home? How do I organize the renting? And I still need to decide where to go. I tend to procrastinate and I’m already behind schedule. I thought, “I might as well enjoy the summer in England,” and then, “Why not wait for the start of the football season?” 
It’s hard to let go of emotional ties. I’m putting it off because I wonder if I can still handle backpacking. Will I be able to adjust to a simpler way of life? Will I feel out of place among younger backpackers? Maybe not. More and more people in their late twenties and thirties in Britain want to break free from their lives and travel. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says that many people who used to say, “I wish I had that chance,” are now realizing they can have it anytime. They just need to be brave, organized, and confident enough to do it.
For Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, this trip is a chance to have fun before settling down. They bought a round-the-world ticket for a year. Danny says, “I’m willing to give up job security for this trip.” He knows he might return to the same job position, but he believes it’s a risk worth taking. When he left the office, he threw his calculator into the river as a sign of freedom!
For Matt, who just left the Army, traveling for a year was a time of change. He needed to break away from the strict way of doing things in the military to live better as a civilian. There are many reasons for people my age to travel, but some common reasons exist. Angela Baron from the Institute of Personnel Development says that today’s workforce is more flexible. Many people work on short-term contracts, so if their contract ends, they have nothing to lose. Some big companies even allow career breaks, knowing that trained employees will return instead of going to competitors.
Dan Hiscocks, managing director of Travellerseye, says more thirty-somethings are thinking about their lives. If people are unhappy with their jobs, they now know they can change things. Travel gives them a chance to think about their lives. Is wanting to travel just a sign that my generation can’t handle adulthood? Jennifer Cox doesn’t think so. She believes it shows we are better educated and more stable, focusing on living a balanced life. We are taking the time to ask ourselves, “Is this what I want?”
Ben, a 32-year-old picture researcher going to Central America for a year, doesn’t think he is running away. He says he is running towards something he wants. But he feels nervous about leaving his comfortable routine, like going to the office every day and chatting with everyone over coffee. I share Ben’s worries about leaving a stable life with few challenges. I’m not sure I would be going on this journey if I hadn’t found my boss so difficult to work with. 
Jennifer Cox points out that it’s common for a big event, like a breakup or losing a job, to push people to travel. It took a little push for me to get moving, but now I feel excited about the next 12 months. No matter what happens, I will be proud to have taken this chance. I believe many of us older backpackers feel the same way.

**Plugging in the Home**
Georgina McGuiness took a long break from journalism and felt lost with all the new technology. She shares how she changed her home into a good place to work.
The Christmas before last, I turned 37 and realized I needed to restart my journalism career. I felt like my skills were old-fashioned, stuck in the 1980s when typewriters were common. I worried that no one would want me in a newsroom because I didn’t know how to use a computer. Many job ads asked for experience in desktop publishing, which I didn’t have. I thought it would be easier to host a seminar on nuclear physics than to learn how to use a computer. I was not good with technology; even calculators confused me, and I didn’t know how to use the timer on the video.
I knew I had to change quickly. I thought leaving home before my kids would be hard, but then I entered a competition in a local newspaper. To my surprise, my family won a computer package! We received a laptop for my husband and a personal computer for the family. We jumped into this new world of the Internet and started chatting with people from around the globe. My kids stopped watching TV, and I set up a small office in the kitchen with a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. I had everything I needed to work from home while still taking my kids to school.
My children were already good with computers from school, but I was nervous. I thought I would lose my work if I pressed the wrong button. I was wrong! I learned the basic skills I needed, and it was easier than I thought. With practice, I got better every day. I started freelancing for a magazine, writing about two articles a month, and I felt proud to balance work and family life.
How has the computer helped me? I used to work at a messy desk and often lost important papers. Now, the computer helps me stay organized. I can keep track of money with spreadsheets and use ready-made invoices and letterheads, which saves me time. As a journalist, being online allows me to research stories, ask questions in forums, and talk about working from home with people worldwide.
However, working from home has its downsides. I can feel lonely without face-to-face contact. There are also distractions, like household chores, and my kids sometimes argue over who gets to use the computer. But many people in my neighborhood are buying computers, not just for learning and fun, but also for work. 
A report called "PC Usage in UK Homes" describes the typical computer user today: they are around 38 years old and well-educated. Most own a personal computer, and many have printers and modems. I feel like I am doing well with technology. Who knows, maybe one day I will be emailing articles to a newspaper in Melbourne or even publishing my own magazine from home. The possibilities seem endless!

**The Tartan Museum**
The Tartan Museum is located in Edinburgh, Scotland. Its modern buildings look very different from the historic city around it. Sally Varlow visited the museum just before it opened to see what it was like inside.
You cannot miss the new Museum of Scotland. It is on the corner of Chambers Street and has a big yellow tower and unique buildings that look like cheese wedges. Last winter, people had mixed feelings about the building. Some called it a "masterpiece" or "stunning," while others were not so sure.
Now that the inside is almost ready, people are wondering if the exhibitions will be just as interesting. The museum tells the story of Scotland through many different objects. There is a timeline to help visitors understand the history, but it does not limit the displays. The museum shows important items, like jewels from Mary Queen of Scots and silver from Holyrood chapel, without being too proud of them.
Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants visitors to enjoy their experience. He believes the museum should be for everyone, not just experts. He does not want to use fake scenes from the past because he thinks it is important to show the truth. This means that what you see in the museum is based on what experts know.
However, it is still unclear if the stories of the objects can be told well enough with just explanations and a few computers. Just before the opening, some things are clear. The views of Edinburgh Castle are amazing, and the museum has many different spaces. The galleries connect to each other, and the walls look like large stone blocks. Natural light comes in through special windows and roof lights, making it a nice place to look at the displays.
The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of kids aged 9 to 12 from all over Scotland. They wanted to have fun experiences with the displays. Although they could not have rides, they got a special area for hands-on activities. The Twentieth Century gallery on the top floor is the only temporary exhibition. It will change every three years and shows items chosen by Scottish people that have influenced life in Scotland, like electric guitars and televisions.
Overall, Dr. Clarke believes that real objects help us understand the past better than anything else. The modern design of the museum is impressive from the inside, but some people wonder if it is in the right place.

**The Future of Newspapers**
The change from print newspapers to online news is happening slowly. Change can be scary for some people, but it can also be a good thing. However, the move to online news is not easy and can be uncomfortable. Many people believe that print newspapers will eventually disappear because fewer people are buying them. Sales of print newspapers like The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have dropped by 8% to 10% each year, while visits to their websites are increasing.
But not everything is clear. A recent survey showed that worldwide newspaper sales actually went up by 1.1% last year, reaching 512 million copies a day. While sales in Western countries have fallen, countries in Asia have seen an increase. News magazines, which many think are struggling, also reported a 5.4% increase in sales.
The same is true for books. E-readers like Kindle are very popular, and their sales have increased a lot this year. However, when bookstores looked at the sales of physical books, they found that sales were only down by 0.4%. This shows that people are buying both e-books and physical books.
Many people believe that young people are not reading newspapers anymore, but this is not entirely true. The latest survey shows that nearly 5 million people aged 15 to 35 still read national newspapers. Different countries have different trends. In Britain, newspaper sales have dropped by 10.8%, but in Germany, the decline is only 7%, and in France, it is just 3.1%.
In the past, experts thought that online advertising would help newspapers succeed online. However, digital advertising on newspaper websites is now decreasing. Many US newspapers have started charging for online access. The best way to attract paying readers seems to be to offer both print and digital subscriptions together. This means that print newspapers are still important for selling online subscriptions. 
However, running both a website and a print edition is challenging and expensive for newspaper companies. Print newspapers still have a strong presence, but it is harder for them to be noticed online.

**Photographing People**
People are the most interesting subjects to photograph. A picture with a person is usually more engaging than one without. However, taking good photos of people can be challenging. Photographers need to pay attention to actions, gestures, and expressions. Sometimes, just having a camera can make people act differently.
**A. Grouping People**  
When taking group photos, avoid straight lines. Ask people to stand at different angles and distances. If possible, have some people sit or kneel in front so you can see all their faces.
**B. Posing for Pictures**  
People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by suggesting comfortable positions, like folding their hands or putting them in their pockets.
**C. The Right Approach**  
Don’t pretend you are not taking a picture when it’s obvious. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken, but they might feel self-conscious. You may need to guide them to look more natural.
**D. Eye Contact**  
A picture looks better if the subject is looking at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens, but they don’t have to smile. If they seem distracted, remind them just before you take the photo. You can also say something funny to get a genuine reaction.
**E. Candid Concentration**  
Instead of looking directly at the camera, the subject can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the photo feel more natural, as if you are observing them without them noticing.
**F. Expressions and Gestures**  
Expressions and gestures tell us a lot about a person. A laughing child can make viewers smile, while a sad face can create sympathy. Look for common expressions like smiles, frowns, or gestures like thumbs-up.
**G. Situation Interest**  
While close-up shots of a person can be powerful, the background can add more interest. Make sure the background does not distract from the subject. A wide-angle lens can help make the subject stand out.
**H. Interaction**  
Good photos often happen when people are interacting, like talking or laughing together. Look for moments of connection, such as eye contact or a friendly touch.
**I. People and Places**  
Many photos of people are taken during trips. To show both the people and the place, use a wide-angle lens and step back to include the background. Make sure the people are close enough to be seen clearly.
**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**  
Decide why you want to take the picture. If it’s to remember someone, a clear posed picture is good. However, family photos can be more fun if they capture real moments instead of stiff poses. Candid shots often bring back memories better than posed ones.

**Under Sarah's Spell**
Sarah Janson is a trompe-l'oeil artist. This means she creates paintings that trick the eye into seeing something that looks real. In this interview with Joanna Watt, we learn more about her.
Not many artists do not sign their work unless someone asks them to, but Sarah Janson is one of them. She does not care about being seen as a great artist. She believes, "It's not the artist who is important, but the work." Sarah is very humble and almost makes it seem like her paintings create themselves. This makes it hard for her during interviews. "I just don't like to shout about myself," she says. When asked if she minds being photographed, she covers her face in surprise.
After 30 minutes, Sarah is more relaxed, and the interview becomes fun and interesting. She has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. Before that, she spent two years drawing at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. However, she was not happy with illustration and started working with a well-known decorator named Jim Smart. He asked her to create one trompe-l'oeil painting, and that changed everything for her. "Suddenly my interest got channelled," she explains. She decided to start her own business, not knowing exactly what would happen but feeling it was the right choice.
Sarah's skills in observing details helped her become a good trompe-l'oeil artist. She often gets asked where people can learn this art, but she believes it cannot be taught. "Trompe-l'oeil is the school of life. It's all about observation," she says. She is always learning and believes that if you think you know everything, you should stop trying.
Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. For example, she says, "I can't paint bread; it always looks like grey concrete." She also struggles with math. When she had a big project to paint the ceiling of a chapel, she got confused with the measurements. She thought, "You're not Michelangelo. Who do you think you are?" This self-doubt makes her feel distant from her talent. Sometimes she talks about herself in the third person, saying, "When I finished that ceiling, I thought, 'Well, I didn't do it, she did.'"
Sarah's trompe-l'oeil art is very special and stands out from others. She has many important projects for businesses and private clients. Much of her work is inspired by buildings. For example, she created a trompe-l'oeil dining room based on a Venetian palace and a painting that makes it look like you can walk into two more rooms.
However, there is a risk with trompe-l'oeil art. Once people understand the trick, they might lose interest. Sarah knows this well. "Trompe-l'oeil has to do two things. First, it must draw you in; it's got to trick you. Secondly, it has to hold you and engage your imagination. That is the most important part."
Sarah believes that trompe-l'oeil art should also be personal for the client. "I love the interaction with clients; that is where the ideas are born," she says. Some clients have clear ideas, while others do not. She listens carefully to understand what they want. Many clients become friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.
Sarah appreciates her clients. "I am very grateful for the mad ones who have let me loose on their walls," she admits. They are happy with her work, which is why she is always busy, even if she does not like to talk about her talent. "I really don't like to shout about myself," she repeats. "Like my work, I am very restrained. I don't want it to shout. You become bored with things that shout." 
While this may be true, you could never get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves to be better known, and I am happy to share it with others.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**
Daniel Goleman looks at the important "people skills" needed to succeed in our jobs.
A. The rules for work are changing. We are now judged not only by how smart we are or by our training, but also by how well we manage ourselves and interact with others. This new way of judging is used to decide who gets hired and who does not. It helps to show who is likely to be a top performer and who may not do as well. These new rules are important for our future job opportunities. They are different from what we learned in school, where doing well on tests was seen as the most important thing. Now, it is assumed that we all have enough intelligence and skills to do our jobs. The focus is on social skills and personal qualities, like being proactive, understanding others, being flexible, and convincing people. These are known as emotional intelligence.
B. In a time when job security is low, personal qualities are becoming more important at work. For many years, people have talked about these qualities using different names, like "character" or "soft skills." Now, we have a clearer understanding of these abilities, called "emotional intelligence." This means being aware of and managing our own feelings and the feelings of others, and using these feelings to guide our actions. In the workplace, emotional intelligence includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. Some people think it just means "being nice," but sometimes it requires being honest, even if it is uncomfortable. It is not about expressing all feelings freely, but about managing them so that we can work well together towards our goals.
C. More businesses are realizing that encouraging emotional intelligence is important for good management. The more complex a job is, the more emotional intelligence matters. If someone lacks these skills, it can affect their ability to use their technical knowledge. Many people have succeeded despite having low emotional intelligence, but as work becomes more complex and requires teamwork, companies that work well together have an advantage. In today’s workplace, where teamwork and customer service are key, emotional intelligence is essential for success in every job around the world.
D. While a person’s IQ does not change much, emotional intelligence can grow as we go through life and learn from our experiences. Studies show that most people become better at managing their emotions, motivating themselves, and understanding others over time. This growth in emotional intelligence is often called maturity. We can learn these skills and use them to help us succeed, especially now when job stability is uncertain. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for struggling companies, nor does it guarantee success. However, if we ignore the human side of work, nothing else will work as well as it could.

'Should the media make money from content they do not own? Digital cameras and camera phones have made it easier to take pictures of important news events. However, social media has changed how people share these photos. Many journalists now look to social networks for images when news happens quickly. Unfortunately, some reporters have used photos from users without asking for permission. There are rules that say images on social media can be used without permission in special cases or when there is strong public interest, but people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event, which means user-generated content (UGC) is important for the future of the media. To keep a good relationship with the public, the media must make sure that people are paid fairly for their work and that they always ask for permission.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**
Acupuncture is a practice that is over two thousand years old. It comes from traditional Chinese medicine, which also includes herbal medicine, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is used to treat many health problems, but it is especially known for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists in the West use it regularly for pain relief.
**What is Acupuncture?**
Traditional Chinese medicine believes that health is when the energy of the mind, body, and spirit are balanced. This energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), flows through the body along pathways called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ, and many smaller ones that carry Qi to every cell. If the flow of Qi is blocked or weak, a person may feel unwell.
When you visit an acupuncturist, they will check where the Qi is unbalanced. They do this by feeling your pulse, looking at your tongue, and asking about your health, feelings, and habits. The acupuncturist uses very thin needles that are inserted into the skin. They may also use heat from burning herbs or apply pressure to certain points to help the flow of Qi.
**Acupuncture Points**
The points where needles are placed are connected to the meridians and may not be near the area that hurts. Many people say they feel a mild ache or tingling when the needle is moved. This can be done by hand or with a machine. Acupuncturists believe this feeling means the needle has reached the Qi.
There are over three hundred acupuncture points on the main meridians, with many more that are used less often.
**Scientific Understanding**
Even though Western doctors do not fully accept traditional Chinese medicine, many agree that acupuncture can help with pain relief. They have found scientific reasons for how it might work. For example, it is thought that acupuncture can block pain signals from reaching the brain or that it can release natural pain-relieving chemicals in the body.
**Types of Pain Treated**
Many people with long-term pain try acupuncture when other treatments do not work. Common pains treated with acupuncture include back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also claim to help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in terminally ill patients.
**Modern Use of Acupuncture**
Although acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years, using it instead of anesthesia during surgery started in the 1950s. This helped convince some doctors outside China that acupuncture is effective. In China today, acupuncture is used in many types of surgeries, including tonsillectomies and heart surgery. Needles can be used alone, with electrical stimulation, or with medication. Some people report that pain is greatly reduced, but this can vary.
**Effectiveness of Acupuncture**
Like many alternative therapies, it is hard to study acupuncture in clinical trials. However, studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helpful for chronic pain. Acupuncturists generally agree with this success rate. They know it does not work for everyone, and some people may need six to seven visits to feel significant relief, although some improvement can be felt after just two or three visits.
**A Different View of Pain**
Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They spend time diagnosing the problem and want to know what outside factors might be causing the pain, such as weather conditions. They also ask about the type of pain, like whether it is sharp or dull. This information helps them decide how to treat the pain, which is not something most doctors would consider.
**Choosing an Acupuncturist**
Some medical professionals have training in traditional acupuncture, while others, including many general practitioners, prefer scientific explanations. Traditional acupuncturists believe that using their methods can lead to better and longer-lasting results. It is important to choose a qualified acupuncturist, who should refer you to a doctor if needed.

P. D. James is a famous crime writer known for her clever and complex stories. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She has a calm and confident presence, which makes it easy to imagine her as a headmistress of a girls' school. However, she is actually quite shy. She admits that her main character, Adam Dalgliesh, the detective in her books, is similar to her, or how she might have been if she were a man. Dalgliesh likes to solve crimes alone, just like P.D. James prefers to write in private. 
Although she is considered one of the best crime writers in Britain, she is modest about her success. Her 12 detective novels are very popular and read by millions around the world. She enjoys the books of her friend Ruth Rendell, especially those written under the name Barbara Vine. P.D. James also likes to read works by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but she also appreciates male authors like Graham Greene and Evelyn Waugh.
P.D. James found success later in life. She was 42 when her first crime novel, Cover Her Face, was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband there, who was a student. Life has not always been easy for her. Her husband, Connor Bantry White, returned from World War II very sick. P.D. James had to work long hours to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. During this time, her ideas for writing were strong, but she had little time to write. Her husband’s parents helped take care of the children, which gave them some stability.
While working full-time for the National Health Service, she used her strong organizational skills. She managed several psychiatric clinics and later worked for 11 years at the Home Office, dealing with police and juvenile crime. While working in forensic science, she became used to seeing dead bodies, but she was not interested in death itself. Instead, she loved the challenge of writing crime stories. 
P.D. James did not want to write about her own difficult experiences. She saw writing detective stories as a good way to learn how to be a serious novelist. She realized that she could follow the traditional rules of detective stories and still write meaningful novels about people. For her, writing detective stories is a way to bring order to chaos. Solving a crime shows that life is important, even if it is not perfect. She believes that nobody truly enjoys violence.

**The Pen is Mightier than the Psychoanalyst**
The study of handwriting to understand a person's character is becoming more popular. In some countries, if you apply for a job, you will likely be asked to provide a sample of your handwriting. This handwriting can help decide if you are suitable for the job. Handwriting analysis, also known as graphology, is considered a real science in many places. Researchers believe it can help show certain health problems, like heart disease and cancer, and can reveal emotional issues.
More companies are using handwriting analysis to help with job interviews. Many large companies now hire graphologists to look at the handwriting of job candidates. However, many doctors and mental health professionals are not sure about the value of graphology. Patricia Marne, a professional graphologist for over 20 years, thinks they should take it more seriously. She believes handwriting can show psychological traits and some medical conditions. She says, "Handwriting can indicate social class and intelligence. It can also help decide if someone should focus on arts or sciences and if they have a trustworthy or tricky character."
According to Ms. Marne, graphology can help identify possible criminal behavior. She says, "Criminals often have messy handwriting, which can show emotional problems. Many come from difficult backgrounds and have not developed emotionally. This can appear as childish handwriting or writing that goes over letters many times." 
Ms. Marne claims she can tell if people are honest or manipulative just by looking at their handwriting. She also says that young male offenders often have tall letters, which means they might be dreaming of a better life. Graphologists can sometimes predict if someone is feeling very stressed or if they might harm themselves.
She explains that heart and lung problems can also be seen in handwriting. "You cannot make a diagnosis from just one sample unless the writing is clearly shaky. But if the handwriting changes over time or if the signature looks different, it could mean something serious has happened." A big emotional upset can also change a person's signature for a short time.
Ms. Marne says handwriting can show other psychological traits. For example, people whose letters look like "threads" might be clever but tricky. Those who write mostly in capital letters may be hiding their true feelings. Light pressure in writing can show sensitivity. If someone’s handwriting is very different from standard writing, it can mean they are confident and creative. Disconnected writing often means the person is a loner. Small signatures can show shyness, while circles over the letter "i" can mean someone wants attention. Heavy crossing of the letter "t" can show intolerance.
Ms. Marne believes it takes six years of study and experience to analyze handwriting well, along with empathy and intuition. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a proper science. She believes this will happen soon. "It is actually more accurate than psychoanalysis because you can learn a lot about a person’s history and emotional struggles without asking them questions that they might not answer truthfully."
Even though this information is interesting, there is not much strong evidence to support these claims. Some psychiatrists are very critical of graphology. They argue that handwriting is influenced by education, artistic skills, and the way writing is taught, and it does not have any other meaning.

**Is Your Office Working Well?**
Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy and healthy workplace, according to a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they were. We had a team of experts to help us: a building health consultant, an ergonomist who studies working conditions, and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.
**Office A: Advertising Agency**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is very simple. It has no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open directly to the street. It is surprising that this office works well, but the small team of seven people seems happy. They adapt to the weather by opening doors or using electric heaters, just like at home. This may be the reason for their happiness: they have created a comfortable working environment without too many rules.
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is mismatched and not very good for working. Many chairs are old and broken, and they do not adjust well. However, the staff have a varied work schedule, which helps them avoid tiredness and boredom.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff enjoy the variety of work and the size of the office. It is small enough to know what everyone is doing but big enough to work alone when needed. The office feels attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.
**Office B: News Service**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office is not very exciting, but it is comfortable and the staff do not dislike it. The air quality is good, partly because of a No Smoking policy.
- **Ergonomist:** The company has hired an ergonomist, so the chairs and lighting are good. The space is okay, but the layout could be better. However, the office feels impersonal with plain grey walls.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The walls are mostly bare, except for some planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have worked there for at least five years, and they have good relationships. The office could be better if the desks were arranged to help share information more easily.
**Office C: Bank**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office gets mixed reactions from the staff. It feels like being in a glass box, and even with smokers nearby, the air is not stale.
- **Ergonomist:** The office is very standard and not inspiring. The desks are just okay, and some chairs do not meet the needs of the users. The computer setups are outdated.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The staff support each other and use technology well. There are many awards on display, but the office has a serious look with wood paneling and brown carpets. It is busy with activity.
**Office D: Newspaper**
- **Building Health Consultant:** This office has many problems. The air conditioning does not work well, causing big temperature changes. The space is messy, and there is not enough desk space. It is also very dusty.
- **Ergonomist:** The furniture is not suitable for a modern office. Many chairs are old and do not adjust well, making it hard for shorter people to work comfortably.
- **Occupational Psychologist:** The office has old brown chairs and dirty carpets. It needs a good cleaning, and the air conditioning must be improved. There were not many conversations when we visited; everyone seemed stressed and focused on deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.

**Chewing Gum Culture**
Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew 12 million sticks of it every day. This ancient habit has become a big business. Each stick of gum has less than ten calories, but it is considered food and must meet the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration.
Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials, which include pine resins and softeners. These help keep the flavor and improve the texture. However, this was not always true. The ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the mastic tree, which grows mainly in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and freshen their breath. American colonists learned from the Native Americans in New England and chewed resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, lumps of spruce for chewing were sold in the eastern United States, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.
Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with the discovery of chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree found in Central America. Gum made from chicle was smoother and more enjoyable to chew, leading to the growth of a new industry. However, attempts to grow sapodilla trees for chicle have not been successful. As the chewing gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were created.
Today, only a few chicle gatherers, called chicleros, still collect chicle. They have a hard and dangerous job, walking for miles in very humid conditions. They face many dangers, including poisonous snakes and insects. One insect, the chicle fly, lays its eggs in the ears and nose of the gatherers. Despite these risks, experienced chicleros climb trees quickly to collect the white sap, which they carry back to a camp. There, they boil the sap until it becomes sticky and form it into bricks.
Life at the camp is tough, with a boring diet mostly made of maize and local alcohol made from sugar cane. Even though their work is hard, chicleros worry about their jobs. Not long ago, the United States imported 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America. Last year, only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula.
As chewing gum sales have increased, manufacturers have turned to synthetic materials to save money and meet demand. Gum producers are also finding clever ways to market their products. They claim that gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were often given gum. One of the biggest claims is that chewing gum can help reduce tooth decay. When we eat, plaque acid forms, but our saliva helps neutralize this acid and provides important minerals. Gum makers say that chewing for 20 minutes can increase saliva flow.
Research is ongoing to create new textures and flavors. Glycerine and other vegetable oils are now used to make the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still use natural ingredients. Additionally, a large area of land in America is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**REMOTE HOTELS**
A. **INDIA - GHANERAO HOTEL, RAJASTHAN**  
Ghanerao Hotel is located in a small village near the Aravalli Hills, known for its craftsmen. The hotel combines the calm of an English country house with Indian culture. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years, and now Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel has basic facilities, with hot water provided in buckets, but this simplicity makes it charming.
B. **NEW ZEALAND - HERMITAGE HOTEL, MOUNT COOK**  
One of my favorite hotels is the Hermitage Hotel on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by chance while climbing. After a long climb down from a glacier, I was surprised to see this hotel in a beautiful and wild area. It was a wonderful experience to arrive at such a luxurious place after a tiring hike, with a man playing music on the piano.
C. **MAURITIUS - PARADIS HOTEL**  
The Paradis Hotel is located on a quiet peninsula in the south-west of Mauritius. The road to the hotel goes along empty beaches where only fishermen are found. The hotel is large and offers many free water sports, but you can easily find peace on its nine kilometers of private beach. If you swim a little way out into the Indian Ocean, you can hardly see the hotel because of the palm trees. In the evening, when everyone has left, you can enjoy the calm and beauty of the beach.
D. **ST LUCIA - LADERA HOTEL**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view of the Caribbean Sea. It is quiet and located high up at 1,000 feet. The open rooms look out between two mountains called the Pitons. The hotel has a colonial style with wooden furniture and four-poster beds covered with light fabric.
E. **TURKEY - THE SPLENDID HOTEL, ISTANBUL**  
The Splendid Hotel is on Buyukada, one of the Princes Islands, and is a great place to escape the noise of Istanbul. It takes only an hour by boat to get there. The islands have no cars, only horse-drawn carriages, and beautiful old wooden buildings. The Splendid Hotel is all white wood with red domes, inspired by a hotel from the French Riviera. Although it is a bit old now, it still has a lot of charm.
F. **FRANCE - CHATEAU D'ETOGES, EPERNAY**  
In the small village of Etoges, in the Champagne region, there is a lovely seventeenth-century chateau. It is surrounded by a moat with swans. The chateau has 20 unique rooms, some with four-poster beds, and one room even has a billiard table. They offer special weekend rates for two nights, including breakfast and dinner, plus complimentary champagne.
G. **KENYA - THE FAIRVIEW HOTEL, NAIROBI**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Nairobi, Africa. It is not overly fancy but is very welcoming. Many travelers stay here to rest after a safari and plan their next adventure. Guests often decide to stay longer after seeing the beautiful gardens and cozy rooms. The hotel has many trees and buildings on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great spot to enjoy the beautiful African sunset while having a nice dinner.
H. **ITALY - HOTEL SPLENDIDO, PORTOFINO**  
The Hotel Splendido was first signed by the Duke of Windsor. Many famous people have visited, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Today, you might see wealthy guests, but the hotel still has a splendid atmosphere. It used to be a monastery and now offers simple but delicious food in the restaurant, along with beautiful Persian rugs and homemade pasta.

Sue Brown is a hotel inspector. Christopher Middleton watched her during an inspection at the Globe Hotel. Just one minute into the inspection, things are already going wrong. The receptionist is busy talking on the phone and does not notice Sue and Christopher. Sue whispers, "She hasn't even acknowledged us. Very poor." This is a common mistake that Sue has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. 
Sue expects better service because the Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide she works for. However, the welcome is not good. The entrance from the car park is through a door with a buzzer, and the long hallway to the hotel is empty and dark. "This is not what I expected," Sue says.
Things get worse when the receptionist says, "We have no record of your booking." There are 15 rooms in the hotel, but only three are occupied that night. The room they are shown is not nice. It feels stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe. 
When Sue started her job, people called her "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black and didn't think she was tough. The next morning, after paying her bill, she tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who looks scared when he sees her. He quickly apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge, saying there is a blocked drain.
Sue suggests that he should not let guests go into the lounge with the smell and should guide them to another lounge instead. Greaves, who has only been at the hotel for five months, takes notes and seems unsure about Sue's advice. 
Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the young waitress, for their good service and knowledge about the hotel’s 400-year history. The dinner is also good enough to keep the hotel’s two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks, "What do we need to do to get three rosettes?" Sue replies, "Don’t serve a pudding that collapses." 
Sue's job is to tell the hotel what is wrong, even if it is difficult. She remembers a time when a woman complained that Sue got her son fired because he served her apple pie with his fingers. Sometimes, she receives angry letters from people who do not like her reports. "You get used to it, but it still hurts," she says. 
Sue must give her findings to the hotel verbally and also write a full report. The hotels pay for her advice. Even though it is a tough job, it is worth it for the hotels with red stars. Greaves is relieved to hear that Sue will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. However, another inspector will come back in two months to check if the problems have been fixed. "Good," Greaves says, but he does not sound very happy.

**Climbing the Seven Summits**
Doug Scott, a mountaineer, shares his experiences of climbing the highest mountains on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. He started this journey later in life and will tell his story in the order he climbed them.
**A. Mt. Everest, Asia (8,848m)**  
Doug and his climbing partner, Dougal Haston, were in a snow cave, 91 meters below the top of Mt. Everest. Dougal started talking about sleeping bags, which Doug found strange since it was just the two of them. He thought it was because they were low on oxygen. Doug began talking to his own feet, feeling the cold. He remembered other climbers who lost fingers and toes to frostbite. They were not just worried about surviving but also about how well they would survive. Over the next two days, Doug thought about their time on the mountain. He felt lucky to have Dougal with him, as he made Doug feel calm and confident. Doug knew he needed to find a better rhythm to reach the summit, and he did.
**B. Mt. McKinley, North America (6,194m)**  
Mt. McKinley is known as one of the most dangerous mountains. In April 1976, Doug and Dougal arrived at the Kahiltna Glacier and spent four days carrying equipment and food to the base. After the first day, they realized how big their task was. They followed a route from 1967 but decided to take a new path to the summit. They climbed with all their gear on their backs, which was a new way to climb this mountain. After three days, Doug's sleeping bag was wet, and they were both struggling. The low air pressure made it feel like they were much higher than they actually were. Finally, they reached the summit and celebrated their success.
**C. Kilimanjaro, Africa (5,895m)**  
In September 1976, Doug and his friend Paul Braithwaite flew to Nairobi to climb Mt. Kenya. However, they ended up climbing Kilimanjaro instead. They got lost in the thick jungle on the way, which was serious because water was hard to find. On the second day, they found some arrows painted on trees and a rock pool, which made them very happy. They tried to climb a steep wall but had to turn back due to falling rocks and ice. Instead, they took a safer route to the summit.
**D. Aconcagua, South America (6,960m)**  
In January 1992, Doug and his wife, Sharu, arrived at Aconcagua. They met a guide named Phil who suggested they join his group to climb a less crowded route. After waiting for bad weather to pass, they started climbing. The Polish Glacier was icy and dangerous, so they chose to take a different path. They walked with many other climbers to the summit. The wind was strong, and they camped outside as night fell. At base camp, they met a group planning to climb the Seven Summits, which made Doug think about doing the same.
**E. Vinson Massif, Antarctica (4,897m)**  
Doug learned that climbing Vinson Massif could be funded by guiding others. In November 1992, his team traveled to the South Pole. During this time, the sun never sets, and it is very quiet when the wind stops. On December 7, they set off for the summit. Despite strong winds and very low temperatures, they all reached the top in eight hours, although they could barely see because of the storm.
**F. Elbrus, Europe (5,633m)**  
In the summer of 1994, Doug's team gathered in St. Petersburg. They arrived at the base of Elbrus and had to pay a fee to their guide. After a few days of getting used to the altitude, they took a cable car up the mountain. They walked to a refuge and faced strong winds as they climbed. They thought they reached the summit but found there was still more to climb. They returned to the refuge and then descended the volcano.
**G. Carstensz Pyramid, Australasia (4,883m)**  
On their expedition to Carstensz, Doug and his team wanted to create a new climbing route and spend time with the local Dani people. They were warned about possible dangers from bandits but decided to continue. On May 12, they started climbing. The weather got better, and two team members went ahead while Doug and another member climbed more slowly. They reached the summit by 11 am, and Doug received a warm welcome for completing his seventh summit. Mission accomplished!

**Style Merchants**
Style is important in our lives today, from our clothes to home decoration and accessories. Jo Foley shares some fashion trends for this year.
**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**  
Ned Ingham creates beautiful and romantic wedding dresses. He suggests that people should avoid traditional, stiff dresses and the overly frilly style. Instead, he recommends simpler designs. Ingham has been drawing and designing wedding dresses since he was a boy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. You don’t have to be a bride to wear an Ingham dress; he also designs elegant evening dresses in modern colors and fabrics. For those who prefer classic styles, he offers a traditional navy-blue summer suit, which has been popular with English women for many years, but he makes it look fresh and new.
**Sally Quail: Jeweller**  
Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but has no formal training in jewellery. She started designing her own engagement ring when she couldn’t find one she liked. This led her to become a designer in 1990. Now, many famous people wear her jewellery. Her style features large semi-precious stones set in gold, creating beautiful necklaces, bracelets, and rings inspired by 18th-century designs. Recently, she has started using diamonds. "I wanted a diamond at this age," says 36-year-old Quail, "so I began working with them."
**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**  
Lily Grimson has been in the competitive fashion business for just four years, but two of her designs have been chosen for a big design exhibition. All of her handbags are handmade in the UK and are not just bags; they are stylish and glamorous, made from high-quality materials like calfskin and silk. A Grimson bag is special because of its elegance and attention to detail.
**Peter Little: Hairdresser**  
For over 20 years, Peter Little has styled the hair of many famous people. He believes most women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage at home. His goal is to make sure his clients look like they haven’t just come from a salon. However, his services are expensive, costing £250 for the first appointment, and there is a three-month waiting list. Peter has also created his own line of hairdryers and styling tools, so people can style their hair at home.
**Penny Pratt: Florist**  
Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and also works as a flower consultant for a large supermarket chain and top restaurants. She has no formal training in floristry and left her teaching job 10 years ago to try something new. Her modern flower arrangements have won many design awards, helping her start her own London Flower School. She has also given successful lectures in Japan and the USA. Penny believes that flower arrangements should be simple but strong, with fewer leaves. For wedding bouquets, she advises that all flowers should be of the same type.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**
The new five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses into a hotel. This allowed the hotel to use the latest technology for both staff and guests.
General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests by name. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will save money in the long run. He is happy with how well it works and the services it provides. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them when they come back. This is possible because the staff can save guests' preferences in the system.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion Hotel has a high-tech system to help with this. Guests can change the temperature in their rooms by three degrees around the normal 18°C. If they want, the front desk can adjust the temperature anywhere between 14°C and 25°C.
Business travelers will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models whenever needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this modern equipment, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and inviting. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a lovely garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This change has many benefits for both him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved parking. The hotel can now offer a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower beds along the path have a beautiful mix of colors and shapes. This is partly because the previous owners were good gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny would say some of Susan's ideas were not worth it, but when she told him she wanted to paint them, he understood her vision.
Susan likes to focus on painting individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set everything up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also enjoys watching how flowers change as they start to wilt. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they keep changing."
Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't like garden flowers back then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they look at home there. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t break anything.
