With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of flowers to paint, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**No Title**
Many trees in the Brackham area fell during the terrible storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This change made the town center look very different, which upset some of the older residents. 
One of those upset was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. However, during the worst of the storm, when the wind knocked down a walnut tree in his garden, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a big and healthy man, but for the first time, he was seriously ill with bronchitis. When he first felt pain in his head and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, tried to get him to see a doctor. He thought the police needed him too much, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forget things and made him more irritable. 
Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. By then, he was too weak to argue. Soon, he was at the pharmacy getting antibiotics and then back home, where Molly sent him straight to bed. 
On Thursday morning, when Molly told him that the walnut tree had fallen during the night, Pelham could hardly believe it. On Thursday evening, he weakly asked if the house was damaged. He was relieved to hear it was not and pulled the sheets over his head. 
On Saturday, when the antibiotics started to work and his temperature went down, he got up and realized that the loss of the walnut tree had changed how the living room looked. The Pelhams' big house was in a large garden. It was expensive, but Pelham was happy with his choice. The garden had made them feel private. 
Now, the storm had changed everything. Before, the view from the living room included the beautiful walnut tree. This tree did not make the room dark because there was also a window on the other wall. The tree created nice patterns of light and shadow that hid the old furniture they had brought from their last house. 
With the tree gone, the room felt too bright, showing the worn-out furniture clearly. The view from the window was not nice either. The tall house next door, which was hidden by the tree, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and pipes on the outside. It seemed to have many upstairs windows, all looking at the Pelhams. 
“Doesn’t it look terrible?” Pelham said weakly to his wife. But Molly, standing in the doorway, sounded more happy than upset. “That’s what I’ve been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost.”

**Living in the Valley**
We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first noticed the dangers in the hills around us that could threaten our survival. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Until then, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. Within a day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost completely blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But in the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed for a longer time. Up there, the wind blew strongly. In our valley, we only felt sudden gusts of wind; the trees swayed, but their branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had reasons to worry. The snow and wind were annoying, but they did not really scare us. The river, the Ryburn, which usually flowed gently, was what worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by the dams built many years ago.
Soon, the snow started to melt. Day after day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. These grey clouds spread over the valleys, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we began to watch the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain fell from the clouds, but the reservoir in the hills was filling up and getting close to overflowing. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. It was like Niagara Falls, as the water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river looked wild as the water poured down towards our home. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was much deeper than we had ever seen, rushing angrily at its banks. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its edge. Luckily, our hopes were answered as the dam held, and the water began to go down.
In the past, before the dam was built, the river had flooded nearby villages many times. Now, the dam controls the river's flow, and usually, everything is fine. The large amount of water from the hills, caused by snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam, with only a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and feel excited by the river's power. Thanks to the dam, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Film critic Mark Adams reflects on his ten years of work for a newspaper called The Front Page. Writing articles about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before that, he had written reviews for novels in other newspapers, films for a magazine, and done some work for the radio. This is how he met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also worked in radio and television. Tom hired Mark, but he was not mainly a journalist, so he was not very careful when choosing his team.
At first, Tom wanted a group of critics to cover different art forms like books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have a weekly lunch to discuss which topics to cover, and there would be guests to make it more enjoyable. Mark felt like he was living a dream: a new newspaper, and he was part of the team. It seemed surprising that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even thought a rich person was helping him and pretending to hire him because he lacked confidence. The first time he saw someone reading the newspaper on the London Underground with one of his reviews, he felt very shy.
Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out as planned. They did not meet as a group, so they communicated by phone. It turned out that people preferred to have a reviewer focus on one subject, so Mark chose to write about films. Without Tom's help, they would not have created the current system where Mark writes a long weekly article about one film. He enjoys this way of working. He would not want to do the usual film critic job, which means watching every new film. That routine would make him bored quickly. He would not want to sit in a screening room on a Monday morning thinking, "What terrible film do I have to watch now?" 
The freedom he has allows him to explore his ideas more deeply or, in a slow week, to find something interesting to say. But what is his role in the public eye? He believes people choose films based on the stars, the advertising, or the director. Some people are loyal to certain types of films, while others avoid them. It is rare for someone who dislikes westerns to buy a ticket for one after reading a review, or for a romantic film lover to skip a love story because of a critic's opinion. So, if a film review is not really a guide for consumers, what is it? Mark does not feel he has to be "right" about a movie. He does not think there should be a set number of "great" or "bad" films each year. His job is to present an argument. He does not see himself as a judge, and he does not want to be one.

**Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km? Because "it's fun."**
**Teenager with a love for endurance sports**
**WANTED:** A sports-loving training partner for a triathlete, preferably female. This is a chance to work with a potential Olympic champion. You should really enjoy distance running (regular 15km sessions), distance swimming (training in cold rivers is a plus), and distance cycling (enjoying 100km rides is helpful). You must be able to do all three activities without resting.
The triathlon is becoming one of the most popular Olympic sports. It has attracted large crowds who are both fascinated and shocked by athletes who swim 1500m, cycle 40km, and then run 10km without stopping. It looks tough, but what makes triathletes want to push their bodies so hard? 
Melanie Sears is a 17-year-old girl with great school results. She has not yet learned the usual phrases about personal satisfaction and mental challenges that many athletes say when asked why they compete. She explains, "You swim 1500m, then run out of the water and jump on your bike, still wet. Of course, then you freeze. After the 40km bike ride, you have to run 10km, which is long when you’re tired. But it’s great fun, and it’s all worth it in the end."
Melanie entered her first triathlon at 14. "I won the junior section, but I was the only junior there. It felt so easy that I waved at my team-mates as I went around." Feeling confident, she entered the National Championships. Although she had the second fastest swim and the fastest run, she did not do well overall. "I was following a man, and suddenly we ended up at the sea. We realized we had gone the wrong way. I ended up cycling 20 kilometres too far. I cried all the way through the run." But she did not give up and is determined to keep trying. "Sometimes I wish I could stop because then the pain would be over, but I’m afraid that if I stop once, I might want to stop again."
Her determination impresses Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director. "I tested her fitness," he says, "and she worked so hard on the running machine that it finally threw her off into a wall. She gave it everything, while most people stop when they can’t go any further. She just kept going."
Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. "I was almost as good as the top three in swimming and running, but much slower at cycling. That’s why I’m working very hard on it." She is trying to convince her parents to buy a £2,000 bike (it’s a special deal with £1,000 off) so she can compete in national 25 km and 100 km races later this year. But there is a cost. Her tough training has made her a bit of a loner. "I don’t have a social life," she says. "I’m not a party person anyway. After two hours of hard swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I call and write to the other girls on the team." What do they talk about? Boys? Clothes? "No, we talk about our times."
Where will all this focus lead? Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," where you only swim 750m, cycle 20km, and run 5km. She wants to enter even tougher events than the triathlon. "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with," she says.

**The Collectors**
Amanda Roy talks about collecting and why many people enjoy this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults also enjoys it. Collecting is a world full of passion, envy, enthusiasm, and joy. But if you want to collect something, remember this: only collect things you truly love.
People have collected items for a very long time. In the past, early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors of the pebbles. This was their first way of gathering objects for personal reasons. Over the years, not much has changed. Children still collect stones and seashells just because they are beautiful.
I have been collecting all my life. I have collected many things, from flowers like tulips to pottery and paintings. My first collection was stones I found in my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a cold and windy place in England. When my parents visited, they took me to a local museum filled with interesting objects collected by people long ago. I was very fascinated by these items.
Many adults share my interest in collecting. One reason people collect is that it gives them control over something in their lives. For me, it is just a fun activity. One famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a "room of wonders" with many curious items, like cups made from coconut shells and pieces of beautiful china. Another collector, Catherine the Great of Russia, had more than 4,000 paintings. But you don’t need to be rich to start a collection. I have collected different items, like tulip bulbs and china cups, with great determination.
I remember when I convinced another tulip collector to sell me a special tulip. I planted it and took care of it, but one year it disappeared – stolen by another collector. I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for different designs. Sadly, my collection was destroyed when my house caught fire. The next morning, I stood in my front hall and saw the remains of my furniture and my collection. I was very sad about both.
I have always been interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or a poet can make an item very valuable. As small objects become popular among collectors, their prices go up. For example, toys from the 1950s are now worth a lot, especially if you kept the original boxes. (I, unfortunately, threw away both the boxes and the toys!)

**My Line of Work**
Four people talk about their jobs.
**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**  
I organize temporary exhibitions. This means I plan and design the exhibition and promote it. I read about the exhibition topic and talk to important people to find out the main ideas and goals. I decide what objects and pictures to show. I also create interactive displays, workshops, and theatre to help the public understand the exhibition. I work with engineers and electricians to make sure everything is safe for visitors. Before the exhibition opens, I help design and write brochures and leaflets to inform people about it.
**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**  
I start my day at 7:30 a.m. by checking the accounts. Then, I see what new maps and documents we need for the taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are in class, learning how to make the journeys. They find the best routes, using the right one-way streets and turns. I help when there are disagreements, like whether a right turn is allowed at a certain junction. When they are close to the test, I give them a simple route, but I tell them they must take a different way because the road is closed. This helps them think of new routes.
**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**  
I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to our main office, but I mostly work on the coast. I collaborate with schools and study centers and run courses for coastal managers. I take them out to sea in a boat to help them understand the life in the ocean. This often changes their views because it is very different from making decisions on a computer. I am lucky because conservation is my hobby, so I enjoy my job. However, I work for a charity, so I always need to find more money, which makes it hard to do everything I want.
**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**  
My job is quite varied. I make sure our publishing program meets market needs and that we have about 300 copies of each book we publish. We have high standards for information and content. We receive many letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I must respond carefully. I discuss future projects and current sales with my co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job enjoyable. The downside is that there is too much administration work, which takes time away from more interesting tasks like product development and design.

**No Title**
Every June, we went to Ireland. Since the four of us started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of the month at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It is a big house by the sea, not far from the village of Ardbeag. The English couple who own the house, the Malseeds, have made some changes to it, but they did it carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds were still advertising. One evening, he said, "How about this?" and read the details. 
The summer before, we went to a hotel that friends recommended, but it was not good because the food was terrible. The four of us have been playing cards together for a long time: Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and me. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school; Dekko Deacon sounds nice, I guess. He and Strafe went to school together, which is why we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live close to the town where the Malseeds lived before moving to Ireland. We always think it is a funny coincidence.
"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are arriving because she is usually waiting in the large hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. She called the rooms "Rose," "Tulip," "Lily," and "Geranium." Instead of numbers, Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of little details like that; her husband takes care of repairs and decoration.
"Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said as he came into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He was smiling, and his dark brown eyes sparkled, making us feel special, not just another group of hotel guests. Everyone smiled, and I could tell the others felt that our holiday had really started. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good.
Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur led the way to our rooms, carrying as much luggage as he could and going back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while, but we didn’t play for too long because we were still tired from the journey. 
In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because Glencorn Lodge is always full in June. From our table by the window, we could see some guests walking on the lawns and others going down the cliff path to the beach. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the beach to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then return in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this would happen because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we had all fallen in love with the beautiful landscape.

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. She is busy making beds and cooking delicious dinners. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Known as Pilch, she works in Val d'Isere, France. Here, she cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah graduated last summer from Oxford Brookes University, where she studied French and History of Art. She does not see being a chalet girl as a long-term job, but rather a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a career. "It's a good way to meet people," she says. "I meet successful people every week."
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m."
After skiing, Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because it would be bad for her work. Dinner is served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning." Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks are not as good."
Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. They usually start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, she does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "and you don’t want to cook breakfast with a headache."
On Sunday, work starts early. Breakfast for guests leaving has to be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for new guests." If she has not done the shopping on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them."
Between tea and dinner, Sarah takes guests who need ski boots or skis to the ski shop and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and sometimes she has a drink afterward, but not always. "Sometimes I'm so tired I just go to bed early," she says.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small girl with pale skin. She looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie, but she said she was six years older. One day, she visited his factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her curly hair framed her pretty face. Seymour found it hard to believe that she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania and doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.
A few times a year, someone would contact Seymour to ask if they could visit his factory. Sometimes, he would help students by answering their questions over the phone or giving them a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita was very small, almost like the children from Marie's third-grade class, who had visited the factory years ago to see how gloves were made. Seymour remembered how Marie loved to watch the workers shape and press the gloves using hot brass hands that looked like they had been flattened. She called them "pancake hands."
Rita asked, "How many pieces come in a shipment?" Seymour replied, "Between twenty and twenty-five thousand." She took notes and asked, "Do they come directly to your shipping department?" He liked that she was interested in all the details. He explained, "They go to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they prepare it for us. My grandfather, father, and I all worked in the tannery here in town. Have you ever been inside a tannery?" 
"Not yet," Rita said. 
"Well, you should visit one if you want to write about leather. I can help you arrange that. Tanneries are old-fashioned. The technology has improved, but they still look similar to how they did hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries in the world. They found 6,000-year-old tanning tools in Turkey. The first clothes were just animal skins that were tanned by smoking them. It’s a fascinating subject. My father knows a lot about leather; you should talk to him. If you start a conversation about gloves, he could talk for two days. Glovemakers really love their work. 
"Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?" he asked. 
"I can't say I have," she replied. 
"Never seen anything made?" 
"I saw my mother bake a cake when I was a child." 
Seymour laughed. She made him smile. She was eager to learn, and he thought she reminded him of Marie. Marie was much taller than Rita, but they both had a bright intelligence. 
"I have an idea," he said. "We will take you through the whole process. Come on! We are going to make you a pair of gloves, and you will watch them being made from start to finish. What size do you wear?"

**Is It a Tough Job?** 
Chris Arnot asks four people with dream jobs if they are as great as they seem.
**A. Raquel Graham**  
Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She cannot meet tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles instead. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she has to travel around the world quickly. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. However, she has one small problem - she does not like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to help me relax," she says. Her worst experience was flying on Concorde. "It felt so closed in with those tiny windows." When she is not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She has to do some boring tasks like organizing schedules, attending meetings with lawyers and accountants, planning trips, and making more travel arrangements. She did not apply for this job. A chance meeting with a pop group manager led to her getting work behind the scenes, and she took a secretarial course in the evenings. Five years later, she was in the right place when her boss needed a personal assistant.
**B. David Brown**  
David Brown has worked as an accountant and a golf caddy, which means he carries a golfer's bags. He prefers being a caddy because golf is his passion. However, there are some downsides. He earns a small flat fee plus a percentage of the winnings. On average, he makes between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of that goes on travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman when he was 31. "You are not just carrying bags. You give advice, use your knowledge, and try to understand the course," he explains. His skills in accounting were recognized by European Tour Productions, and they made him a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes statistics from the caddies, which are important for TV commentators, golf magazines, and the golfers.
**C. Martin Fern**  
Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a daily newspaper. One of his easier tasks is to taste food at the best restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "For those who can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I would rather spend £120 on a meal I will remember than buy a microwave." His cooking talent led to a friend offering him a food column in a Saturday Review. At that time, he was the creative director of an advertising agency, and it was a good extra income. He was 42 when another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant a 50% cut in my guaranteed income," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and tries to stay fit by cycling a couple of miles to the nearest tube station.
**D. Dick Prince**  
"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, one of Britain's most popular children's writers. "Before that, I loved words and enjoyed writing, but I mostly wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I had been a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So, I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, which became my first published children's book." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy; I have to work hard on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I don't wake up at dawn, though. After lunch, I spend a couple of hours typing what I wrote in the morning. I use an old typewriter instead of a laptop. I get between 50 and 100 letters a week, and that is the part of being a writer I enjoy the most. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help with that."

In the lumberyard by the lake, there was an old two-story brick building. Around it, there were big piles of soft sawdust. That afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored, so they climbed up to the roof of the building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down." Without thinking, he jumped off the roof and landed in the sawdust, rolling around and laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all cowards!" 
His friends looked scared but eventually jumped down one by one, smiling with relief. They lay on the sawdust, telling jokes until one of them said, "Let's go back up and jump again." They were not very excited, but they climbed back to the roof and started jumping off quickly. Soon, only Michael was left. His friends called up to him, "Come on, Mike! What's wrong?" 
Michael wanted to jump down, but he hesitated. He stood at the edge, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and take a deep breath, but he couldn't jump. His friends started laughing at him because they were tired of waiting. "Come on, you're a coward! Do you think we're going to sit here all night?" they shouted. When he still didn't move, they began to walk away, still teasing him. 
Michael felt alone and unhappy. He stayed at the edge of the roof for a long time, watching the sun set over the lake. He was sweating from being nervous. Finally, he closed his eyes and jumped down into the sawdust. He lay there for a while, and the yard was quiet because the workers had gone home. 
As he got up slowly, he felt ashamed and wanted to avoid everyone. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said coldly, "You should be able to get home on time. If you won't come home, maybe you should stay out tonight." She was a strong woman with soft skin and a little grey in her hair, always patient. But Michael, feeling gloomy and miserable, hardly listened to her. He was still thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy in your job and not sure how to change it? Kitty Doherty offers some helpful advice. Many people who want to change their job go to a careers adviser. First, you will write a short history about yourself and then take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you will get a summary of the results and suggestions for different careers, along with any retraining you might need.
I decided to try Career Analysts, a big organization that gives career advice. Taking the careers test felt like being back in school during science exams. I was in a group of about ten people, and we had to answer questions quickly. I reminded myself that it wasn’t about passing or failing. It was hard to see how the tests would show who I really am. The tests included finding mistakes in lists of names and numbers and matching similar shapes.
After the tests, I talked with an adviser. He used my test results and our conversation to create a report with his observations and suggestions. I agreed with most of what he said, but I was a bit upset to learn that I did poorly in the scientific and technical tests. I’m glad I didn’t become a nurse! However, it was good to hear that I made the right choices in journalism.
Changing your career doesn’t always mean making a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager after five years. Her friends suggested she go to Career Analysts for help. Donna said, "Losing my job was a great chance for me to think about my career. I wanted to look at my skills and interests." Some of the results surprised her. "I didn’t know I had a talent for design. But I had to think about the cost of retraining in design and my financial situation," she explained. Other ideas included taking a year off to work in the Far East. In the end, she decided to use her existing skills and move into a job that suited her better. Now, she works as a Public Relations officer. She believes she could have reached this point without Career Analysts, but they helped her understand what she really wanted to do. She has sent several friends there, and they are all happy with the service.
Some people feel they would not have made important decisions without help. Juliet Greene, 26, visited Career Counselling Services and made life-changing choices. After working at a major bank for six years, she found her job boring and wanted a new challenge. She went to Career Counselling Services with an open mind. The tests showed she was interested in sciences. She had four meetings with an adviser. The third meeting was recorded, which helped her remember what she said. After the fourth meeting, she decided to study geology and plans to start a degree later this year. She thinks the advice from Career Counselling Services was worth the cost. Now, she feels much happier and more positive.
However, career advice does not work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, a 24-year-old sales representative, said, "I was at a point in my career where I didn’t know what to do next. I thought a careers adviser might suggest something new. I got many new ideas, but I rejected them because they either meant a big pay cut or a lot of retraining. I didn’t learn anything new about myself." She felt that if she had told a friend the same things, they would have given her similar advice.

**Fun at the Dentist's?**
If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in the center of Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch where patients sit while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Fifty percent of people only go to the dentist when they are in pain instead of for regular check-ups. This is because they are scared." To help with this, he has tried to make a place where people feel safe. That is why he decided not to wear a white coat, which many people connect with pain. He believes that dental treatment should happen in a relaxing and enjoyable atmosphere.
This idea is surprising for many people who think of dental visits as painful or very serious. Jerome says, "If people are relaxed and entertained, they will forget their bad experiences." One of his new ways to help patients relax is by using virtual-reality headsets. "We were the first dental office in Britain to use them, and they are very popular. Patients wear the headsets during their check-up, sitting comfortably on the blue couch while watching a film about underwater wildlife. Then, the headset shows them a special camera view of their mouth."
Most patients seem to enjoy this part of their visit. Another interesting thing is that the office smells more like a perfume shop than a dentist's office. Today, it smells like orange. Jerome explains, "When people come in, I want them to feel with all their senses that this is not a typical dentist's visit. Smell is very important. The usual dentist smell can make people nervous."
I found the nice smell in the office very pleasant. Although Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, he takes his work very seriously. The relaxation techniques are important, but the quality of the treatment is the most important thing. For example, Jerome uses a special tool that sprays warm water on the teeth to clean them instead of scraping. It feels a little strange at first, but if people are relaxed, it is not painful at all.
Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental techniques. "I found that when you make it easier for the patient, it is easier for you too," he explains. He believes that his patient-focused approach is the start of a change towards a less formal style in British dentistry.
At that moment, a patient arrives. Jerome quickly goes to him, offers a cup of tea (herbal or regular), asks what video he would like to watch, and gently leads him to the chair. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment, and it is easy to see why. The office feels more like a beautiful salon than a regular dental practice.

**Bitter Water Hits the Big Time**
Chocolate comes from South America and is now a huge global business. In Britain, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter, which is about eight percent of all chocolate sales for the year. Only at Christmas do people buy more chocolate. 
The large production of chocolate started in the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan civilizations in Central America over three thousand years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds inside. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, but this is a mistake from the 17th century when they were also called cacoa and cocao beans.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and made a drink called xocoatl, which means "bitter water" in their language, Nahuatl. They flavored this drink with spices for special occasions and to welcome guests. The Spanish liked the drink better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another hundred years for the recipe to reach the rest of Europe.
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in major European cities where people could drink chocolate. Until the last century, the drink was made from solid chocolate blocks that had to be melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the crushed beans. The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when a company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to create a solid bar. A Swiss company later added milk solids to make milk chocolate.
At the beginning of the 20th century, French companies dominated the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to attract some French style. Then, in 1905, Cadbury introduced the Dairy Milk bar, which was first called Dairymaid. Smart advertising linked it to the healthy milk from the English countryside, making it popular against the richer French brands.
Today, British people eat about four chocolate bars each week. This has made chocolate companies look for new ways to attract customers. One new idea is the "extended line," where chocolate bars are turned into ice cream, soft drinks, or desserts to attract chocolate lovers who want something different.
However, cacao farmers are still struggling because cocoa bean prices fell in the late 1980s. Many small-scale farmers went out of business. So, as you enjoy your next chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**
At 83 years old, Peter Cooke is a master of his art. He still wants to try new things, like making paper and working with feathers. But for now, he focuses on what he loves: creating beautiful objects from shells. 
As he shows me his work in his apartment, he asks, "Am I boring you?" There is a fine line between being boring and being interesting, but Peter is definitely interesting. His charm and the beauty of his creations make it easy to listen to him. 
He points to some shell-covered decorations above his fireplace. "I won’t mind if people don’t buy them because I love them," he says. "I never planned to sell my work. About five years ago, some friends told me I should have an exhibition so more people could see my art. They helped me talk to a gallery owner." 
The exhibition in London was a success, with 70% of the pieces sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The prices for his work are high, around £2,000 for some decorations. Cooke says he has nothing to do with the prices and is happy to share them. He believes that no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him that one day, people will want his pieces because he will stop making them.
Cooke wishes he had started this work earlier in life. He thinks he could have made even more amazing things. Although he still has many ideas, he feels he can’t do as much now because he is not as strong as he used to be. However, his work is very different from the common shell items found in seaside shops. He describes himself as having a "miniature mind," which helps him create boxes covered in tiny shells, pictures made from shells, and baskets of realistic flowers.
He has his own way of working and uses materials he finds. For example, he uses cardboard from laundered shirts for flower bases, a special glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. "I have an idea of what I want to do, and it just happens," he says about his process. The details and colors in his work look very careful and planned.
Peter travels to many places to find beautiful, tiny shells. He has been to beaches in France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines, where he lies on the sand to search for shells. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who accuse him of harming the beaches. "When I collect shells, I hear people walking on them much faster than I can collect them. The sea breaks up the shells that are left. I would never take shells with living creatures in them, but once they are empty, why shouldn’t I collect them?" 
His argument is strong, especially when you think about how much one person can carry home, creating beauty from the shells he finds.

**The Schoolgirl Model**
Kira Langer is a 15-year-old girl who is a model. When she is not traveling to exciting places or appearing on magazine covers, she studies for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.
The receptionist at Kira's modeling agency told me, "I'm afraid Kira will be a little late." I thought, "That's okay." I had read some bad things about models, like they can be difficult or vain. I worried that Kira might be very late or not come at all. But when Kira arrived, she was smiling and relaxed, and she was with her mother. 
Kira was not wearing fancy clothes; she had on a simple black dress and trainers. She seemed very friendly and was not selfish at all. Kira explained that all models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Her mother looked proud of her daughter.
Kira seemed a bit confused about her sudden fame because it was unexpected. It was her older sister who encouraged her to enter a modeling competition. Kira said, "I said no, but she sent some photos anyway." When she found out she was a finalist, she was at school. This gave her the confidence to continue, and she won the competition easily. The Select model agency in London offered her work right away.
Now, Kira has to manage her two lives as a student and a model. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too highly of herself. Kira finds this hard to handle because she is not a selfish person. She said, "They think I can't stay the same just because I'm a model. The only thing that has changed is that I am more confident."
Being a busy model affects her social life. The agency can call her at any time for a job the next day. Kira said, "If my friends are going out, I can't promise to join them because I don’t know my schedule." However, her friends understand and do not complain about her modeling.
Kira has the looks, talent, and support to have a great career. Not many people can say that before finishing school. As I was ending the interview, I asked her what she would like to do if she were not a model. She thought for a moment and said, "I’d like to do what you’re doing."

**Father and Son Start Gold Rush**
Terence and Chris Madden have traveled from the cold north of Canada to the hot lands of Africa looking for valuable metals. This father and son team—one is an explorer and the other is a mineral expert—believe their mine on a Welsh mountain could have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging in the Welsh hills, they think they are very close to finding a gold vein worth five million dollars. 
"As we dig, we are finding a lot of gold; now we just need to dig a bit more to reach where it is concentrated," said Terence, 68, from Liverpool. They have dedicated their lives to finding gold. Their search started when Terence read about gold worth millions hidden in the "Dolgellau gold belt," an area near the town of Dolgellau in Wales. While reading old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth, they chose the best area of land to explore.
Since they first cleared the land and found pieces of gold in the rocks, they have spent ten years getting permission to work from the landowners, taking soil samples, and removing old cars and trash. They dug out 150 tonnes of greenstone rock to create a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they are running out of money. They have spent their savings on this dream and need to convince someone to invest £50,000 to dig a bit deeper to reach the gold.
Chris Madden says, "Right now, it seems unlikely, but we have a few people we can contact." As news spread about their dig, more people in the area became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the locals are hopeful. "If they are right, it would bring more people here," said Peter Woolven, manager of the Royal Ship Hotel, "but if they find gold, I hope millions of people don’t come and dig up the hillside."
The Welsh gold industry has declined a lot since its peak in the late 1880s when many people worked in hundreds of mines across the countryside. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, individual gold diggers are coming back. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel deep into the hill on the other side of the ridge from the Maddens. "Searching for gold is very emotional," said Hall, 70. "It's adventurous and exciting, the thrill of finding hidden treasure. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, like a small car, and dives three kilometers down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
Inside the vehicle, there is very little space. Rachel says, "I can reach out and touch the two pilots." They cannot stand up or move around, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up. If there is a problem and they need to get to the surface quickly, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface, but Rachel thinks it would not be a nice journey.
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. She got in with an instructor who explained what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. They went to a place five days away from the Canary Islands in the Atlantic Ocean, where there are many underwater volcanoes that release black smoke. The Russian team was dropping off equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano.
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She says, "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.'" Black smokers are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. This water comes out at a speed of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.
Rachel felt scared the first time she dived with an American team. They were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. She heard a loud bang and thought, "I'm going to die." They waited in silence, and when nothing happened, they felt incredible relief—they were still alive!
Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure for Rachel. Every time she looks out of the porthole and sees the chimneys, she feels amazed. She thinks, "Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen this." Rachel studied black smokers for three years for her PhD, and when she finally saw them in person, it was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a little sunburned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was confused by different train schedules, money, and languages. "Never again," I said as I arrived home. I said the same thing the next year and the year after that. All I needed to do was buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month.
Sleeping in a train corridor is very different from sleeping in a regular bed. The movement of the train rocks you to sleep. Carrying all your things in a backpack makes you travel simply and can lead to wasting things, like burning socks that smell bad or throwing away books after reading them. But this way of thinking is part of the Inter-Rail spirit, where you can forget about common sense and just enjoy the journey. All you need is that special ticket in your hand.
This ticket lets young people travel through many countries in one day, which is amazing. On my first trip, my friends and I didn’t realize how much we could do with this ticket. We thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we soon wanted to see more countries, and there was always one more place to visit. The extra travel didn’t cost us anything.
We were interested in culture, but this was our first holiday without our parents, like many other Inter-Rail travelers. We planned our own schedule and focused on the sights we could see easily. It was a chance to avoid guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes all I wanted to see was the view from the train station. We were just trying to enjoy ourselves, like most other Inter-Railers who shared the train with us.
The excitement of travel comes from arriving in a place you only knew by name. It feels like the city didn’t exist until the train arrives, and you see it for the first time. By traveling through Europe, watching the changing landscapes, and noticing different lifestyles, you can really understand the continent. Everyone knows about these places, but it means nothing until you see them yourself. That’s why other people’s holiday photos can be boring. While the train trip may not show you new things in the world, it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail gives people a great chance to explore it, even if it doesn’t happen right away.

Arriving at an airport in another country and finding out that your luggage is missing can be very disappointing. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline finds your bags. If you are in a different climate, you may have to wear clothes that are not suitable for the weather. 
Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers at some point. Even the best airlines can make mistakes, and it is hard for any airline to promise that your checked luggage will travel on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes.
Here is how it works: Airlines ask passengers to check in early, which gives enough time for bags to be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest time needed to change from one flight to another, and these times are also set longer to help with luggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. However, extra security checks and air traffic problems can cause flight delays, which can lead to luggage issues. 
Human mistakes can also happen, like if a luggage tag gets torn off. These problems can be worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London’s Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways alone had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow.
Even busy airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich can have problems. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers quickly connect to flights to Latin America.
To avoid losing your luggage, try to book direct flights when you can and check in early. If you must change planes, it is best to fly with the same airline. Allow extra time for connections by taking an earlier flight, and make sure to label your luggage with your home and holiday addresses, including your flight numbers.
If your luggage is still missing after all this, contact the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before you leave the airport.

**The Kingfisher**
Wildlife photographer Charlie James is an expert on the kingfisher, a beautiful blue-green bird that lives near streams and rivers and eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, providing some shade to the shallow water. The main colors in this scene are soft greens, browns, and different shades of yellow from the sunlight. The sound of the water is gentle, like a breeze. The kingfisher moves quickly and smoothly, like a flash of light. It is gone in a moment, but its image stays in your mind because it is so powerful for such a small bird.
Charlie James fell in love with kingfishers when he was young. He feels a strong connection to this little bird, but he cannot explain why. The kingfisher is part of many legends. In Greek mythology, it is a moon goddess that turned into a bird. Another story says that the kingfisher flew so high that its upper body became blue like the sky, while its lower body was burned by the sun. There is some truth in this story. Even though kingfishers have many shades of blue, they do not have blue pigment in their feathers. Instead, the way their feathers are structured scatters light and reflects blue. This is why a kingfisher can look bright blue or rich emerald green depending on the light.
It is no surprise that many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. Their beautiful colors and the fact that they are shy but can be watched from a distance make them very interesting. Charlie James's first hiding place was an old blanket he put over his head while he waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot. The bird came back in just a few minutes and sat only one meter away. However, it took him four more years to get his first good picture. During this time, the European kingfisher became a big part of his life. He spent as much time as he could by a stream where kingfishers lived. Unfortunately, school took away some of his time with the birds, and he missed classes, calling himself an "academic failure." But his passion for the kingfisher, which is the most common kingfisher in the world and the only one that breeds in Europe, was noticed. At 16, he was hired as an advisor for a nature magazine. He later worked as an assistant to the editor and then became a freelance wildlife film cameraman.
Now, he wants to make the perfect kingfisher film. "No speech, just beautiful images that say it all," he says. "I like to photograph parts of kingfisher wings..." His voice trails off as he thinks about the colors of the bird he has spent more than half his life observing, which still fascinates him. His photographs show some of his feelings, but Charlie knows that there is much more to his connection with the kingfisher than his work can ever show.

**Conducting an Orchestra**
Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their experiences.
**A. ANNE MANSON**  
Anne Manson, 30, wanted to learn from famous conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. When an assistant could not come, she stepped in to help. Later, she led her first rehearsal with Abbado. "I wasn't nervous. I enjoy being in front of an orchestra," she said. Manson, who is from America, works with a well-known opera company in London that focuses on modern music. She is also gaining recognition in other European countries, thanks to support from the British Arts Council. Since her first experience, she has helped Abbado on many projects.
**B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE**  
Andrew Constantine, 31, believes the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. He feels lucky about the timing: "If I had won earlier, I might have been forgotten." The competition gave him many chances to perform and work as an assistant to a famous conductor. However, he worries about being known only for the competition. "If in three years people still connect me to the competition, I will be concerned," he said. But orchestras like the English Chamber Orchestra are inviting him back, which is important for his career.
**C. WASFI KANI**  
Wasfi Kani, who started Pimlico Opera, enjoys the long practice times needed for opera. "The music deserves four weeks of focus," she said. Kani began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became fully professional two years ago. Learning from Sian Edwards was a turning point for her. "I saw her conduct and realized she was my size. I had always learned from much bigger people, which made a big difference." She appreciates the complexity of opera, saying, "There are many arguments, and you have to think about the singers' personalities."
**D. ROGER VIGNOLES**  
Roger Vignoles, 48, found conducting surprising but fascinating. He started as a musician in an opera house and learned from good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival, which was new for him. "It was easier than I expected. I knew the music well and what I wanted it to sound like," he said. He is grateful for all his experiences in music and performing. Now, he is open to trying different things to discover what he enjoys.
**E. WAYNE MARSHALL**  
In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, a young assistant conductor, and told his agent about him. Now 32, Marshall quickly found himself conducting a musical in London with little notice. It was a tough start, especially when some musicians were reading newspapers during the show. "I was firm with them. I always kept a clear beat and did my best," he said. He noticed that many musicians do not seem to need much guidance from a conductor. "But I am not afraid to say what I want. If people see you are worried, it gets worse." Marshall has not studied conducting formally, but he is determined and knows what he likes.

**Variations on a Theme**
If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many options in Britain. We asked five families to try some of the best parks.
**Fun Island - The Burns Family**  
Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island would be boring. But we were surprised! The park is great for younger children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for little kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and nicer scenery. However, the staff were very helpful, and the park was clean and safe.
**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**  
None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn’t know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it! He enjoyed the Mountain Train and liked Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and were happy to find places to relax. The park looked beautiful, and the staff were friendly. There was something for everyone, even adults.
**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**  
After seven hours, we still wanted to see more. The kids loved the Big Top Circus, which had an amazing trapeze act. We tried the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared and kept their eyes closed, they said they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you will get wet, but you don’t. Toy Land is also very fun for younger kids. The children wanted to try the new ride, Fear Factor, but we were relieved they were too small for it! The park is so well designed that waiting in line isn’t boring. It was very clean, and the staff were great. One staff member even helped me with one of the girls when I couldn’t sit with both of them.
**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**  
We arrived at one o'clock and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger children because the rides are not too scary. I am a bit scared of rides, but I had fun too. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes very exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over too quickly! I wouldn’t go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were a bit older, they might have found it too easy, but they loved it at their age.
**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**  
The park says there is "No Limit to the Fun," and we really felt that was true. The tallest roller-coaster in Europe, the Rocket, is very impressive. Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters in the air, was even scarier! There are about a dozen main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but enjoyed the Long Slide. The staff were friendly, but some were not as welcoming. You need a whole day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn’t have told the kids we were going home early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside**
Five women share their experiences of starting a business in the countryside.
A. **Christine Hogan** runs a computer-aided design business that makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time employees. She says, "My customers are friends. My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted a job I could do at home. I had worked with computers before marriage, so my husband suggested I start this business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. I was careful with my spending and always told the bank manager if I might overspend. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. My business is small, and most customers come to pick up their work."
B. **Maggy Sasanow** designs greeting cards from her home. She says, "I enjoy being independent. I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but when I got married, we moved to the countryside where there were no jobs like that. So, I started my own business and now I make 50 different greeting cards that I sell to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The downside of working from home is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. I don’t advertise; my business grows by word of mouth. People send me work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. I miss sharing ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad."
C. **Delia Turner** has a curtain-making business that has had ups and downs. She says, "I started my business eight years ago when it was growing. In two years, my income went from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to have six full-time workers, but I had to let them go because the economy got worse. It was hard because jobs are not easy to find here. Now, I make curtains at home with my husband’s help and work with women who also work from home. I have to lower my prices sometimes and look for new opportunities."
D. **Tessa Strickland** runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons: it was cheaper than London, and she loves the countryside. She says, "I like being able to work when I want. Most of my income comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at strange hours. The hard part is staying disciplined and shutting the office door. I publish children's books from different cultures and work with authors and artists. I felt lonely at first because all my experience was in London."
E. **Meg Rivers** runs a cake business that makes £250,000 a year and employs six people, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home. She says, "I am very interested in health, so I began making fruit cakes with good quality ingredients. Friends and family started asking for cakes, and soon I was sending them all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building where we make all the cakes. I don’t bake anymore; I manage the business. My biggest challenge has been the financial side because we didn’t have a lot of money to start."

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**
The Watkins family is very talented in music. The sons are composers and award-winning musicians, while their dad makes musical instruments. 
John and Hetty Watkins are schoolteachers from South Wales. When they needed to buy a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul, they found it was very expensive. John thought, "Maybe I can make one myself." He found a school nearby that taught instrument making and took evening classes for about three years. 
After trying to make violins and violas, John finally made his first cello. Paul, now 28, says, "It turned out really well. He made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago." John has now retired from teaching and makes about twelve violins each year. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.
Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul remembers, "I began with the piano as soon as I could reach the keys." He also tried the violin because his dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. But Paul preferred the cello after meeting the cellist in his dad's group. He thought the cellist was very cool and started taking lessons.
Huw, now 22, says, "My parents were supportive but not pushy. I wanted to follow in Paul's footsteps." Huw is now making a name for himself as a pianist and composer.
Paul has done very well with the cello his dad made. He won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At just 20 years old, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he plays a different cello, which is very old and on loan from the Royal Academy of Music. 
Paul will soon perform on television, playing Elgar's Cello Concerto. He says, "I will always play it my way." However, he cannot watch himself on TV because he will be performing at the Cheltenham Festival that same night. Huw will also be busy, as his String Quartet will have its London premiere at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be very organized to keep up with all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.

**Looking after the Countryside: The National Trust**
The National Trust is an organization that works to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who helps take care of the beautiful areas owned by the Trust.
Gareth believes that a National Trust Warden needs common sense and good people skills. He often works with farmers, visitors, conservationists, and building companies. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm until he got married. Many people wanted the job of National Trust Warden, but Gareth got it because of his local knowledge and farming experience, even though he did not have formal training.
Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand the farmers' problems. He says, "They can't trick me!" His farming background also helps him with the physical work of the job, like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since joining the Trust, Gareth has learned more about nature conservation. He remembers picking flowers and collecting butterflies when he was younger. He now realizes that farming has changed the countryside, but it is not the farmers' fault; they were just following government rules.
When Gareth started his job, farmers and conservationists did not get along. They both wanted things done their way. Now, they are talking and understanding each other better. Gareth says, "We are close to finding a way to work together."
Gareth's job includes conservation, allowing the public to visit the Trust's land, planting trees, and working with tenant farmers. He wants to finish projects efficiently and enjoys seeing them completed. However, he spends a lot of time on reports and paperwork.
Gareth loves his job and enjoys talking to the public, although some visitors can be difficult. He says, "Some people come in, demand things, and leave as if they own the place. It can be frustrating to be nice to them!" But Gareth believes that common sense is important.
If you have common sense and like working outdoors, you might consider becoming a warden like Gareth. However, there may not be a job available on the Lleyn Peninsula for a long time!

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slowinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day, teaching at a local school and then training in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s it."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be as fit as possible. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have support from home, which is very special," she said. "It’s important to improve the reputation of netball in our country. There will be more pressure because we are playing at home. People expect us to start the tournament well."
Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra mentioned, "We have always beaten them, but they will be fun to play against because they are very skilled." The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world, but Kendra knows the Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. In the Championships, you only have one chance, so you must be ready."
In the fifteen years she has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. Kendra said, "You don’t train hard to lose. But after the game, we are all friends again." 
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. Kendra said, "It is important for us to think and train like world-class players. As captain, I need to have a strong mindset and lead by example. I want to support and encourage my team."
Kendra explained, "From the start of my netball career, I have planned everything carefully. I decided that this competition would be my last as a player." She will likely coach young players in the future, but for now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes.

**SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS**
How can parents help a child with great musical talent? It can be hard to know the best way to support their gift. Some parents might not see their child's needs until the child becomes frustrated and acts out. While most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math and English, musically talented children need special support that regular schools may not provide, especially if music is not a main focus.
Children who are musically gifted, and those whose talents are encouraged by their parents or teachers, can benefit from attending a specialist music school. There are five of these schools in Britain, and they are relatively new. They provide a friendly environment for children aged seven to eighteen to develop their musical skills with the help of professional musicians.
At specialist music schools, children spend a lot of time on music activities. They have individual lessons (up to three hours a week for their main instruments), play in orchestras and chamber groups, and receive voice training and music theory lessons. They also practice in private rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their day includes a limited academic program that focuses on important subjects like English, math, basic sciences, and languages. Students can also study more subjects if they want.
All five British specialist music schools are independent, meaning they are not funded by the government. Classes are small, with more teachers available for each student. Most children at these schools live there full-time, which allows them to spend their formative years with others who share their interests.
However, there are some downsides. One major issue is the cost; fees can be high (between £12,000 and £17,000 a year for boarders). Each school tries to help parents with scholarships and financial aid for very talented children. Also, not all parents want to send their children to boarding school, especially at a young age. Many directors of these schools worry about admitting children as young as seven into such a strict environment. They want to help children grow into well-rounded individuals.
It is true that separating musically gifted children from a young age can cause stress. Some children may lose their musical talent during their teenage years, and the pressure to succeed can lead to feelings of failure. However, specialist schools closely monitor each student's progress and provide help when needed.
Most former students of music schools feel they gained a lot from the high-quality music education, but many also worry about the limited academic program, which is less important than music. Many musically talented young people are also very smart and can handle academic challenges. They may feel frustrated if their academic needs are not met.
For these reasons, it might be better to wait until a child is older and can make their own choices before considering a specialist music education. Children who are also academically gifted can do well in regular schools with good music programs or by combining regular school with music training at junior departments of music colleges. These colleges offer Saturday morning lessons with excellent teachers, as well as opportunities to play in orchestras and chamber music groups. However, this option may not be possible for families living far from London or other big cities.

**An Eye for Detail**
Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. The large garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden is full of her favorite flowers, especially tulips and poppies. Some plants grow wildly and spread all over the garden. The two long flower beds along the path have a beautiful mix of colors and shapes. This is partly because the previous owners were good gardeners and left plants that Susan liked. She also kept the gardener, Danny. Susan says, "In fact, it was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny would say some of Susan's ideas were not worth it, but when she told him she wanted to paint them, he understood her vision.
Susan likes to focus on painting individual plants instead of the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks one flower and takes it to her studio. "I don't set the whole thing up at once," she explains. "I take one flower out and paint it, which might take a few days. Then I bring in another one and build up the painting that way. Sometimes it takes a couple of years to finish."
Her busiest time is in spring and early summer when the tulips bloom, followed by the poppies. "They all come out together, and you're so busy," she says. But she also enjoys watching how flowers change as they start to wilt. For example, with tulips, "you bring them in and put them in water, then leave them for a day, and they change shape. They open up and look amazing. At first, you think they are boring, but they keep changing."
Susan has always loved plants. "I studied botany in school and collected wildflowers from the countryside," she says. "I didn't like garden flowers back then; I thought they looked fake, like silk or plastic flowers. I was fascinated by how wildflowers could grow in tough places, like cracks in rocks or on cliffs."
Today, her garden has many plants from faraway places, but they look at home in her garden. She has a relaxed attitude towards her garden, like a caring aunt who lets children play freely as long as they don’t break anything. With two upcoming exhibitions to prepare for and plenty of flowers to paint, she has found it hard to work in the garden lately. She now has an extra gardener, but she knows that to stay connected to her art, "you have to get your hands dirty."

**Keeping Holiday-Makers Happy**
A chalet girl's work is never done, says Sarah Sutherland-Pilch. She is busy making beds and cooking delicious dinners. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and comes from West Sussex, England. Known as Pilch, she works in Val d'Isère, France. Her job is to cook and clean for visitors who come to ski and stay in wooden houses called chalets.
Sarah graduated from Oxford Brookes University last summer, where she studied French and History of Art. She thinks being a chalet girl is not a long-term career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a more serious job. "It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful guests every week," she says.
Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to work. The chalet can host up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. "They get a full breakfast - porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants." After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either prepares afternoon tea for the guests or cleans the rooms, which she says is the worst part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. "On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.," she says.
Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower first but does not sleep because she says it is not good to sleep before dinner. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans the kitchen. "There's nothing worse than coming into a messy kitchen the next morning," she says. Sometimes she talks with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. "Good guests can make a week great, but some weeks are not as good for different reasons."
Sarah meets her friends in the chalet where she lives, and they usually go out around 11 p.m. They often start at a place called Bananas, then go to G Jay's, and maybe end the night at Dick's T-Bar. However, Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. "It's a tough day," she says, "when you don’t want to cook breakfast feeling tired."
