On Sundays, work starts earlier. Breakfast for the guests must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. "We clean everything - clear the breakfast, strip the beds, and get ready for the next guests." If she has not done the shopping for the week on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for the new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. "I think the mountain air affects them," she jokes.
Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests who need ski boots or skis and then gets a ride back to the chalet. Soon, it is time for dinner again, and she might chat with friends, but sometimes she is too tired and goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. One day, she worked at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing my clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform at the zoo. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is a calm place, but here I was rushing around when I could be quietly cuddling an animal. Some people on the fashion team seemed stressed, but my job at the zoo is not very stressful. During a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I find it interesting to see how magazines work, but I really love my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in my leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to wear, which was good because I got very dirty. While I was petting an elephant, I thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I retire from fashion, I could see myself working with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She worked with the television gardening show Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team, and Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. I liked being outside because I sometimes don’t see daylight at work. Even though it was hard work, it was fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn’t expect gardening to be so hard or need so much planning. I enjoy gardening, but I don’t plan to quit my nursing job."
Charlie Dimmock is a landscape gardener on Ground Force. He worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out medicine. I thought I would faint during some tasks, but I surprised myself and felt fine. The nurses are very friendly, and it felt very different from my usual job with men. I think my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not easy, but it made me feel good."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and when I put it on, I felt different—people looked at me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and what to do if someone has a heart attack, which I knew from my training. When the passengers boarded the flight to Paris, I handed out magazines. Everyone stared at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren on board who wouldn’t sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one sensible adult."
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don’t exercise. I was surprised by how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. At lunch, I was surprised to see that some trainers didn’t eat very healthily, but they all drink a lot of water. I wouldn’t change my job for this, but it has inspired me to join a gym and try to be healthier."

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**
**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I fell in love with the south of France a long time ago and try to visit as often as I can. There is a local train from Cannes that goes along the coast and crosses the border into Italy. It takes you past beautiful sea views. No matter the weather or the time of year, the journey is always magical. Out of the other window, you can see some of the best gardens and homes in France. It feels like you are looking into the lives of rich and famous people. The passengers are always lively because there is a mix of tourists and locals, all enjoying the amazing trip.
**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have had many great train journeys, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express, which travels across the desert in northern Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip from Cape Town to Kruger National Park because I was considered too young and troublesome. I was sent to stay with my aunt. When I moved to England as a teenager, I still hadn’t traveled by train. London Waterloo was the first real train station I ever saw, and its big glass roof amazed me.
**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
I am very thankful for one train in particular: the Blue Train. It took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said that pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey was lovely as we traveled through France and then by boat up the Nile. It was the perfect way to relax after all the wedding planning.
**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
We were writing articles about a trip around the world and needed to cross a desert in Africa. There were no roads, so we had to take the Desert Express. The schedule was not reliable; we were just told to be ready on a certain day. We heard that the driver would wait for days if people were still coming. When the train arrived, many people rushed to get on, and some even traveled on the roof for free. At night, the train went through some of the most beautiful landscapes I have ever seen. It felt like a dream, like traveling on the moon.
**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
Most people have favorite memories of trains from when they were children, but that’s not true for me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus, where I saw very few trains. It wasn’t until I was a teenager that trains became important in my life. I made a film that featured a railway in Yorkshire. Most of the filming was on an old train line that volunteers had taken care of. That’s when my love for steam trains began. When we weren’t filming, we took every chance to ride the train, and when I returned last year, it felt like time had stopped. Everything was still the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!

'Want to Get Published?**
If you want to publish your story, our expert Margaret Stubbs has some helpful advice. Many readers of this magazine ask, "I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?" 
First, you need to research where to send your work. This means learning about different publishers and improving your writing skills. To sell your writing, you need to understand the publishing world. No matter what you write, you should know the markets you want to reach. 
One of the best ways to learn about these markets is to read a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading different materials will help you understand what kinds of writing publishers are looking for. Remember, this information changes often because new magazines and books come out all the time. 
If you are unsure about what to write, let’s say you want to write short love stories. First, find out which magazines publish love stories. This market is quite small now, so get recent copies of those magazines. Look at the types of stories they buy and who their readers are. Readers have different expectations, and editors want to meet those needs.
Sometimes, new writers send me their stories and say, "This has been rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?" As a former teacher, I don’t want to discourage anyone, but it is likely that their work is not ready for publishing. Many new writers are too quick to send out their work before it is good enough. If you have only written one story or article, it is very unlikely to be published. 
When you hear about someone’s success, they usually have been writing for years before they got published. When you send your work for the first time, keep writing more stories while you wait for a reply. Write ten more stories, or even twenty. Each one will be better than the last, and you will start to see yourself as a writer. This will help you become more confident and fluent in your writing. 
Don’t throw away any of your stories; instead, try to improve them. Also, I suggest not showing your work to others in the beginning. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections before they succeeded. 
Do everything you can to grow as a writer. Look for a creative writing course near you, or join a local writers' group. This will help you gain ideas and confidence by meeting other writers. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

**No Title**
On the last day of a bad year, I was waiting at the Baltimore train station for the 10:10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people there than I expected. The station didn’t feel as nice as usual. Older couples with matching bags filled the benches, and many college students had left their bags on the floor. A grey-haired man was walking around, talking to different people. He looked well-off with his tanned skin and nice clothes. 
He approached a woman sitting alone and asked her if she was going to Philadelphia. She said she was going north, but to New York. He thanked her and moved on. I was interested in what he was doing. He then asked an old lady if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to Wilmington. He kept walking to a couple with matching luggage. 
I moved closer, thinking he could have asked me too. I understood why he didn’t; he probably thought I looked unreliable. He quickly glanced at me and then went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked stressed now. 
“Please!” he said to a woman reading a book. “Tell me you’re going to Philadelphia!” She looked up from her book. She was in her thirties, maybe thirty-five. “Philadelphia?” she said. “Yes, I am.” 
“Could I ask you a favor?” I stood a few feet away, pretending to check my wrist, even though I didn’t have a watch. I could tell the woman was becoming cautious. The man noticed too and said, “Nothing too difficult, I promise!” 
They announced my train, and people started moving toward Gate E, pulling their bags behind them. The man began to explain, “My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, went shopping, and came home to find my wife upset. She hardly said ‘hello’ to me. My daughter forgot her passport and called from the station in Philadelphia. She didn’t know what to do.” 
The woman listened sympathetically. I would have stayed quiet to see where this was going. “I told her to stay at the station, and I would get someone to bring her passport.” 
I thought it was strange. If it was such an emergency, why didn’t he go himself? The woman asked him, “Why don’t you go yourself?” He replied, “I can’t leave my wife alone for that long. She’s in a wheelchair.” I thought this was a weak excuse. 
I looked at them again. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a plain one, which would have made more sense. A padded envelope hides what’s inside! From where I stood, it looked stapled shut too. I thought silently, “Be careful, lady.”

**Gary and Me**
John Moore, the owner of a restaurant, talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. His chance was to run a restaurant, and Gary's chance was to cook. When John found out about a restaurant for sale, he quickly went to see it. The place was in bad condition, but it was perfect for his plans.
Running the restaurant reminded John of his childhood. He remembered how his mother worked in a factory, and he felt sad when he was left alone. Because of this, he wanted to have time for family. John's wife took care of their children and managed the finances while he ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always made time to eat together as a family. This helped their children, Gary and Joe, become confident. From a young age, they would talk to the regular customers, which gave them a good start in life.
Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a corner bath like it was a swimming pool and hurt himself. As he grew older, he had to earn pocket money. He started with small jobs and by age ten, he was working in the kitchen every weekend, which gave him plenty of money at school. He was very disciplined and often woke up before his father. In a family business, everyone helps out, and John liked seeing Gary work.
Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as skilled as the adult chefs and sometimes even managed the kitchen. He could cook over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would work in catering because he had talent. When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend’s restaurant.
Recently, Gary started playing the drums and formed his own band. John wonders what will happen to Gary's cooking if his music career takes off. He advised Gary to focus on one thing at a time to be successful. John told him, "If you want to achieve something in life, you need to do it by the age of 30. After that, it’s harder."
At 17, Gary went to catering college. On his first day, while other students were just starting, Gary quickly chopped vegetables and sliced meats. He finished his work in an hour and even helped others. Everyone is amazed at how successful Gary's TV cooking show has become, and John is very proud of him. He always tells Gary that if you want something, you must work hard for it because nothing is given for free. Gary has seen his chance and taken it.
As parents, we talk to our children as they grow up. If they remember even a little of what we say, we should be happy. John thinks that Gary must have listened sometimes because of the things he says and does.

**Finding a Flat in Dublin**
Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way to find one is through personal contacts. If you know someone who knows someone leaving a flat, that can help. But if, like Jo, you just arrived in Dublin, you don’t have any contacts. So, Jo had to stay in a hostel and look for a flat. For Jo, Dublin felt very new and unknown. She didn’t think about why she was going there. Everyone at her school thought she would leave her small town. They all wanted to escape and see more of life. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, where family helped them settle in. But Jo was going to Dublin alone.
Jo’s mother thought it would be good for her to stay in the hostel. It was run by nuns, so her mother believed she would be safe. Her father hoped the hostel would be warm because hostels are often cold. Jo’s sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy for staying in a hostel for a whole week. But Jo didn’t know they were talking about her while she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, "Own room, own television, share kitchen, bathroom." It was very close to her job at the post office and seemed too good to be true. Jo hoped it would be nice, that they would like her, and that it wouldn’t be too expensive.
There wasn’t a line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The mention of "own television" made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a simple red-brick house with a basement. The flat was upstairs. As Jo climbed the stairs, a cheerful girl with a college scarf came down. "Desperate place," she said. "They’re both awful. Common as dirt."
Jo continued up and met another girl named Nessa. Nessa said, "Did you see that stuck-up girl leaving? I can’t stand her kind." Jo asked what she did. Nessa replied, "She just looked around and acted like it was terrible, speaking in a posh accent. We wouldn’t want her here, would we, Pauline?" 
Pauline, who had colorful clothes and bright hair, was a punk. Jo was surprised because she had seen punks on the street but never talked to one. "I’m Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat," she said. Nessa invited Jo to have tea with them. She brought out three mugs: one with "Nessa," one with "Pauline," and one with "Other." "We’ll put your name on a mug if you come to stay," Nessa said kindly.

**Behind the Dolphin's Smile**
People love dolphins. We enjoy watching them in seaside areas, movies, and TV shows. However, the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says that dolphins are in serious trouble. Mark Simmonds reports on the decline of dolphin populations.
Dolphins are special to us. They are very intelligent, can feel human emotions, and make us dream of freedom in the ocean. Our love for dolphins has grown because of TV shows. First, there was Flipper, and now there is Darwin from Seaquest. But these happy images hide the truth about dolphins living in polluted and overfished seas today.
The number of North Sea harbour porpoises, a type of dolphin, has dropped by up to 89,000. You might think that such popular animals would be protected by laws and cared for in special marine areas. Unfortunately, this is not true, and the lack of protection could lead to a major wildlife disaster.
There are forty different types of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common dolphins are the striped dolphin, the common dolphin, the bottlenose dolphin, and the smaller harbour porpoise. The striped and common dolphins usually live far out in the open sea and are seen in small groups. We know very little about them. 
Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be seen often near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found along the Channel coast and in rivers in Britain, like the Thames. Now, they can only be found in a few places, like the Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few that are left show signs of stress, like skin injuries.
It is hard to know exactly why dolphin numbers are decreasing. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces the number of fish in the ocean, which also affects dolphins and porpoises. Porpoises need to find food quickly, and if fish are taken from one area, they may not have enough time to find food elsewhere. They can also get caught in fishermen's nets, which they cannot see. 
In modern fishing, large nets are often left in the water or pulled quickly through the sea. In recent years, many dead dolphins have washed up on the beaches of France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on their bodies show that they died because they were caught in these nets.
Dolphins can also store harmful substances in their bodies. For example, pesticides can build up in dolphins because they are fat-soluble. This means that when female dolphins produce milk, it can contain high levels of these poisons, which can harm their young. There is already one case of a young dolphin dying from its mother’s poisoned milk.
Another serious threat to dolphins is noise pollution caused by humans. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their environment. In the ocean, noise travels much better than in the air. This noise from ships and oil wells may disturb dolphins in ways we do not fully understand.

**GETTING FIT**
Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you feel balanced, especially when life feels chaotic. You might be tired of reading about fitness, but there are many good reasons to exercise, and very few reasons not to.
Exercise helps improve your muscles and can change your body shape quickly. It makes your muscles stronger and helps you stand and sit better. It can also prevent injuries by fixing muscle imbalances. Exercise can quickly improve areas like your thighs, stomach, and arms. It is good for your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.
You may have heard many reasons to exercise before, but here’s something new: exercise can help reduce feelings of depression and tiredness, and it can help you sleep better. It also helps manage stress and can relieve some health problems. 
If you still need convincing, just remember that exercise is good for you. There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or using weights. However, be careful not to push yourself too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. If you are unsure about what is best for you, talk to your doctor.
Good posture is very important. If you don’t have good posture, exercise won’t help you change your body shape. Good posture makes you look and feel better. If you tend to slouch, think of a balloon pulling the top of your head up. This can help you stand taller and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.
Stretching is also important. It helps you move easily and keeps your posture correct. Stretching can prevent injuries from overuse. If you stretch four or five times a week, you will become more flexible and fit. 
A good exercise routine should include a warm-up, stretching, a workout, and a cool-down period.

**IN THEIR NATURAL HABITAT**
What makes film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman stay away from home for many months? They are looking for the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it can be very hard to find them. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater, which has had six months of almost non-stop rain. This has caused many problems. Newman said they had to buy an expensive piece of equipment so that if one of their vehicles gets stuck in the mud, Amanda can pull him back to safety. Together, they have made some of the best wildlife films on TV, including a popular film about leopards. While that film was being shown, they were already back in the field, this time following the shy jackal.
Traveling film-makers have been moving around the world to film exotic wildlife since television started. I talked to Newman while he was having a rare meeting with other people at a safari lodge. He said, "We do have some arguments, but we get over them quickly." Neither of them thinks of themselves as the leader. They get along well because they both see the animals in a similar way. 
When they travel, they usually set up their tents each night. But now, they are working from a fixed camp. They wake up at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before to keep it warm. Their meals are pre-packed and heated by whoever is available. Newman said, "We can be out for up to eight weeks, so cooking can be a bit stressful." 
It can be tough living in remote areas, but it allows them to get close to the animals. Newman remembers filming a family of lions. One lioness would often go off alone, but when she returned, she would greet all the other lions, and eventually, she would greet their car too.
Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called "The Great Rift." Two years later, they began working together to film Arctic foxes. Since then, they have learned to spend four months in one location to gather enough material for each half-hour film. Before they can start filming, they must submit a script for approval. 
Newman said, "Amanda and I had a good working relationship from the start because we shared the same ideas and vision. We want to make a film that shows the true spirit of the place and the animals, and that touches people's hearts. I believe if you can make people feel something, that is better than just making them think."

**The Netball Captain**
In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of the England netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised to hear about her training place. I asked her, "Don't you get strange looks?" She replied, "I focus so much on my movements and my feet that I don’t notice anything else. I might see cars slow down a little, but that’s all."
Kendra said, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict schedule to be very fit for the games. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest one yet, with 27 countries participating. "We will have home support, which is very special," she said. "It is important to improve the reputation of netball in this country. Playing at home means there will be more pressure. The crowd will have expectations and support us. People want us to start the tournament with a good game."
Their first match is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. Kendra believes they have always won against them, but it will still be exciting to play because Barbados has talented players. The England team is currently ranked fourth in the world. However, Kendra knows the World Championships will be tough. "You have to push yourself to play every day. There is no rest between games like in a series. You can still win a series if you lose the first game, but in the Championships, you only have one chance, and you must be ready."
In the fifteen years Kendra has played at a high level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive now. "You don’t train hard to lose," Kendra says. But after the game, everyone is friendly. 
Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. "It is important that we all think and train like world-class players," Kendra explains. As captain, she believes it is important to have a strong mindset and to lead by example. "I see my role as supporting and encouraging the team."
Kendra has planned her netball career carefully. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She will likely coach young players in the future, but right now, she is focused on her final big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have tears in her eyes. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

**In Hot Water**
Rachel Mills is a scientist who spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She teaches and researches marine geochemistry, which means she studies the chemicals in the sea. Rachel works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, about the size of a car, and dives three kilometers down into the ocean to study underwater volcanoes.
Inside the vehicle, Rachel says, "There is very little space. I can touch the two pilots. We cannot stand up or move around, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours: three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up."
"If there is a problem and we need to get to the surface quickly, we can press a panic button. This makes a small escape vessel come out, and it goes up to the surface very fast. No one has tested it yet, but I think it would not be a nice trip."
Rachel remembers her first time in the vehicle. It was on a ship, and she got in with an instructor. He explained what to do in an emergency, even if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in such a small space.
Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian team. "We went to a place that was a five-day sail west of the Canary Islands. There, on the ocean floor, are many underwater volcanoes that blow out black smoke. This is where the Atlantic Ocean is very active. The Russian team was leaving some scientific equipment to study a project that would create a hole 150 meters through a volcano."
When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the Oceanography Centre in Southampton. "Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I enjoy, but I do it so I can continue my research on the 'black smokers.' This is another name for underwater volcanoes, where hot water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at a speed of one meter per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees."
"The only time I was scared was when I first dived with an American team. We were towing equipment when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a huge bang, and I thought, 'I'm going to die.' We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we were so relieved - we were still alive!"
"Diving to the deepest part of the ocean is an adventure. Every time I look out of the window and see the chimneys, I feel amazed. I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I finally saw them in real life, it was an incredible feeling."

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. Studies show that people make judgments about us within the first few minutes of meeting. They notice how we dress, our eye contact, our body language, how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we use.
Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She worked hard to earn her degree and felt confident when she graduated. She applied for a job at a nearby primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. On the day of the interview, she saw a small hole in her jacket. She thought about changing, but she didn’t want to be late because she believes it is important to be on time. Unfortunately, Mary did not get the job. A friend who works at the school told her that the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn’t take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says that people who care about their appearance are more likely to care about their jobs. Many people think that what is inside matters most, but in an interview, you should try to present yourself in the best way possible.
Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an administrative assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but did not get an interview. She thought it was a mistake and asked the Director of Personnel what happened. He told her that she did not fit the image of an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was shocked because she believed her work was good and that her clothes should not matter.
Movement and gestures also affect how an interviewer sees a candidate. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that only 7% of our message comes from the words we use, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our words and facial expressions send different messages, the listener will pay more attention to the non-verbal message. So, it is important that your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion and had a great interview. She was offered the job right away. However, she was too excited and showed too much enthusiasm. The boss realized she would not turn down the offer, so he gave her a lower salary than she wanted. She believes she could have negotiated for a better salary if she had controlled her excitement.
Finally, what we say and how we say it can help us succeed in an interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. For example, reading the annual report can help you understand the company better. Mentioning something that interests you during the interview can show your interest in the company.
Business consultant Marian Woodall advises having a few questions ready and avoiding long, confusing sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and key points."

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring. No one was having fun anymore. I didn’t plan to leave my job yet, but then I lost it unexpectedly. I didn’t get a lot of money when I left, but it was enough to start my farm. My big chance came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, about 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He says, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to leave my job and become an artist. A career counselor helped me a lot. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we didn’t need to worry about money. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. It was hard to leave our friends, but we are lucky that they still visit us."
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot, but the hours were very long. I didn’t want to become a senior partner and work even more, so I left. Many people thought I would get bored, but I never did. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always new collections and designs to work on, so I stay busy. I feel happier now and less stressed. However, I miss talking to colleagues. What I love about my job is that I am fully responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when it’s your name on the product, you care even more."
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I worked in finance since I was 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I didn’t find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year instead. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I used to feel out of control, but now I have peace of mind and control over my life. That is the best part."

**Dedicated to Their Sports**
Four young sports stars talk about their lives.
**A Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and athletics. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose to focus on athletics instead. My biggest moment was when I competed for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Unfortunately, it did not get much media attention, which was disappointing. I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home all winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there because the facilities are great and the nightlife is exciting. However, I have to be very disciplined. If my friends invite me out the night before training, I have to say no. I wish I could go, but being dedicated is important in this sport. My main goal is to reach the next Olympics - that would be amazing.
**B Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so I meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn. To succeed, I have to avoid late-night parties. I don’t mind this too much, but I love sleeping in, which I often have to give up. However, it is worth it because my dedication helped me win the National Championships last year. After a win, I always celebrate with a big night out, and if I win money, I treat myself to a nice trip. The sacrifices are worth it because winning the championship allowed me to present a surfing series on TV. Now, I guess I am a bit of a celebrity.
**C Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When I am on a boat with my friends, we have a lot of fun. We are traditional and always celebrate our wins in style. Some people say we act a bit childish, but we do not seek media attention. Sometimes, reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so it is nice to come back and spend time with my friends who do different things. You cannot focus on the sport all the time; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but I am rarely recognized in public. I would not like to be a celebrity. I do get nice letters from fans asking for signed pictures, and I reply to every one, even if it takes time.
**D Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It feels great to walk onto the court and feel the crowd's support. At my last tournament, it got a bit crazy with fans crowding around. I enjoy being recognized by fans when I am out shopping, but it has its downsides. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got too much attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you have to make sacrifices in sports; you need to be serious and professional. I try not to let it bother me too much. I want to focus on my game now and enjoy other things in life after I retire, which comes early in this sport.

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and if I give in to their requests, I feel guilty about buying unhealthy food. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry that they are missing out on learning how to make their own choices. I just can’t win."
Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things. Arguments about how bad sugar is for teeth are not convincing when compared to the fun and emotional ads they see.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb points out, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests. "My son pays attention to ads, but he is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent in their responses to their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands could attract more customers.

**Five-Star Luxury with Modern Technology**
The new five-star Merrion Hotel has just opened in Dublin. It was created by changing four large old houses into a hotel. This allowed the hotel to use the latest technology for both staff and guests.
General Manager Peter MacCann wants his staff to know the guests by name. For more details about what guests like, he uses the hotel’s computer system. This system helps the hotel give special service to returning guests. Although it cost £250,000 to set up, MacCann believes it will save money in the long run. He is very happy with how well it works. For example, if a guest asks for certain music CDs during their first stay, those same CDs will be ready for them when they come back. This is possible because the staff can save guests' preferences in the system.
Many hotel guests often complain about room temperature. The Merrion Hotel has a high-tech system that lets guests control the temperature in their rooms. They can change it by three degrees around the normal temperature of 18°C. If they want, the front desk can adjust the temperature anywhere between 14°C and 25°C.
Business guests will find the technology in their rooms very useful. MacCann thinks that about 65% of the hotel’s business will come from this group. To meet their needs, the hotel has put a business center in each room. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine that also works as a photocopier and printer, and a video-conferencing system.
Technology changes quickly, so the hotel has prepared for future improvements. They have added extra cables for new technology. The televisions are rented, so they can be replaced with newer models whenever needed. DVD recorders can also be updated.
Even with all this modern technology, MacCann wants guests to feel comfortable, not overwhelmed. The hotel has 145 large and well-furnished bedrooms that are cozy and welcoming. There is also a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden.
The food at the hotel is very important. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, has moved his restaurant to the Merrion. This move has many benefits for both him and the hotel. He has designed a new kitchen and improved parking. The hotel can now offer a great place to eat without financial risks. With good technology and a skilled staff, the Merrion Hotel is likely to be very successful.

**Where I Get My Energy**
Emma Marsden asked six women who live life fully how they find their energy.
A. **Jeanette Kupfermann, Journalist and Author:** "I get my energy from excitement. I need to do things that challenge me. When I learn something new, I feel very energized. I also love rhythm; right now, I am learning flamenco dancing. Dance is amazing and gives me energy. If I am bored, I feel tired and think life is not worth it. Doing something meaningful, even in a small way, gives me energy."
B. **Linda Kelsey, Magazine Editor:** "I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love being at work, so it doesn’t feel like a burden. If you enjoy what you do, you don’t feel sad, even if you are tired. I need enough sleep, and when I get it, I feel great. If I only sleep six hours, I feel a bit tired. I know exercise gives me energy, but sometimes it’s hard to find the energy to do it! I go to a yoga class once a week and try to exercise at home. After I exercise, I feel much better. I often feel low in the afternoon, so I think it’s good to eat something then."
C. **Annie Nightingale, Disc Jockey:** "I don’t eat very healthily for energy; I think it comes from being enthusiastic and positive. I don’t like negative people. I believe we should enjoy our lives and have fun. It’s important to achieve things and set goals. I love my job, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with many lively young people, which energizes me. I enjoy taking photos, even if I’m not great at it. I also write lyrics for fun, which helps me relax when I travel a lot."
D. **Floella Benjamin, Author and Children's TV Presenter:** "My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in what I do, both at work and at home with my family. Being positive helps a lot. I love working with kids because they are full of energy. Energy is like a natural feeling that comes from talking to others. Just smile at someone and see how good it feels when they smile back. It’s much better than feeling sorry for yourself. I try to eat healthily and don’t smoke or drink, but I don’t have a strict exercise plan. I get my energy from playing with kids."
E. **Deborah Moggach, Author and Playwright:** "What I love most is creating a garden from a wasteland. I once turned a concrete area into a beautiful garden. It was better than any workout. Knowing that someone wants to read my writing gives me energy too. I also enjoy sneaking into a farmer's land or a forest. If someone catches me, I say, 'Oh, what a lovely place! I didn’t know it was private.' I like this because it feels playful."
F. **Katherine Monblot, Therapist:** "I believe you should care about what you do in life. I like to take risks and get bored easily, which keeps me motivated. Doing things you don’t want to do can make you tired. I used to be part of many committees, but I didn’t like how they took my time. You only have a certain amount of energy, so use it for what matters most to you."

**ICE SKATING**
Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Archaeologists have found skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until iron skates were made in Scandinavia around 200 AD. For the rich people in Scandinavia, skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was seen as elegant, but in the 1924 Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie showed a more athletic way of skating. This made skating very popular. 
Today, skating combines art and athleticism, making it both beautiful and challenging. For beginners, balance and control are very important, and you can only go faster as you get better. The way you position your body helps with balance. Your legs should be slightly bent, and your knees should be relaxed. This helps keep your weight centered and your body leaning slightly forward. 
Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. When you push forward with one foot, make a small movement with the other foot. It’s not too hard! If you practice this for a while, you can slowly make bigger movements as you improve. 
Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should know. Even professional skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up. 
Once you feel confident on the ice, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance skating, speed skating, and pair skating. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have instructors who can help you learn the basic moves, turns, jumps, and spins of freestyle skating.
If you watch good skaters, you will see how relaxed and smooth they are. To skate well, you should practice exercises regularly. It can be dangerous to skate if your body is stiff, so warm-up exercises are important. These should focus on your legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.
Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It also helps your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. When combined with swimming or jogging, skating is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Bills**
Seeing a talented child win a medal can bring tears of joy. Julia Gregson spoke to three young stars and their mothers about the good and bad parts of their lives.
A. **Annika Reeder**, 15, won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "Right now, the training is very hard. I don’t have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gymnastics and school. I take it one day at a time. When I feel really tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can’t take too many days off because it makes your body stiff."
B. **Annika's mother** says, "From a young age, Annika showed great talent. I’ve seen other parents push their kids, but it doesn’t work. To perform at Annika’s level takes a lot of time and energy, so you have to want to do it. People often say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don’t see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and gained confidence."
C. **Sarah Stokes** started show-jumping at age 10 and has won the British National Championship. "It’s great that my parents like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows can last from one to five days. I never get tired of it; I love it! Even if my parents weren’t there, I would still do it because I am very determined. I’m happy when they are proud of my wins, but I do it for myself. This year, I want to qualify for the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."
D. **Sarah's mother** says, "From the moment Sarah sat on a horse at age 1, I knew she loved it. When she was 5, she would wake up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, we travel all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is very organized. She is happiest on a horse and knows what to do. Watching your child succeed at something they love is amazing."
E. **Jane McShane**, 10, is the Under-14 Chess Champion in Britain. "Tournaments are really friendly. I know everyone, and it’s fun. When I play, I don’t concentrate as much as I should. I just look around and don’t think too much. I’m not worried about being proud; I don’t talk about my success at school because I don’t like to feel embarrassed."
F. **Jane's mother** says, "Jane played her first game when she was 5. My father wanted to see if she liked it. He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it right away. By the end of that day, she had memorized all the moves, and by age 6, she was beating adults. I’m happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop playing tomorrow, I would support her. I don’t want to hold her back because she is so talented. If she has this gift, I want her to reach her full potential."

It's true - we are all getting taller. Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his careers teacher he wanted to join the navy after school. The teacher asked, "What do you want to be? The flagpole on a ship?" This was funny because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, at 228 cm, he is the tallest man in Britain. 
Every ten years, the average height of people in Europe increases by one centimeter. More tall people are being born each year. However, this does not mean we are becoming a super race. Instead, we are returning to how we were as cavemen. We are starting to lose the effects of many years of poor diet, which is having a big impact. Professor Chris Stringer, a palaeontologist, says, "We are beginning to reach our true potential. We are becoming like Cro-Magnons, the people who lived 40,000 years ago."
For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Many natural areas were taken over by farms, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 
Over the years, we have mostly eaten soups, porridges, and breads, which have left us underfed. In one study in Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Corn, which was thought to be good, actually caused health problems. 
Despite this, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting could. Many people who rely on farming are still not well-nourished. Only recently have wealthier countries started to improve their diets. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like those of our ancestors. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its own problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Also, legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products often. The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University thinks it could be around 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. 
However, scientists say that while some people are getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might get even smaller. In other words, our growth could be affected by global warming.

**Studio Audiences**
What is it like to be in the audience when a television show is being made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of television, but many people do not understand them. When we watch game shows, we see the audience getting excited and wonder, "Who are these people?"
Some people think that studio audiences are not very important. I have heard that even people who work in television do not think highly of them. One cameraman even said they are treated "like cattle." I used to think that studio audiences were made up of silly people who wanted a moment of fame. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from different backgrounds, jobs, and income levels. Television shows try to attract different types of people for different programs.
Many of us who watch television at home do not understand why anyone would want to be in a studio audience. Why would someone apply for tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio just to watch what they can see at home? One reason is that people hope to be on television for a moment. I did not believe this until I spoke to Angela, who said she came for a chance to appear on TV. Another reason is that people are curious to see how a show is made. But the most common reason I heard was, "A friend gave me a ticket."
Most of us have never been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it is like. You sit close to strangers while someone holds up signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you do what the signs say. This is true for some shows, but not all. As one studio manager said, "We always assume a show will be good enough not to need these signs."
Is there a real difference between being in a studio and watching at home? For Claire, being in a studio is "more exciting," while Charlotte liked being part of live television. She said, "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. When you watch him at home, you miss a lot." What I missed was seeing the live actors. I could only see the back of someone’s head. The opening scenes were so far away that I ended up watching the show on a monitor.
Going to a studio may not be the best way to watch television, but that is not what matters. For most people in the audience, it was just fun and a free night of entertainment.

**Favorite Places**
**Bruce**  
I don’t like wild landscapes that have no human touch. I prefer places with people. When I travel, I enjoy lovely villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I would ride my bike to the village of Lastingham in its beautiful valley. Cycling helped me relax from school. I loved exploring the hills, valleys, and old villages. Coming from Scotland, I found the landscape both familiar and different, and I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in my diary. This was my first try at travel writing, which later became my career.
**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by volunteers. I always travel first class because it doesn’t cost much more than regular tickets. The views are not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the journey I always look forward to - when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we see people doing everyday things, like making tea or folding a chair. I see myself in their eyes, a woman in a tiny train carriage, looking into their homes. I like the simple landscape of fields, sheep, and a distant grey sea. It makes me look more closely and find something new.
**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a quiet and beautiful coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so there are not many people here. A few brave surfers come, but most visitors enjoy the beauty of the sea. This coast, facing the Atlantic, is known for shipwrecks. There are walking paths along the coast that you can combine with trips into the beautiful valleys filled with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in a simple self-catering place with a family in the village of Southole.
**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland that is great for hiking. There are not many people living or visiting there. It is a quiet and remote area, and I love the feeling of space. I found this place by chance when I was a student, and I visit every year, either alone, with my boyfriend, or now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits more special. I feel sad that he is growing up in a city.
**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. It was about finding peace and reconnecting with my English roots. I grew up in what is now Sri Lanka, but when I was twelve, I went to school in Devon, in the west of England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. There was a story about a place we would never cycle past: if you went down the driveway, you would never return. That place was Glenthorne. It is my dream place. It is a magical, quiet, and romantic house. You can only hear the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**
We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work to tell me she found a beautiful pine snake. "Can we keep him?" she asked excitedly. I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We had a special tank ready for animals like this, so we could admire it and look it up in our natural history book.
I got home late and quickly put a pot on the stove. Suddenly, I heard my sons screaming, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their bedroom. The problem was with Domino, our cat, and Bianca, the white mouse I got for Mother's Day. Domino had the mouse in his mouth and was running around the room, trying to escape with his catch. 
I jumped into the chaos and tripped over something, falling to the floor. While I was thinking about how to stop Domino, I noticed the snake. It had escaped and was slithering off the table and onto the floor. I crouched down as the snake moved closer, while the kids and the cat were jumping around, making a lot of noise. The dog was barking too. 
In the kitchen, the pot boiled over, so I quickly turned off the gas and went back to help. I managed to grab Domino by the tail and pulled the small, wet mouse from his mouth. Surprisingly, the mouse was okay. Domino caught the same mouse three more times in its life, but it eventually died of old age.
Feeling good about saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It seemed strong and I knew it would be hard to catch. I sat on the floor, trying to calm the snake down. Slowly, it relaxed and rested its head on its body, but it still looked suspicious. I carefully lifted the snake and stood up. I walked to the end of the garden and pointed it towards a tree, hoping it would go there.
When I finally let go of the snake's head, I expected it to bite me, but instead, it slid over my shoulders like a colorful scarf. We stood there in the evening light, with my four children, me, and the snake. My oldest son, DJ, broke the silence and said, "Mum, you are nice and warm, and the shed isn’t."
I asked the kids to help me encourage the snake to move on. Slowly, it did. Without looking back, it climbed up the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last bit of its tail vanished, my three-year-old son Clay sighed and said, "Wow, that was one big snake!"

**Drop Me a Line!**
In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, the old way of writing letters is at risk of disappearing. However, I believe that receiving a letter is special and cannot be replaced by any other way of communicating. There is excitement when a letter arrives, joy in seeing who it is from, and happiness in reading what it says.
I have been writing letters for as long as I can remember. It probably started with the little notes I wrote to my mother. She always made sure I wrote my own thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn’t matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.
When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote to my parents every week, and they wrote back to me. Sometimes my father wrote long, funny letters, which I loved. Most of the letters from home talked about everyday life with my parents and their friends. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters the most.
I also received letters from my boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we kept in touch by writing. Writing letters actually helped our relationships. I found it easier to express my feelings in writing than by talking.
I enjoy letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Short notes are nice, but it’s even better to get a whole year’s worth of news! I love receiving letters in airmail envelopes with beautiful stamps. I get letters from friends in different countries, like Mangala in Sri Lanka, a penfriend in Australia, and another in Vancouver. There is also a lady from France who writes to me. We started talking in a restaurant after a holiday, and I asked for her address. If she hadn’t replied, we would have missed out on a great friendship. Now, we write to each other regularly. I can practice my French with her since she doesn’t speak English. We have visited each other’s homes.
My biggest success in letter writing happened this summer when my family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but had never met. Everyone was surprised that our friendship lasted so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it!
I am happy that my children are continuing this tradition. Like my mother, I make sure they write their own thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did for my mother. She and my son have their own penfriends in Texas, organized by my penfriend. I strongly encourage everyone not to let letter writing become a lost art.

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**
Many ancient pictures carved into the rocks at a famous tourist site in France are being slowly destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged so quickly that they may not last for future generations. The mountain is believed to have been a place for prayer and worship, and it has drawings that are 4,000 years old. These include pictures of cows, fields, and different gods and goddesses. However, as more people visit the site, the pictures are being ruined by careless graffiti.
Jean Clottes, the chairman of the International Committee on Rock Art, says, "People think that because the pictures have been there for so long, they will always be there. But if the damage continues like this, there will be nothing left in 50 years." He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings, which wears away the rock and damages the artwork. Some visitors even take pieces of the rock home as souvenirs. He explains that when people cannot take a good photograph, they rub the drawings to make them clearer. The drawings are already polished by the weather, and if the sun is shining and the visitors cannot see them well, they rub and scrape them to make them look newer.
Other researchers have noticed that some people come with long sticks to scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts disagree on the best way to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, the director of the Museum of Natural History in Paris, believes the only way to save the site is to make the whole mountain a "no-go" area, allowing the public to visit only on guided tours. He says that if this does not happen, the site will be completely destroyed, and important research will be lost.
Clottes disagrees with this idea. He says, "Henry de Lumley's plan is very strict, and while it may work, it will also upset local people." He reminds us that the site was declared a historic monument by the Ministry of Culture, and we must do everything we can to protect it.
David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says, "Henry de Lumley's idea is not perfect. Our department believes that people should be able to see the site, but it is hard to stop visitors from causing damage because the area is so large. I would like everyone to visit, but the main problem is money. We do not have enough funds to hire enough guards. We may need to think about charging a fee since there is no chance of getting government funding."
In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who has also studied the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach—since tourists can now avoid a long walk by hiring vehicles—the damage will increase quickly. She believes the only solution is to block off the area and provide guides. "You can't say the plan can't happen because there is no money," she says. "That is not good enough. Money must be provided because the Ministry of Culture has classified this area as a historic site. If we do not take action, we will be responsible for losing the drawings for the next generation."

**Young Shoppers**
Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "It feels like a battle. They want everything they see. If it’s not the newest sugary cereal, it’s a Disney video or a comic book. Usually, they want all three. I can’t afford all this, and when I give in, I feel guilty for buying them unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get stressed before we even leave the house. I try to avoid taking them shopping, but then I worry they are missing out on learning how to make choices. I just can’t win."
Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes when they go shopping. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising aimed at children, mostly on TV. This amount is likely to grow, and supermarkets are a big part of this advertising. Children often do not understand why their parents say they cannot buy certain things. Arguments about how bad sugar is for their teeth do not work well against the fun and persuasive ads they see.
Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always correct. It is good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only hear about products from TV ads, they get a very one-sided view. Parents feel frustrated because they have to compete with advertising and often disappoint their children."
The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb explains, "The goal of advertising is to convince people to buy products. So even if they can’t say, 'Tell your mom to buy this,' that is still the effect."
Shopping with children can be stressful for parents because they have to decide which requests to agree to and which to refuse. One mother says she tries to be patient when talking about food with her children, but she still feels unhappy about how she handles their requests. "My son pays attention to ads, but he is critical of them. We talk a lot about different products and look at labels together. I’ve talked about it so much that he thinks all ads are bad. Now, we have very little conflict in the supermarket because the children don’t ask for things I don’t want to buy."
Parents also admit they are not always consistent with their children’s requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We refuse to buy sweets for him because we say they are bad for him, but we buy double cream and chocolate for ourselves. It’s nice to buy good things, and it’s normal for children to want to share that. But I still get annoyed by their requests. It depends on how I feel. If I’m in a good mood, I’m more likely to say yes. It’s hard to be consistent."
Supermarkets could help reduce the conflict between parents and children by removing sweets from checkout areas or providing supervised play areas. Even if parents spend less money because their children are not with them, the idea of shopping without their children’s demands might attract more customers.

**Going Up the Wall**
In the past, climbers went to the mountains to climb. Now, people can climb in many places, both indoors and outdoors. A crowd watches in excitement as the French climber Francois Lombard hangs upside down by two fingers on a climbing wall. He is competing in the World Cup Climbing Championships at the National Indoor Arena in Birmingham. This arena is better known for the TV show Gladiators, but both events have one thing in common - The Wall. This is possible because of new technology that is developing quickly.
Before the mid-1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs where there were good climbing spots. In winter, they had to deal with cold weather, go for walks, or climb on snow and ice in Scotland. As the sport grew, it became important for climbers to stay fit. Since they could not use cliffs for much of the year, they started to climb on brick edges or stone buildings. This helped them keep their fingers strong and avoid getting bored.
Soon, many sports centers built climbing walls using special bricks. One of the first climbing walls was made by Don Robinson, a physical education teacher, in a corridor at Leeds University in the mid-1960s. He created a wall with natural rock set in concrete. Many climbing walls like this were built in sports halls across the country in the 1970s, but they had some problems. These walls could only be straight up and down, while real cliffs have different shapes like overhangs and slanted rocks. Once the walls were built, they could not be changed, and climbers would get tired of the same routes.
In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny created a new material that could be shaped like the rocks on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any wall and removed when climbers wanted something new. French companies also started to make climbing walls with steel frames. Concrete was too heavy for making overhanging walls without a lot of work, but steel frames could be built anywhere. This system allowed climbers to have many different holds to choose from.

**So You Want to Be an Actor**
If you tell someone that you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is a risky choice. Acting is indeed a risky career because there are many actors but not enough jobs for them. When you decide to become an actor, some of your friends might think you are making a bad choice, while others may support you. Everyone will give you different advice. 
Choosing to be an actor is a personal decision, and you are responsible for your own path and dreams. There are no easy ways to succeed in acting. There are no tests to pass, and even after training, there is no guarantee you will get a job. Success depends on both luck and talent. However, there is always a need for new actors, and acting can bring excitement, glamour, and sometimes good rewards.
Many people want to know what talent is. I think talent is a mix of natural skill and imagination, which is hard to measure. It also involves courage and belief in what you are doing. 
Why do people want to act? It can be hard to explain. In theater, the important moment is when the actor connects with the audience. This connection is what motivates actors to perform. 
When you ask successful actors how they achieved their success, they often don’t have a clear answer. They know some things about their skills and techniques, but they also understand that their success can change quickly. 
Disappointment is a big challenge for actors. Last month, you might have been without work, doing other jobs like selling clothes or waiting tables. Then, you might get a chance to audition for a role. But even if you really want the job, you might not get it. Because of this, actors often avoid talking about their chances of getting a role. They find ways to cope with the stress of competition and the fear of rejection. 
No one likes to be rejected. This possibility is there from the moment you start auditioning. You are saying you are ready, willing, and hopefully talented enough for the job. In many ways, your success depends on how much you care about acting. If you don’t care enough, others may not care about you either.

**Food for Everyone**
We are happy to share our special selection of the best cookbooks available now.
A. When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many places around the world, and she loves exciting food. She also understands what the average cook can do in a normal kitchen. The book that made her famous is "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course." This book is now a must-have for modern cooks. It gives simple but expert advice on basic and advanced cooking, along with hundreds of great recipes that are not boring. The book has been updated and is the perfect answer to the question: "If I could only have one cookbook, which one would it be?"
B. Raymond Blanc went from being an amateur chef to the owner of the most famous French restaurant in Britain in just 15 years. Now, he has a book to go with his first TV series called "Blanc Mange." Raymond wants to help everyone become better cooks by showing how and why certain ingredients work together. He believes that cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. His book has over 80 amazing recipes that show this. It is a practical book that explains why some dishes can go wrong and includes some basic food science. Monsieur Blanc loves to cook for others, and this book shows that he is very good at it.
C. Le Cordon Bleu is a name that represents the best in classical French cooking. For the past 100 years, expert chefs at this famous cooking school have trained students to reach perfection. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have released a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook," which has 100 of the school's best recipes. Although these recipes are classic, they still feel fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has always supported traditional French cooking but has also changed some recipes to make them healthier. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then includes sections on Appetisers, Main Dishes, and Desserts. Each recipe has step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from Cordon Bleu schools around the world have chosen their famous recipes and shared their secrets.
D. Fast food? No way! Many people think that good food takes a long time to cook. But Nigel Slater, the food editor of The Observer, disagrees. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be good. Nigel believes that it is possible to make something tasty in the same time it takes to order a pizza. He has already written two successful books to prove this. In this new book, you will find many delicious recipes, and each one can be ready in just 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way, sharing more than 200 recipes from around the world. Just because he likes fast food doesn’t mean he doesn’t appreciate good food. If you think fast food can’t be great, try his recipes—they are simply delicious!
