For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. One study found they ate from 85 different wild plants. But about 9,000 years ago, farming started, and this changed everything. Many natural areas were taken over by farms, and now just three plants - wheat, rice, and maize - provide more than half of the calories people eat today. This poor diet has harmed human health. 
Over the years, we have mostly eaten soups, porridges, and breads, which have left us underfed. In a study in Ohio, scientists found that when they started to grow corn, healthy hunter-gatherers became sickly farmers. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Some anthropologists say corn was not a good thing for health. 
However, farming spread because one piece of land could feed ten times more people than hunting could. Many people who rely on farming are still poorly nourished. Only recently have wealthier countries started to improve their diets. In Europe, the US, and Japan, diets are becoming more like those of our ancestors. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is a good trend, but it has its own problems. 
Even though people are getting taller, standard bed lengths have stayed at 190 cm since 1860. Also, legroom in planes and trains seems to be getting smaller, and clothing companies have to change their products often. The question is: how tall can we get? We cannot keep growing forever. There must be a limit. Robert Fogel from the University thinks it could be around 193 cm, and we might reach it this century. 
But scientists say that while some people are getting taller because of better nutrition, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, humans were a bit rounder and taller to keep warm. Now that the climate is warmer, we seem to be getting thinner and shorter, even when we eat well. As the planet continues to warm, we might get even smaller. So, the growth of humans could be affected by global warming.

**A NEW LIFE**
**The Farmer**  
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London, but now he runs a sheep farm. He says, "After 14 years in the City, it became boring. No one was having fun anymore. I didn’t plan to leave my job yet, but then I lost it unexpectedly. I didn’t get a lot of money when I left, but it was enough to start my farm. My big chance came when I met the head chef of a well-known hotel. By supplying them with meat, my reputation grew, and now I also sell meat online. I’m happy to be out of the office, but surprisingly, my work hours are still long, about 80 to 90 hours a week, and I’m still selling a product."
**The Painter**  
Ron Able White was a manager in advertising, but now he is an artist. He says, "I started painting as a hobby, but I found it much more exciting than my job. It made sense to leave my job and become an artist. A career counselor helped me a lot. I think I was the first person to tell him, 'I don’t want to go back to my old job.' He was surprised because most people in their forties need to find work quickly for money. My wife and I married young, and our children are grown, so we didn’t need to worry about money. We moved to the north of England, where we didn’t know anyone. We left our friends, but we are lucky that they still visit us."
**The Hat Maker**  
Katherine Goodison worked as a lawyer for five years before starting her own hat-making business in her London flat. She says, "Being a lawyer was fun and I earned a lot, but the hours were very long. I didn’t want to work more and more, so I left. Many people thought I would get bored, but I never did. The key is to have deadlines. In fashion, there are always new collections and designs to work on, so I stay busy. I feel happier now and less stressed, but I miss talking to colleagues. I love being responsible for my work. If I do a bad job, I am the one to blame. When you work for a company, you care, but when it’s your name on the product, you care even more."
**The Masseur**  
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years before becoming a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He says, "I worked in finance since I was 22, making deals. I liked the excitement, but I didn’t find it rewarding. I almost lost my job in 1989, but I left and traveled for a year. During that year, I thought about what I wanted to do. I was interested in health, so I visited top gyms and talked to the owners about how they started. I knew I needed qualifications to change careers, so I took massage courses. Then I got a part-time job at the Life Centre. I have no regrets. I feel in control of my life now, and that is the best part."

**A Winning Game**
Two brothers have found that their childhood game is great for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two bearded brothers in their forties, are at their simple home in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, playing a game called pichenotte. They say this game is special. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, who was a grocer from Quebec, Canada, brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, every weekend and holiday, the family played pichenotte and had a lot of fun. 
Later, the family moved to New Mexico, but they still remembered their grandfather's pichenotte board, which he made from old wooden crates. When visitors came over, they were often curious because the game was unknown in the southern USA. Three years ago, Dave noticed that their old pichenotte board was damaged, so he decided to make a new one. The new board looked great. A relative saw it and wanted one, and then a friend wanted one too. 
To see how popular the game was, the brothers took one of Dave's new boards to a sports bar in Santa Fe. Dave said, "People started to watch and said, 'No way I'm playing that silly game.' But soon, they couldn't get up from the table!" When people asked about the game's history, Dave did some research. He found out that the game likely started in India, where a similar game called 'carroms' is played. This game changed into 'squails' in Britain, and British people brought it to Canada. The French-Canadian version is called pichenotte.
Pichenotte can be played by two to four people and is a game of skill. Each player has 12 pieces, or 'pucks', which they flick across a round board using their fingers. If a puck goes into a small hole, it is worth 20 points. There are three rings around the hole worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game has eight small posts that make it harder to play. A game usually lasts about two minutes.
When the brothers saw how much people liked the game at the bar, they made more boards and took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people came to buy them, and the game became more popular. Soon, they started having championships and created a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. As more people learned about the game, the boards sold quickly. The brothers decided to make pichenotte their full-time job. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12 kg, and is 1 cm thick. Norm said, "They're very strong because they need to last a long time." 
The boards are sold for $595 each on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows about the game yet, but the brothers hope that one day they will be able to buy a luxury car instead of using their garage for making boards. For now, they enjoy playing the game that they hope will bring them success.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**
When you first enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just a piece of empty land, covered in weeds. For a long time, people thought it was useless. But one man, with the help of his wife, worked very hard to change this land into the beautiful village you see today. 
Many tons of soil and clay were moved to change the flat land into the lovely landscape you see now. Bulldozers and digging machines helped, but a lot of hard work was also done by hand. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tons of topsoil were added to create the lawns, flower beds, and rock gardens. 
In building the Model Village, hundreds of trees and bushes were planted. These plants were chosen carefully because they needed to survive near the sea and withstand strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden centers, but some were brought from as far away as Canada and New Zealand.
The whole village was created by Colin Sims, who made over 100 models by hand over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from different materials like stone, concrete, treated wood, and plastic to resist all kinds of weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn how to choose the right materials, but soon he became an expert himself.
You will notice that everything is built to the same scale, and even the smallest details are carefully made. This took a lot of patience and special building techniques. The Model Village is very popular and is known for its high quality and good maintenance. The methods used here have been copied in other model villages in England and even taught in some colleges.
All the buildings in the village show traditional British styles and are not based on one specific place. One of the most impressive buildings is the Manor House, which is a typical 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It is inspired by manor houses found in the West Country. 
As you walk around the village, you will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is the newest addition. Please stay on the paths during your visit and do not touch the models; if you accidentally break something, it can take us a long time to fix it. You can take photos from the pathways only. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.
To make your visit more enjoyable, you will find buttons in front of some models. Press these buttons to see the models move. At the end of your visit, we would love to hear your comments. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us create a more interesting display. We also want to know if you saw any models that need improvement. We are always updating the models and need your feedback.
We hope you enjoy your visit and look forward to seeing you again. Don’t forget to tell your friends about us!

Every week, British tabloid newspapers publish pictures that invade people's privacy and break the rules set by newspaper editors. While some pop stars do take pictures with paparazzi sometimes, this is not common. Most of the time, it hurts public figures when their private moments are shown on the front page. However, very few people ask for help from the Press Complaints Commission (PCC), which was created to handle these problems. These pictures rarely serve the public interest. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How does a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help keep people safe? The actress has complained about long-distance photos before, and since she was in a hotel, where people expect privacy, she had a good reason to complain, but she did not take any action. It is a scandal that the PCC did not start an investigation. The PCC should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. Like the actress, the pop star has not made a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC take action against these unfair attacks?
This seems like a good idea. It could lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers would report on this, and it would be shown on TV and radio. The public would not support these newspapers, and editors would have to stop publishing such stories. Photographers would also be affected, as they would not be able to afford to hide and take pictures of celebrities anymore. If the PCC decided to act like a "police officer," there would be some problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it talk to the victim and encourage them to complain? And if the person still did not want to do anything, should the PCC still act? Also, celebrities and royals might expect the PCC to take action on stories about them, and they could be upset if it does not happen. 
The job of the PCC is very big. How could it monitor all of the British press, including national and regional newspapers and magazines? There is also the issue of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want the added embarrassment of an investigation? Most people probably just want to move on with their lives. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They could have a worse story that they do not want to be made public if they complain. In this way, the PCC might become a problem for them too. 
One British comedian faced issues with the press when he and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He did not complain then, and he also did not complain when he and his family were photographed during a holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger, saying they thought it was just a joke and that he, being a comedian, would have a sense of humor about it. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many college graduates get advice when they start their first job. This article talks about what to think about when looking for a second job. We are not talking about people who want a temporary job while looking for a permanent one or those who leave a job they don’t like after a few weeks. Instead, we focus on those who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do next.
What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. You need to think about whether you want to specialize in a certain area, move up to a job with more responsibility, or change to a different field. Whatever you choose, it is important to pick your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in this job for two to three years. Future employers will look closely at this job when you apply for your next one. It should show that you are serious about your career. Most importantly, it should help you grow, develop your skills, and give you more responsibilities.
If you want to travel, now might be a good time to do it. You can work temporarily when you come back and then find your second job. Employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are not likely to leave again soon.
Juliette Davidson spent her first year after college working for three lawyers. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned how to work in an office and improved her typing skills. However, there was no chance for promotion. One day, she decided to leave, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year.
Now, Juliette works as a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. She says, "In two and a half years, I have become more skilled, and my job has really grown." From the start, her boss wanted to help her develop. Although her job title is the same, her responsibilities have changed. She now does most of the correspondence and budgets and answers questions from company chairmen and people wanting to start their own businesses. Brenda includes her in all her work and gives her specific projects and events to organize.

'Confident People: What's Their Secret?'**
Confident people seem like they were born that way, but most say it is a skill they learned. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.
**A. Jenny**  
When I finished school, I was very shy and thought I would always be that way. When I was about twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous, but I did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. On my first day, I was very anxious, but my confidence grew over time. Working at the school changed my life and helped me become more outgoing.
**B. Michaela**  
Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and became too aggressive. I thought that was how confident people acted, but I learned that confidence comes from believing in yourself. If work gets too hard, I don’t feel guilty about leaving some tasks for the next day. When I face something difficult, I remind myself that I have nothing to lose. Fear can make you feel less confident, so I talk to myself to calm those fears.
**C. Lisa**  
People think I am very confident, but I often feel scared inside. I learned to look confident because it is important in my job in TV. Interviewing people showed me that many of us feel tense in important situations. We feel better when we talk to friendly people. My mother once told me that everyone is too busy worrying about themselves to notice me. I remember this advice often. I also believe you gain confidence by facing your fears. I was very nervous during my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt I could handle anything.
**D. Barbara**  
My confidence comes from enjoying my work, but I have built it up over the years. If you keep working and learn from mistakes, you will feel more confident next time. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone will like you. You need to accept yourself and not try to be what others want. My company offers training courses, which have helped my self-esteem. Setting small goals helps too. It feels good to achieve something instead of trying to do everything at once and ending up with nothing.
**E. Kim**  
After college, I worked as a secretary and often sat in meetings without speaking up. Eventually, I found the confidence to share my thoughts. When I started working in politics, I was very nervous about speaking in public. I told myself that many people do this every day, so I could too. I also found it helpful to write down some notes to help me feel more secure. I believe everyone feels a bit nervous when speaking in public. The real secret to confidence is to keep telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

**Visit to Malaysia**
Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a nervous night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled widely when I gave him his torn kite. "You have to keep it," he said. "It's traditional - if the line breaks, finders keepers... and anyway, I have many more." He pointed to a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All the kites were exactly 120 cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat down in the shade of the tall trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and looked at Malaysia's biggest kite festival.
In the center of the beach, there were 10 platforms where helpers held up the kites. A line of nervous competitors held the lines of their kites and waited for the countdown. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered, and the kites flew into the air like rockets. More than 500 men and boys had signed up for the competition, which lasts for five days every year. Each person entered four different kite designs, which were judged on decoration, stability in the air, and how well they flew. 
"Flying kites isn't so difficult," said Adnan, "but making them takes real skill. Visit me at home, and I'll show you how to do it." I received five invitations that day, and I decided to accept his. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers in a large, nice room. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help rebuild his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, through beautiful mountains covered in rainforest.
I took a wrong turn, and the smooth road ended at a river. A small boat was waiting to take people across. Nearby, I saw a sign that pointed up a path into the forest and said: "Jelawang Jungle 3 km." Before I started walking, it would have been good to know that most of the path was steep and slippery. When I reached the campsite, I found a man named Baba waiting with a flask of tea. He took care of a kitchen and a few bamboo huts. I decided to stay there, trying not to think about the insects under my thin mattress. 
At night, it was very dark and full of different sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many creatures moved and made noise. In the morning, there was a great view of five ranges of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning struck the trees. A moment later, I was soaked. As I slid down the hill, I wondered how the giant butterflies avoided the big drops. I also worried about my car getting washed away (it sometimes happens) and if I would drown if I opened my mouth. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the hill.
In Kota Bahru, the capital of Kelantan, everyone asked me questions: "Where are you from?" "How old are you?" But they were friendly. Kelantan is known for its kites, but I remember it more for the kindness of its people.

**What kind of shopper are you?**
We all go shopping, but we do it in different ways. Do you know what type of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.
A. **Melanie, 22, dancer**  
"I love shopping! I can't spend enough money! When I have cash, I go shopping and it makes me happy. I find it hard to walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we often go shopping together. We are both addicted to shopping!"
B. **Brenda, 40, office manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he likes. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but it’s not fun because we all like different things. I don’t spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel guilty and tell my husband I spent less than I really did."
C. **Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
"I only shop for what I really need. I hate shopping and only go when I have to. When I do go, I know exactly what I want and I don’t want anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I would rather be doing something else."
D. **Anita, 35, TV producer**  
"I like to look around sometimes, but I usually know what I want and where to find it. I don’t waste time and try to shop quickly. However, I have bought things I didn’t really need, so maybe I’m careful but sometimes make mistakes."
E. **Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
"I really don’t like shopping. I find it hard to find clothes I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. Luckily, I don’t have to shop for clothes often because I get most of my clothes for free. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and do it quickly."
F. **Lisa, 22, actress**  
"I think I’m a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we often end up buying things. I don’t usually go with a specific item in mind, but if I see something I like, I buy it."
G. **Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
"I’m a careful shopper. I enjoy shopping, but I don’t buy a lot. I usually know what I want and don’t spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but then I often feel worse because I spent too much money."
H. **Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
"I love shopping, but only on certain days and never on Saturdays because it’s too busy. I’m a careful shopper. I have an idea of what I want before I go, and I don’t buy things right away. I check other shops to find better prices, which takes a long time!"
I. **Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
"I don’t like shopping much, maybe because I work in the city and the shops don’t interest me anymore. When I have to shop, I go but don’t try things on because it’s too much trouble. The clothes I buy don’t always fit, but I don’t care too much. I’d rather make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping."
